revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10ehf1)
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} [[File:Looking for a tactical vehicle 1033.png|thumb|right|Slide from the [[Defense Logistics Agency]]'s brochure, describing the '''1033 Program''''s transfer of military equipment to American police forces.]]
In the [[United States]], the '''1033 Program''' transfers excess [[military equipment]] to [[civilian]] [[law enforcement agencies]]. The program legally requires the Department of Defense to make various items of equipment available to local law enforcement.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dla.mil/AboutDLA/News/NewsArticleView/Article/998344/shedding-light/|title=Shedding Light|work=Defense Logistics Agency|access-date=2018-02-21|language=en-US}}</ref>
{{As of|2014}}, 8,000 local law enforcement agencies participated in the program that has transferred $5.1 billion in military material from the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] to [[law enforcement in the United States|law enforcement agencies]] since 1997.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Poynton |first1=Aaron |title=Military & Civilian Resources: Doing More With Less |url=http://www.domesticpreparedness.com/pub/docs/DPJSeptember14.pdf |website=Domestic Preparedness |publisher=Domestic Preparedness Journal |accessdate=4 February 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6XKhUGKS2?url=http://www.domesticpreparedness.com/pub/docs/DPJSeptember14.pdf |archivedate=27 March 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> According to the [[Defense Logistics Agency]], material worth $449 million was transferred in 2013 alone. Some of the most commonly requested items include ammunition, cold weather clothing, sand bags, medical supplies, sleeping bags, flashlights and electrical wiring. Small arms and vehicles such as aircraft, watercraft and armored vehicles have also been obtained.
The program has been criticized over the years by local media, by the [[Office of the Inspector General, U.S. Department of Defense]] in 2003, and by the [[GAO]] which found waste, fraud and abuse. It was not until media coverage of police during August [[2014 Ferguson unrest]] that the program drew nationwide public attention; the Ferguson Police Department had equipment obtained through the 1033 program.<ref>https://www.usatoday.com/story/opinion/2014/08/13/ferguson-police-michael-brown-militarization-column/14006383/</ref>
President Obama signed Executive Order 13688 on May 2015 limiting and prohibiting certain types of equipment.<ref name="Obama bans">{{cite news|last1=Korte|first1=Gregory|title=Obama bans some military equipment sales to police|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2015/05/18/obama-police-military-equipment-sales-new-jersey/27521793/|accessdate=28 August 2017|work=USA Today|date=18 May 2015}}</ref><ref name="Recommendations re: EO 13688">{{cite web|title=Recommendations Pursuant to Executive Order 13688|url=https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/sites/default/files/docs/le_equipment_wg_final_report_final.pdf|website=Obama White House Archives|publisher=White House|accessdate=28 August 2017}}</ref> On 28 August 2017 President Trump rolled back Obama's Executive Order.<ref name="Trump lifts ban">{{cite news|last1=Johnson|first1=Kevin|title=Trump expected to lift ban on military gear to local police forces|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2017/08/27/trump-expected-lift-ban-military-gear-local-police-forces/606065001/|accessdate=28 August 2017|work=USA Today|date=28 August 2017}}</ref> The [[ACLU]] and the [[NAACP]] have raised concerns about they call the [[militarization of police]] forces in the US. Attorney General Jeff Sessions announced the move early Monday morning of that week at the Fraternal Order of Police convention in Nashville, and said the president would do so by executive order.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/true-crime/wp/2017/08/27/trump-restores-program-sending-surplus-military-weapons-equipment-to-police/|title=Trump to restore program sending surplus military weapons, equipment to police|last=Jackman|first=Tom|date=2017-08-27|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-03-22|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref> At the same time, [[United States Attorney General|Attorney General]] [[Jeff Sessions]] and the director of the [[Fraternal Order of Police]] (FOP) pointed out the use of 1033 equipment as life saving devices seeing restrictions on distributing military surplus to police as “too far." The FOP also pointed out that the armored vehicles weren't tanks.<ref name="Trump lifts ban" />
==History==
===Predecessor, 1943–1949=== In 1944, the [[Surplus Property Act]] provided for the disposal of surplus government property, and spawned numerous short lived agencies like the Surplus War Property Administration (SWPA), in the Office of War Mobilization (OWM, February–October 1944), the Surplus Property Board (SPB), in the Office of War Mobilization and Reconversion (OWMR, October 1944 – September 1945), the Surplus Property Administration and also corporations like the Petroleum Reserves Corporation (PRC) and the War Assets Corporation to deal with it. The [[War Assets Administration]] was the latest to operate and was abolished in 1949.
===1990–2014=== The "National Defense Authorization Act of 1990", section 1208 authorized transfer of [[military hardware]] from the Department of Defense broadly to "federal and state agencies", but specifically "for use in counter-drug activities".<ref name=LESO>{{cite web|author1=Law Enforcement Support Office (LESO)|title=1033 Program FAQ|url=http://www.dispositionservices.dla.mil/leso/Pages/1033ProgramFAQs.aspx#q1|publisher=DLA Disposition Services|accessdate=27 November 2014|date=n.d.|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141202031945/http://www.dispositionservices.dla.mil/leso/pages/1033programfaqs.aspx#q1#q1|archive-date=2 December 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name=wofford>{{cite news|last1=Wofford|first1=Taylor|title=How America's Police Became an Army: The 1033 Program|url=http://www.newsweek.com/how-americas-police-became-army-1033-program-264537|accessdate=16 August 2014|agency=Newsweek|date=13 August 2014}}</ref> as this legislation was passed in the context of the [[War on Drugs]].<ref name=wofford /><ref name=dw>{{cite news|last1=Walker|first1=Richard|title=US police go military with 1033 program|url=http://www.dw.de/us-police-go-military-with-1033-program/a-17857709|accessdate=18 August 2014|publisher=Deutsche Welle|date=15 August 2014}}</ref> Until 1997, it was called the '''1208 program''' and run by the Department of Defense from the Pentagon and its regional offices.<ref name=1033brochure>{{cite web|title=The 1033 Program|url=http://www.dispositionservices.dla.mil/leso/Documents/LESO%20Forms/1033%20Program.pptx|publisher=US Government Defense Logistics Agency|date=n.d.|accessdate=16 August 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141130143525/http://www.dispositionservices.dla.mil/leso/Documents/LESO%20Forms/1033%20Program.pptx#|archive-date=30 November 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In 1995, the "Law Enforcement Support Office" was created within the DLA to work exclusively with law enforcement.<ref name=1033brochure />
With passage of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1997, the 1208 program was expanded to the 1033 program allowing "all law enforcement agencies to acquire property for bona fide law enforcement purposes that assist in their arrest and apprehension mission", and that "Preference is given to counter-drug and counter-terrorism requests".<ref name=LESO/> It was signed into law by President Bill Clinton on 23 September 1996.<ref>https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/104/hr3230</ref>
In October the [[DLA Disposition Services]] first released information about the equipment distribution by county. An inflection point occurred in the fall 2014 after several events brought increasing public scrutiny, and the eventual release of Federal records on the movement of military goods to civilian police forces was made public on November 21, 2014. <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.themarshallproject.org/2014/12/03/the-pentagon-finally-details-its-weapons-for-cops-giveaway|title=The Pentagon Finally Details its Weapons-for-Cops Giveaway|date=2014-12-03|access-date=2018-03-18}}</ref> <ref name=federalist20141219>{{cite news |last1=Bottum|first1=Joseph |title=National Security: Even Small Towns Are Loading Up On Grenade Launchers |url=http://thefederalist.com/2014/12/19/even-small-towns-are-loading-up-on-grenade-launchers/ |accessdate=21 December 2014 |work=The Federalist |date=19 December 2014}}</ref>
==Description== The [[DLA Disposition Services|U.S. Defense Logistics Agency Disposition Services]] (DLA) help the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] to dispose of its "excess property [...] from air conditioners to vehicles, clothing to computers" by "transfer to other federal agencies, or donation to state and local governments and other qualified organizations", as well as by "sale of surplus property".<ref name="DLADSabout us">{{cite web|author1=DLA Disposition Services Public Affairs|title=About Us|url=http://www.dispositionservices.dla.mil/Pages/About_Disposition_Services.aspx|publisher=DLA Disposition Services|accessdate=27 November 2014|date=n.d.|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141118163512/http://www.dispositionservices.dla.mil/Pages/About_Disposition_Services.aspx#|archive-date=18 November 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Availability of surplus equipment has been facilitated by the [[U.S.–Iraq Status of Forces Agreement|reduced American presence in Iraq]] and Afghanistan.<ref name=dw /> The 1033 program is designed to specifically work with [[law enforcement agency|law enforcement agencies]], like local police forces, school district police and others.
===Material donated=== From 1997 until 2014, $5.1 billion in military hardware were transferred from the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] to local American [[law enforcement agency|law enforcement agencies]], according to DLA's "Law Enforcement Support Office" (LESO) and material worth $449 million was transferred in 2013 alone.<ref name=LESO /><ref name=ingraham>{{cite news|last1=Ingraham|first1=Christopher|title=The Pentagon gave nearly half a billion dollars of military gear to local law enforcement last year|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/wonkblog/wp/2014/08/14/the-pentagon-gave-nearly-half-a-billion-dollars-of-military-gear-to-local-law-enforcement-last-year/|date=14 August 2014|accessdate=16 August 2014|work=Wonkblog|publisher=The Washington Post}}</ref> About a third of the equipment is new.<ref name=dansky>{{cite web |url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/08/19/opinion/dansky-militarization-police/?hpt=ob_articlefooter&iref=obinsite |author=Kara Dansky| title=Emotions run high in Ferguson, Missouri |work=CNN Opinion|publisher=Turner Broadcasting System, Inc.| date=19 August 2014}}</ref> The most commonly obtained item from the 1033 program is ammunition. Other most commonly requested items include cold weather clothing, sand bags, medical supplies, sleeping bags, flashlights and electrical wiring.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Cook|first1=Lindsey|title=Most Popular Items in the Defense Department's 1033 Program|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/blogs/data-mine/2014/08/21/most-popular-items-in-the-defense-departments-1033-program|publisher=U.S. News|accessdate=15 January 2015}}</ref> The 1033 program also transfers office equipment such as fax machines, which many smaller police departments are unable to afford. The DLA also offers tactical armored vehicles, weapons, including grenade launchers, watercraft, and aircraft.<ref name=1033brochure /><ref name=ppt>{{cite web|author1=DLA Disposition Services|title=1033 Program Overview|url=http://www.dispositionservices.dla.mil/leso/Documents/LESO%20Forms/1033%20Program.pptx|publisher=LESO|accessdate=27 November 2014|pages=69|format=powerpoint presentation|date=22 July 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141130143525/http://www.dispositionservices.dla.mil/leso/Documents/LESO%20Forms/1033%20Program.pptx#|archive-date=30 November 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Police departments=== {{As of|2014}}, 8,000 local law enforcement agencies participate in the reutilization program.<ref name=LESO /> Police departments are responsible for paying for shipment and storage of material acquired, but do not pay for the donation. The largest number of requests for material comes from small to mid-sized police departments who are unable to afford extra clothing, vehicles and weapons. The program gives smaller police departments access to material that larger police departments are usually able to afford without federal assistance.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Firozi|first1=Paulina|title=Police forces pick up surplus military supplies|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2014/06/15/local-law-enforcement-agencies-surplus-military-equipment/10286485/|publisher=USA Today|accessdate=15 January 2015}}</ref> A [[memorandum of agreement]] between the DLA and the states participating in 1033 requires that local police forces either utilize the military equipment within one year or return it.<ref name=dw /> The rules allow police to dispose of or sell some goods after at least one year of usage.<ref name=az/>
===School districts=== {{As of| September 2014}} more than twenty [[school district]] police agencies received military-grade equipment through the program.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://talkingpointsmemo.com/dc/school-districts-1033-program-military-equipment|title = Report: School Districts Are Receiving Free Military Gear From The Pentagon|publisher = Talking Points Memo|accessdate=15 September 2014|date=September 2014}}</ref> The [[San Diego school district]] planned to return a military surplus vehicle after negative public reaction.<ref name=KPBS>{{cite news|author1=Associated Press|title=San Diego School Police To Return 18-Ton Military Vehicle|url=http://www.kpbs.org/news/2014/sep/18/san-diego-school-police-return-18-ton-military-veh/|accessdate=28 November 2014|work=KPBS|publisher=KPBS Public Broadcasting|date=September 2014}}</ref>
The [[Los Angeles School Police Department]] has also received excess military equipment, including 61 assault rifles, three grenade launchers, and an [[MRAP]] vehicle.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Pamer|first1=Melissa|last2=Romero|first2=Lynette|title=LAUSD Police Arsenal Includes Armored Vehicle, Grenade Launchers, Chief Confirms|url=http://ktla.com/2014/09/15/lausd-police-arsenal-includes-armored-vehicle-grenade-launchers-chief-confirms/|accessdate=2 December 2017|publisher=KTLA 5|date=15 September 2014}}</ref> Ten School Police Departments in Texas also participate in the 1033 program, in total acquiring 25 [[automatic pistols]], 64 [[M16 rifles|M16 assault rifles]], 18 [[M14 rifle|M14 assault rifle]]s, 15 vehicles and [[Improved Outer Tactical Vest|tactical vests]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Noll|first1=Scott|title=Military Rifles, Armor Sent to Texas School Police|url=http://www.khou.com/news/investigations/military-rifles-armor-sent-to-texas-school-police/259166309|accessdate=2 December 2017|publisher=KHOU 11|date=5 September 2014}}</ref>
As of 2014, at least 117 colleges and universities in the United States have used the 1033 program to acquire military-grade equipment through their campus police departments.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.chronicle.com/article/On-Campus-Grenade-Launchers/148749|title=On Campus, Grenade Launchers, M-16s, and Armored Vehicles|date=2014-09-11|work=The Chronicle of Higher Education|access-date=2017-12-02}}</ref> Higher education institutions that participate in the program include local community colleges, state universities, and Ivy Leagues, ranging from [[Hinds Community College]], [[University of Central Florida]], [[University of California]], [[Columbia University]], and [[Yale University|Yale]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/ppm9zv/the-pentagon-is-giving-grenade-launchers-to-campus-police-904|title=The Pentagon Is Giving Grenade Launchers to Campus Police|date=2014-09-05|work=Vice|access-date=2017-12-02|language=en-us}}</ref>
In 2012, the [[University of California, Berkeley|University of California at Berkeley]] attempted to use the federal program to acquire an Armored Response Counter Attack Truck, also referred to as a [[Lenco BearCat]], to deal with possible campus shootings, but public outcry forced UC Berkeley Chancellor [[Robert J. Birgeneau|Robert Birgenau]] to reverse procurement of the eight-ton armored truck.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/07/06/university-of-california-armored-truck_n_1654032.html|title=University Of California, Berkeley Campus Police Will Not Be Allowed To Buy Armored Truck|last=Kingkade|first=Tyler|date=2012-07-06|work=Huffington Post|access-date=2017-12-02|language=en-US}}</ref> In 2013, Ohio State University acquired an [[MRAP]] (Mine-Resistant Ambush Protected) vehicle that was equipped with a machine gun turret, becoming the first campus in the U.S. to integrate this kind of military-grade equipment into their campus police department.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/09/18/ohio-state-university-armored-truck_n_3949750.html|title=Ohio State University Acquires Military-Style Armored Truck (PHOTO)|last=Stuart|first=Hunter|date=2013-09-18|work=Huffington Post|access-date=2017-12-06|language=en-US}}</ref> [[Florida State University]] used the program to acquire a [[Humvee]], which campus police say is only to be used in the case of an active shooter, not a civil disturbance.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Grasgreen|first1=Allie|title=Military Hardware for College Cops|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2014/08/defense-surplus-university-police-110323|accessdate=2 December 2017|date=25 August 2014}}</ref> [[Central Washington University]] has also received an armored truck through the program, claiming the truck is used to train for active-shooter scenarios.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/15/campus-police-weapons_n_5823310.html|title=Campus Police Are Stocking Up On Military-Grade Weapons|last=Kingkade|first=Tyler|date=2014-09-15|work=Huffington Post|access-date=2017-12-06|last2=Svokos|first2=Alexandra|language=en-US}}</ref> The most popular military equipment acquired by colleges and universities through the 1033 program is the [[M16 rifle|M16]]. Campus police at the [[Arizona State University]] currently hold the most M16’s with a total of 70, followed by [[Florida International University]] and the [[University of Maryland]], which both carry 50 M16’s. <ref>{{cite news|last1=Bauman|first1=Dan|title=Campus Police Acquire Military Weapons|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/22/world/americas/campus-police-acquire-military-weapons.html|accessdate=2 December 2017|publisher=The New York Times|date=21 September 2014}}</ref>
The [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]]<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.chronicle.com/article/On-Campus-Grenade-Launchers/148749|title=On Campus, Grenade Launchers, M-16s, and Armored Vehicles|last=Bauman|first=Dan|date=11 September 2014|website=The Chronicle of Higher Education|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> has provided a variety of military and police equipment to both private and public universities across the country. Equipment allocated has ranged from gauze,<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/2017/09/16/why-are-us-universities-arming-themselves-with-grenade-launchers_partner/.|title=Why are US universities arming themselves with grenade launchers?|last=Karioris|first=Frank|date=27 September 2017|website=Salon|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> trousers, and other basic supplies, to armored vehicles,<ref name=":1" /> grenade launchers, and [[M16 assault rifle|M-16 assault rifles]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/adamandrzejewski/2017/08/31/tracking-military-weaponry-and-war-machines-flowing-to-americas-local-police-departments/#415c3582b636|title=Tracking Military Weaponry and War Machines Flowing to America's Local Police Departments|last=Andrzejewski|first=Adam|date=1 September 2017|website=Forbes Magazine|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Many spokespersons for colleges and universities that received this military equipment have cited cost efficiency as the main motivation for engaging in this partnership, including [[University of Florida]]’s dean of students Jen Day Shaw, who stated that the program "is a cost savings for taxpayers.”<ref name=":0" />
Participating campus departments pay only for delivery and maintenance of allocated military supplies, paying a mere $507.43 for as many as 12 M-16 rifles ([[University of Louisiana at Monroe]]).<ref name=":0" /> If colleges and universities seek to acquire material not obtainable directly through the 1033 program, like other local law enforcement agencies, they may purchase said equipment through federal grants allocated by the [[Department of Defense (US)|DOD]]. Another justification for involvement in the 1033 program is the epidemic of school shootings on U.S. campuses, with many college and university representatives citing the [[Virginia Tech shooting]] as reason for concern and increased militarization of campus police departments.<ref name=":0" />
In instances where campus police departments fail to or do not directly attempt to acquire excess military material from the 1033 program, partnership with local and regional law enforcement through [[Mutual aid (emergency services)|mutual aid]] allows colleges and universities to indirectly benefit from the program by utilizing military equipment obtained by law enforcement agencies in the surrounding area.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/07/06/university-of-california-armored-truck_n_1654032.html|title=University Of California, Berkeley Campus Police Will Not Be Allowed To Buy Armored Truck|last=Kingkade|first=Tyler|date=2012-07-06|work=Huffington Post|access-date=2017-12-06|language=en-US}}</ref> Where police jurisdiction overlaps between college and universities and the municipal area they inhabit, the acquisition of material such as an [[MRAP]] by a municipal law enforcement agency can substitute acquisition by a campus police department, as was the case between the city of [[Davis, California|Davis]], CA and the [[University of California, Davis|University of California at Davis]] in 2014.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.sacbee.com/news/local/crime/article2607226.html|title=Davis acquires mine-resistant war vehicle while some complain of militarization of police|date=2014-08-20|work=The Sacramento Bee|access-date=2017-12-06|language=en-US|issn=0890-5738}}</ref>
===Oversight=== Law enforcement agencies must declare the intended use for each item, maintain an audit trail for each item and conduct inventory checks for DLA. Firearms, certain vehicles and other equipment must be returned to the Defense Department after use.<ref name=az/> "For security reasons [1033 program record] information is not subject to public review", per DLA.<ref name=az/>
A state coordinating agency in each U.S. state, except for Hawaii, headed by a state coordinator that is appointed by the state governor must approve an application, and is supposed to function as oversight after dispersion of equipment.<ref name=ACFS>{{cite web|author1=Daniela Guzman|title='From warfighter to crimefighter' – the US 1033 program, and the risk of corruption and misuse of public funds|url=http://www.acfcs.org/from-warfighter-to-crimefighter-the-us-1033-program-and-the-risk-of-corruption-and-misuse-of-public-funds/|publisher=Association of Certified Financial Crime Specialists|accessdate=28 November 2014|date=29 August 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141205152727/http://www.acfcs.org/from-warfighter-to-crimefighter-the-us-1033-program-and-the-risk-of-corruption-and-misuse-of-public-funds/#|archive-date=5 December 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The state coordinating agency is housed within a state agency that varies from state to state, for example in the Alabama Department of Economic and Community Affairs, the Alaska Department of Public Safety and so on.<ref name=statelist>{{cite web|author1=Law Enforcement Support Office|title=State Coordinator Contact List|url=http://www.dispositionservices.dla.mil/leso/Pages/StateCoordinatorList.aspx#Florida|publisher=DLA|accessdate=28 November 2014|date=n.d.|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141205103749/http://www.dispositionservices.dla.mil/leso/Pages/StateCoordinatorList.aspx#Florida#Florida|archive-date=5 December 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The fact that in Arizona a [[Payson, Arizona]] Police Department Detective, was appointed as the state coordinator, made it easier for [[Paul Babeu]], Sheriff of [[Pinal County, Arizona]] to amass "more than $7 million worth of Humvees, fire trucks, firearms, defibrillators, barber chairs, underwear, thermal-imaging scopes, computers, motor scooters and other in 2010–2012, which he told county supervisors he would auction off to balance his budget.<ref name=az/> This is because the detective had appointed an office grants administrator in the Pinal County Sheriff Office to help him "oversee and authorize military-surplus requisitions". The Sheriff's speaker described it as chance to cherry-pick, "as we can start approving our own requests".<ref name=az/> After the [[Arizona Republic]] newspaper expose the DLA "announced agency-wide reforms, and Sheriff Paul Babeu was directed to retrieve vehicles and other equipment his office distributed to non-police organizations" and "about the same time, weapons requisitions were temporarily suspended and audited nationwide.<ref name=az2014>{{cite news|author1=Dennis Wagner|title=Police in combat gear stir criticism|url=http://www.azcentral.com/story/news/local/arizona/2014/08/20/police-combat-gear-stir-criticism/14324639/|accessdate=28 November 2014|work=The Arizona Republic|publisher=Gannett Company|date=20 August 2014}}</ref>
In 2003, a [[Office of the Inspector General, U.S. Department of Defense|Defense Department Inspector General]] audit found incorrect or inadequate documentation in about three-quarters of the transactions analyzed, declaring 1033 Program records unreliable.<ref name=az>{{cite news|author1=Dennis Wagner|title=Pinal Sheriff's Office stockpiles, prepares to sell military equipment|url=http://www.azcentral.com/news/politics/articles/2012/05/04/20120504pinal-county-surplus-military-equipment.html#ixzz3KJLGWRkQ|accessdate=27 November 2014|work=The Republic|publisher=Gannett, azcentral.com|date=19 May 2012}}</ref>
In 2005, the [[Government Accountability Office]] found that the Pentagon "does not have management controls in place" to avert waste, abuse and fraud in the program. Investigators identified "hundreds of millions of dollars in reported lost, damaged, or stolen excess property ... which contributed to reutilization program waste and inefficiency."<ref name=az/>
== Political responses ==
In August 2014, the militarized response to [[2014 Ferguson unrest|civil unrest in Ferguson]], Missouri led to increased criticism of the 1033 program: *U.S. senator [[Rand Paul]], a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]], stated that the American government "has incentivized the militarization of local police precincts and helped municipal governments build what are essentially small armies."<ref name=dw /><ref name=RandP>{{cite news|author1=Rand Paul|title=Rand Paul: We Must Demilitarize the Police|url=http://time.com/3111474/rand-paul-ferguson-police/|accessdate=27 November 2014|work=Time Magazine|publisher=Time Warner|date=14 August 2014}}</ref> *Congressman [[Hank Johnson]], a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]], drafted legislation proposing to curb, but not end the 1033 program, urged legislative armed services committee to suspend the transfer of some equipment.<ref name=hill>{{cite news|author1=Mario Trujillo and Jesse Byrnes|title=Lawmaker drafting bill to demilitarize local police 108|url=http://thehill.com/policy/defense/215160-lawmaker-drafting-bill-to-stem-flow-of-tanks-and-m16s-to-police|accessdate=27 November 2014|work=The Hill|publisher=Capitol Hill Publishing Corp.|date=14 August 2014}}</ref> *President Obama ordered a review of the program.<ref name=Reuters>{{cite news|author1=Steve Holland|author2=Andrea Shalal|title=Obama orders review of police use of military hardware|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/08/24/us-usa-missouri-shooting-militarization-idUSKBN0GN0O920140824|accessdate=24 August 2014|work=Reuters.com|date=24 August 2014}}</ref>
In September 2014, [[Senator Claire McCaskill]] organized the Senate's first hearing on the program, and federal officials faced bipartisan criticism: *Brian Kamoie, assistant administrator for grant programs at the [[Federal Emergency Management Agency]], stated that officials are conducting a review to determine if police forces deployed in Ferguson improperly used equipment purchased with the grants for riot suppression, which is not allowed. It was inconclusive from the questioning, how many times equipment was purchased with funds used to combat terrorism.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Nelson|first1=Steven|title=Pentagon Rethinks Giving MRAPs, Bayonets to Police|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2014/09/09/pentagon-will-rethink-giving-mraps-bayonets-to-police-official-says|website=US News|publisher=US News|accessdate=10 September 2014}}</ref> *Rear Admiral John Kirby, press secretary for the [[The Pentagon|Pentagon]], argued that the program has aided law enforcement across the US in counter-terrorism and counter-narcotic operation, and to protect civilians. He stated that the Pentagon was diligent in deciding what equipment was sent to specific police departments.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Lamothe|first1=Dan|title=Pentagon defends program supplying military gear to Ferguson police|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2014/08/19/pentagon-defends-program-supplying-military-gear-to-ferguson-police/|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=24 November 2014}}</ref> *Chuck Canterbury, president of the [[Fraternal Order of Police]], argued that [[mass shooting]]s could occur anywhere in the United States, even in small towns, and that the equipment obtained from the 1033 program is being used to protect civilians and law enforcement.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bruce|first1=Becky|title=Fraternal Order of Police defends 'militarization'|url=http://www.ksl.com/?nid=370&sid=31391932|publisher=KSL Radio|accessdate=24 November 2014}}</ref> *Congressman [[Buck McKeon]] scheduled a [[United States House Committee on Armed Services]] subcommittee "Oversight and Investigations" hearing to examine the program, which was postponed.<ref name=lillis/> *The [[House Judiciary Committee]] declined to review the program, stating that any review would follow an investigation by the Obama administration.<ref name=lillis>{{cite news|last1=Lillis|first1=Mike|title=Push to demilitarize cops in lame duck|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/house/222520-new-push-to-demilitarize-cops-in-lame-duck|accessdate=26 November 2014|agency=The Hill|date=1 November 2014}}</ref>
In October 2014, *Congressman [[Hank Johnson]] urged the heads of the Armed Services Committees to adopt a moratorium on the transfer of certain items and to eliminate a section of the House version of the 2015 Defense bill, passed earlier in 2014, that would expand equipment transfers to [[U.S. Customs and Border Protection|border security]], the nation's largest law enforcement agency.<ref name=lillis/>
In November 2014, *Rand Paul's second Ferguson op-ed in ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' did not mention the demilitarization of the police, which had been subject of his first op-ed, .<ref name=bloom>{{cite news|author1=David Weigel|title=How Police Unions Stopped Congress From 'Militarization' Reform|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2014-11-25/how-police-unions-stopped-congress-from-militarization-reform|accessdate=27 November 2014|work=Bloomberg News|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.|date=27 November 2014}}</ref> *Steve Rabinovich, a police officer writing for police website ''PoliceOne.com'', defended the 1033 program as necessary for protecting police officers from violent or deadly assaults by individuals or anti-government groups viewing police as scapegoats.<ref name=policeone>{{cite web|last1=Rabinovich|first1=Steve|title=Answering the critics of MRAPs and the 1033 Program|url=http://www.policeone.com/chiefs-sheriffs/articles/7774911-Answering-the-critics-of-MRAPs-and-the-1033-Program/|work=policeone.com|publisher=Praetorian Group, Inc|accessdate=26 November 2014|date=4 November 2014}}</ref> *The [[United States House Committee on Armed Services|House Committee on Armed Services]] reviewed the program, interviewed four witnesses, including the president of the [[Police Foundation]], the director of the National Tactical Officers Association, and two employees of the Department of Defense<ref name=ramey /><ref name=asc13nov>{{cite web|title=The Department of Defense Excess Property Program in Support of U.S. Law Enforcement Agencies: An Overview of DOD Authorities, Roles, Responsibilities, and Implementation of Section 1033 of the 1997 National Defense Authorization Act|url=http://armedservices.house.gov/index.cfm/hearings-display?ContentRecord_id=E248A7D4-556D-4B41-A794-B4DF23237150&ContentType_id=14F995B9-DFA5-407A-9D35-56CC7152A7ED&Group_id=64562e79-731a-4ac6-aab0-7bd8d1b7e890|author=House armed services committee|publisher=U.S. Congress|date=13 November 2014|accessdate=26 November 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141206014054/http://armedservices.house.gov/index.cfm/hearings-display?ContentRecord_id=E248A7D4-556D-4B41-A794-B4DF23237150&ContentType_id=14F995B9-DFA5-407A-9D35-56CC7152A7ED&Group_id=64562e79-731a-4ac6-aab0-7bd8d1b7e890#|archive-date=6 December 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and their heads, Reps. [[Buck McKeon]] (R-Calif.) and [[Adam Smith (politician)|Adam Smith]] (D-Wash.) are working on a compromise of the [[Howard P. "Buck" McKeon National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2015 (H.R. 4435; 113th Congress)|2015 defense authorization bill]], instead of a moratorium.<ref name=lillis/> *Senator McCaskill suggested that "Congress would seek to better train police to use transferred equipment".<ref name=mmsantoro>{{cite news|last1=McMorris-Santoro|first1=Evan|title=Washington Bails On Demilitarization After Ferguson|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/evanmcsan/washington-bails-on-police-demilitarization|accessdate=26 November 2014|agency=Buzzfeed|date=24 November 2014}}</ref> *The [[White House]] had not released results of its review, promised in September, when [[National Guard of the United States]] was deployed to Ferguson and further unrest occurred after the grand jury decision in Ferguson. Police lobbying efforts, and the [[United States elections, 2014|elections]] had rendered Congress [[Lame duck (politics)|lame duck]], and the support for ending or changing the 1033 program dwindled.<ref name=mmsantoro />
In May 2015, following the [[2015 Baltimore protests]], Obama announced reviews of the use of military equipment, stating "We've seen how militarized gear sometimes gives people a feeling like they are an occupying force as opposed to a part of the community there to protect them," and "Some equipment made for the battlefield is not appropriate for local police departments."<ref>https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-politics/wp/2015/05/18/obama-to-visit-camden-n-j-to-tout-community-policing-reforms/</ref><ref>https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/05/18/us-usa-race-obama-idUSKBN0O30UQ20150518</ref>
===Other criticism=== Kara Dansky, senior counsel for the [[ACLU]], wrote that the federal government is deliberately militarizing local law enforcement agencies.<ref name=dansky/>
According to a study by [[social scientist]] Dr. Casey Delehanty and colleagues, larger 1033 transfers are associated with increased killings by police.<ref name="veconomist" >{{cite news|author=C.K.|title=The rhetorical power of "support our troops"|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/democracyinamerica/2017/10/patriotism-and-protest|work=[[The Economist]]|date=4 October 2017}}</ref>
==Police department suspensions== DLA public-affairs chief Kenneth MacNevin stated in 2012, that "more than 30 Arizona police agencies have been suspended or terminated for failing to meet program standards and nine remain under suspension".<ref name=az/> One of them was the [[Maricopa County, Arizona]] law enforcement after failing to account for 20 of the 200 military weapons it had received.<ref name=cassidy>{{cite news|last1=Cassidy|first1=Megan|title=MCSO missing nine weapons from Pentagon's 1033 program|url=http://www.azcentral.com/story/news/local/phoenix/2014/08/26/mcso-weapons-pentagon-suspension-1033/14659089/|accessdate=29 August 2014|agency=AZ Central|date=27 August 2014}}</ref> The suspension did not affect police acquisition of high powered weaponry due to anti-racketeering or confiscated drug funds, according to Maricopa's Sheriff.<ref name=cassidy />
In North Carolina, law officials are working to reinstate the 1033 program through more rigorous inventory management, after the state was suspended for failing to account for some transferred equipment.<ref name=ramey>{{cite news|last1=Ramey|first1=Elisse|title=1033 Program in Eastern North Carolina|url=http://www.witn.com/home/headlines/The-Military-Excess-Property-Program-in-Eastern-North-Carolina.html?ref=761|accessdate=26 November 2014|agency=WITN|date=24 November 2014}}</ref> North Carolina officials state that 3,303 out of the 4,227 pieces of equipment obtained through the program are tactical items including automatic weapons and military vehicles and the remainder is not used in combat, and includes cots, containers and generators.<ref name=ramey />
Fusion reported in August 2014 that a total of 184 state and local police departments had been suspended from the program for missing weapons and failure to comply with guidelines.<ref name=fusion>{{cite web| url=http://fusion.net/leadership/story/americas-police-departments-lose-loads-military-issued-weapons-984250| author=Daniel Rivero, Jorge Rivas |title= Fusion Investigates: How did America's police departments lose loads of military-issued weapons?| publisher=Fusion |date=26 August 2014| accessdate=27 August 2014}}</ref> Missing items included M14 and [[M16 rifle|M16 assault rifle]]s, pistols, shotguns, and two [[Humvee]] vehicles.<ref name=fusion/>
Investigative journalist Susan Katz Keating reported in October 2017 that certain elements of the program were restored despite the compliance issues.<ref>http://www.realclearinvestigations.com/articles/2017/10/05/pentagon_to_police_here_are_your_weapons_please_dont_lose_them_again.html</ref>
==See also== *[[DLA Disposition Services]] *[[Ferguson unrest]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2017}} {{Infobox company | name = Allbirds, Inc. | logo = Allbirds logo.png | image = Allbirds wool runners in white.jpg | image_caption = The Allbirds wool runners in white | type = [[Private company|Private]] | industry = Footwear | founded = {{start date and age|2014}} | location = [[San Francisco]], [[California]] | founders = [[Tim Brown (footballer)|Tim Brown]]
Joey Zwillinger | num_employees = | areas_served = [[United States]], [[Australia]], [[New Zealand]], [[Canada]] | num_employees_year = | website = {{url|http://allbirds.com}} }} '''Allbirds''' is a San Francisco-based direct-to-consumer startup aimed at designing environmentally friendly footwear.{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/4243338/allbirds-wool-runners/|title=The World's Most Comfortable Shoes Are Made of Super-Soft Wool|website=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|access-date=7 February 2017}} Allbirds first shoe was the Wool Runner, which is made from New Zealand superfine [[Merino|merino wool]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/11/technology/allbird-shoes-silicon-valley.html|title=To Fit Into Silicon Valley, Wear These Wool Shoes|last=Bowles|first=Nellie|date=2017-08-11|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-10-19|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} The company claims to keep the brand as eco-friendly as possible{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/01/01/allbirds-the-sustainable-sneaker-thats-growing-in-popularity-without-a-big-brand-name.html|title=This eco-friendly sneaker is attracting celebrities without the benefit of a big brand name|last=Findling|first=Deborah|date=1 January 2017|website=[[CNBC]]|access-date=7 February 2017}} and is a [[B Corporation (certification)|certified B Corporation]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.esquire.com/style/mens-fashion/news/a53540/allbirds-sustainable-sneakers-tim-brown-interview/|title=These Sneakers Are Affordable, Sustainable, and Genuinely Stylish|date=2017-03-02|work=[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]|access-date=2017-03-30|language=en}} In March 2018, the company started offering their footwear with [[eucalyptus]] tree fiber.{{Cite news|url=https://work.qz.com/1230230/allbirds-wool-sneaker-maker-is-now-making-shoes-from-eucalyptus-trees/|title=Allbirds, maker of Silicon Valley's "it" sneakers, is now making shoes from trees|last=MacLellan|first=Lila|date=15 March 2018|work=[[Quartz (publication)|Quartz]]|access-date=22 March 2018}} In August 2018, a [[Flip-flops|flip-flop]] collection made of [[bioplastic]] foam from [[sugar cane]] was released by Allbirds.{{Cite news|url=https://www.smh.com.au/lifestyle/fashion/these-game-changing-thongs-are-made-from-sugar-cane-20180802-p4zv4b.html|title=These 'game-changing' thongs are made from sugar cane|last=Economos|first=Nicole|date=2 August 2018|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|access-date=8 August 2018}} In October 2018, the company raised a $50M Series C, bringing its total valuation to $1.4B.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/trendy-sneaker-startup-allbirds-laces-up-1-4-billion-valuation-1539281112|title=Trendy Sneaker Startup Allbirds Laces Up $1.4 Billion Valuation|last=Copeland|first=Rob|date=2018-10-11|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-10-16|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}} == History == Allbirds co-founder [[Tim Brown (footballer)|Tim Brown]]{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/allbirds-wool-loungers-review|title=We tried 'the world's most comfortable shoes' to see if they're as great as everyone says they are|work=Business Insider|access-date=2017-11-03|language=en}} got the idea for the company while he was vice captain of the New Zealand football team. He had previously attended business school and used to make leather shoes for friends but was aware of how uncomfortable they were. In 2014, he received a [[Funding of science|research grant]] from the New Zealand wool industry to engineer a [[Sneakers|sneaker]]. He then launched his idea on [[Kickstarter]], raising $119,000 in five days.{{Cite news|url=http://observer.com/2016/04/allbirds-is-shaking-up-the-sneaker-market-with-a-pair-of-wool-shoes/|title=Allbirds is Shaking Up the Sneaker Market With a Pair of Wool Shoes|date=19 April 2016|newspaper=[[New York Observer|Observer]]|access-date=7 February 2017|language=en-US}} After launching on Kickstarter, Brown teamed up with Joey Zwillinger, a [[Biotechnology|biotech]] engineer and [[Renewable resource|renewable materials]] expert. The co-founders began developing their process and officially launched Allbirds in March 2016.{{Cite web |url=http://www.refinery29.com/2016/03/105001/allbirds-merino-wool-sneakers |title=The Comfiest Sneakers Ever Aren't What You'd Expect |date=27 December 2016 |first=Alyssa | last=Coscarelli| website=[[Refinery29]]|access-date=7 February 2017}} During their first year in business, the company raised $7.25 million from investors including [Maveron], [[Lerer Hippeau Ventures]], Red Sea Ventures, Slow Ventures, Peterson Partners, Antipodean and Western Technology Investment.{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/09/07/allbirds-raises-7-25-million-unveils-new-shoe-colors/|title=Allbirds raises $7.25 million, unveils new shoe colors|last=Roof|first=Katie|website=[[TechCrunch]]|access-date=7 February 2017}} In December 2017, Allbirds sued [[Steve Madden (company)|Steve Madden]], alleging that the company's Traveler shoes look nearly identical to its wool runners.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thecut.com/2017/12/steve-madden-sued-by-allbirds-over-wool-sneaker.html|title=Steve Madden Sued by Sustainable Start-up|last=Spellings|first=Sarah|date=13 December 2017|work=[[New York (magazine)|The Cut]]|access-date=5 August 2018}} As of 2017, the company had 50 employees in their San Francisco headquarters, 40 employees at the Nashville warehouse and 350 contractors in a factory in South Korea. By October 2018, Allbirds sold a stake to investors at a valuation of $1.4 billion.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/trendy-sneaker-startup-allbirds-laces-up-1-4-billion-valuation-1539281112|title=Trendy Sneaker Startup Allbirds Laces Up $1.4 Billion Valuation|last=Copeland|first=Rob|date=2018-10-11|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-10-12|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.marketwatch.com/story/allbirds-the-trendy-shoe-startup-now-valued-at-14-billion-2018-10-11|title=Allbirds, the trendy shoe startup, now valued at $1.4 billion|last=Copeland|first=Rob|work=MarketWatch|access-date=2018-10-12|language=en-US}} == Products == Allbirds began with one product, the Wool Runner. In 2017, the company released a second shoe, the Lounger.{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/allbirds-wool-loungers-review-2017-5|title=There's a new version of the 'world's most comfortable shoes' that Silicon Valley loves — here's our verdict|work=Business Insider|access-date=2017-10-19|language=en}} The shoes are made from [[Castor oil|castor bean oil]] and superfine [[Merino|merino wool]], with each strand 17.5 microns wide. This material allows the shoe to be machine washable. On 24 October 2017, Allbirds launched a shoe line for children named Smallbirds.{{Cite news|url=https://www.racked.com/2017/9/5/16250626/allbirds-funding-kids-shoes|title=How Does Allbirds Get Bigger? Kids Shoes and More Stores|last=Lieber|first=Chavie|date=5 September 2017|work=[[Racked]]|access-date=5 August 2018}} The limited edition children shoes are $55 a pair and are an exact replica of its adult Wool Runner. Smallbirds are for children ages 2–4 and are available in three colors: natural grey, Kea red and NZ blue.{{Cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/10/24/allbirds-launches-a-kids-shoe-line-called-smallbirds/|title=Allbirds launches a kids shoe line called Smallbirds|last=Buhr|first=Sarah|work=TechCrunch|access-date=2017-11-03|language=en}} In March 2018, Allbirds began offering [[eucalyptus]] tree runners, making it the company's first footwear product made primarily without wool.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-03-15/your-next-sneakers-will-come-from-trees|title=Allbirds Hooked You On Wool Shoes. Next, Shoes Made from Trees|last=Stock|first=Kyle|date=15 March 2018|work=[[Bloomberg News]]|access-date=22 March 2018}} Allbirds also offers a version of its Lounger shoe made from eucalyptus trees, in addition to wool. They also launched the Tree Skipper, a [[boat shoe]] made of the same material.{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/allbirds-co-founders-new-summertime-tree-shoe-collection/|title=Allbirds co-founders on their new plant-based shoe collection|date=15 March 2018|work=[[CBS News]]|access-date=22 March 2018}} In August 2018, Allbirds released [[flip-flops]] made from SweetFoam (a [[foam]] derived from [[sugar cane]], developed by the company in partnership with [[Braskem]]).{{Cite news|url=https://philadelphia.cbslocal.com/2018/08/02/shoe-company-unveils-flip-flops-soles-made-from-sugar/|title=Shoe Company Unveils Flip-Flops Soles Made From Sugar|date=2 August 2018|work=[[KYW-TV]]|access-date=8 August 2018}} === Partnerships === In November 2017, Allbirds and [[Outdoor Voices]] collaborated on a line of [[athleisure]] apparel which included two limited edition colors of the Allbirds wool runners.{{Cite news|url=http://www.instyle.com/fashion/all-birds-outdoor-voices-collaboration|title=This Allbirds x Outdoor Voices Collab is a Match Made in Athleisure Heaven|last=Cleary|first=Alison Syrett|date=16 November 2017|work=[[InStyle]]|access-date=9 June 2018}} In early 2018, five limited edition colors of Allbirds were released, available for purchase at pop-ups inside of five US and two Canadian [[Nordstrom]] locations, in addition to the Nordstrom website.{{Cite news|url=https://people.com/style/allbirds-sneakers-nordstrom/|title=Nordstrom Now Sells Allbirds, the Cute and Comfy Sneakers Hilary Duff and More Celebs Love|last=Phillips|first=Kami|date=12 April 2018|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|access-date=9 June 2018}} In May 2018, [[Shake Shack]] branded pairs of Allbirds tree runners were sold at [[Madison Square Park]] in [[New York City]] for one day.{{Cite news|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/40576132/this-must-be-how-brands-like-allbirds-and-shake-shack-get-their-kicks|title=This must be how brands like Allbirds and Shake Shack get their kicks|last=Locker|first=Melissa|date=22 May 2018|work=[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]]|access-date=9 June 2018}} In September 2018, Allbirds collaborated with [[Air New Zealand]] to create an [[eye mask]] for its business class passengers.{{Cite news|url=https://wwd.com/fashion-news/fashion-scoops/all-birds-eye-mask-air-new-zealand-1202830531/|title=The merino wool mask will be on board select business cabin flights|last=Ap|first=Tiffany|date=20 September 2018|work=[[Women's Wear Daily]]|access-date=21 September 2018}} == Retail == As of August 2018, Allbirds operated retail stores in [[New York City]], [[San Francisco]], and [[Toronto]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.retail-insider.com/retail-insider/2018/5/allbirds-opens-1st-standalone-brick-and-mortar-store-in-canada|title=Allbirds opens 1st Standalone Brick-and-Mortar Store in Canada|last=Patterson|first=Craig|date=28 May 2018|work=Retail Insider|access-date=5 August 2018}} The company is also planning to open stores in [[Boston]], [[Chicago]], [[Los Angeles]] and [[Washington, D.C.]] in 2018.{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/09/04/allbirds-is-opening-massive-store-in-new-york-and-plans-more-across-us.html|title=Allbirds is opening a massive store in New York and plans more across the US|last=Thomas|first=Lauren|date=4 September 2018|work=[[CNBC]]|access-date=4 September 2018}} In October 2018, Allbirds launched in the [[United Kingdom]] with its first London store.{{Cite news|url=https://www.businessoffashion.com/articles/news-bites/allbirds-to-launch-in-the-uk|title=Allbirds to Launch in the UK|last=Chitrakorn|first=Kati|date=20 July 2018|work=[[Business of Fashion]]|access-date=5 August 2018}}{{cite news |last1=Moran |first1=Graeme |title=The Allbirds sustainable footwear revolution comes to London |url=https://www.drapersonline.com/business-operations/the-allbirds-sustainable-footwear-revolution-comes-to-london/7032765.article |accessdate=2 November 2018 |publisher=Draper |date=October 31, 2018}} ==See also== *[[Carbon negative]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} [[Category:Shoe companies of the United States]] [[Category:Companies based in San Francisco]] [[Category:Kickstarter-funded products]] [[Category:Benefit corporations]]

page.title: Americans for a Society Free from Age Restrictions

revision.text:
{{Infobox Organization |name = Americans for a Society Free from Age Restrictions |image = |image_border = |size = |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = ASFAR |motto = Ability, not age |formation = 1997 |extinction = |type = [[Nonprofit corporation]] |status = [[501(c)(3)]] public charity |purpose = [[Youth rights]] |headquarters = Chicago, IL, United States |region_served = |membership = 1,600+ |leader_name = Max Harmony ([[President (corporate title)|President]]) Susan Wishnetsky ([[Secretary]]) |main_organ = [[Board of Directors]] |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = Shoestring |website = [https://www.facebook.com/FreeFromAge Facebook.com/FreeFromAge] |remarks = }} {{Youth rights sidebar}}
'''Americans for a Society Free from Age Restrictions''', also known as '''ASFAR Youth Liberation''', is an organization dedicated to increasing the rights of youth under [[American law]]. The purpose of ASFAR is to "defend and advance the [[Civil rights|civil]] and [[human rights]] of [[adolescents|young people]] through promoting the elimination and reform of laws that limit the [[Freedom (political)|freedom]] and [[self-determination]] of young people in the United States, and [[Youth empowerment|empowering young people to act]] on their own behalf in defense of their rights and freedoms".<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100106011404/http://www.asfar.org/Articles_of_Incorporation ASFAR Articles of Incorporation<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> ASFAR is associated with the [[youth rights movement]], which advocates more freedom for young people and protection of their rights under law, in order to allow them the greatest degree of self-determination possible.
== History and schism == {{Section OR|date=October 2007}} ASFAR, originally an email list organization, was founded in 1996 by Matt Walcoff and Matt Herman, two individuals who felt that age restrictions in the U.S. had gone too far. The small project grew into what could be called a legitimate organization. In 1999, ASFAR was [[Corporation|incorporated]] in Missouri.
Within a year of its founding, ASFAR developed internal conflicts that would ultimately split the organization. Disputes over [[Corporate governance|internal affairs]] and over the Declaration of Principles would lead to the creation of two factions. One group, which included the majority of the membership at that time, called for a detailed and radical [[Political platform|declaration of principles]] and a high degree of membership involvement in the formation of policy. This faction took the name of the group literally and insisted the organization oppose all age restrictions as a matter of principle.
The other faction, led by Herman and Walcoff, called for a more traditional organization, led by a [[board of directors]] and with a smaller, more pragmatic set of policy positions. This latter group would leave to form the more visible and active [[National Youth Rights Association]] (NYRA).<ref name="youthrights.net">[https://web.archive.org/web/20120219160636/http://www.youthrights.net/index.php?title=ASFAR-NYRA_Schism Schism - Youth Rights Network<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
== Present status == ASFAR opposes a wide variety of laws that limit the freedom of young people, such as [[voting age]] limits, [[curfew]] laws, compulsory education, [[child labor laws]], [[age of consent]] laws, [[Legal drinking age|minimum drinking ages]], [[pornography]] age laws, [[child prostitution]] laws and minimum ages for [[Firearms license|firearm possession]]. They support a non-age-based alternative to every age-based law, and believe that the rights of all people to freedom and self-determination outweigh the cost of implementing non-age-based laws.
The animosity that led to the schism with NYRA has largely subsided, and ASFAR enjoys amicable and cordial relations with NYRA. While neither organization has gone on record as supporting formal reunification, neither organization has formally renounced the prospect.<ref name="youthrights.net"/>
ASFAR published an internet [[zine]], ''Youth Truth'', that was nominated for the [[Utne Reader|Utne]] [[Alternative Press (music magazine)|Alternative Press]] Award for "General Excellence -- [[Zine]]" in 2006. ''Youth Truth'' was suspended in 2007 by order of its board of directors. In the January 2010 board meeting, the board of directors appointed Susan Wishnetsky to restart the zine. Meanwhile, ASFAR's opposition to the [[age of consent]] continues to attract members to ASFAR, as NYRA objects to taking a position on the issue.<ref name="ASFAR Work Plan">https://web.archive.org/web/20120310151524/http://www.youthrights.org/docs/NYRAChapterHandbook.pdf NYRA chapter handbook; see note in right-hand column of page 4</ref> ASFAR is currently in the process of forming new positions on the age of consent, students' rights, the drinking age, and the treatment of young people by the media.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110314110939/http://asfar.org/ Former ASFAR web site]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Americans For A Society Free From Age Restrictions}} [[Category:Youth rights organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:Youth-led organizations]] [[Category:Ageism]]
