{{EngvarB|date=February 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2017}} {{Infobox organisation | name = Green Investment Group | image = Green_Investment_Group_Logo.png | size = 250px | abbreviation = | formation = 2012 | type = Limited | headquarters = [[Edinburgh]], [[Scotland]], [[United Kingdom|UK]]<ref>https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/SC574147</ref> | location = | region_served = United Kingdom | key_people = Ed Northam (Head of Green Investment Group) | main_organ = | parent_organisation = Macquarie | budget = | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | website = {{url|greeninvestmentgroup.com/}} }} '''Green Investment Group Limited (GIG)''' is a specialist in [[green infrastructure]] principal investment, project delivery and the management of portfolio assets, and related services.
The business was launched initially by the [[UK government]] in 2012 as the first institution of its type in the world. The organisation was acquired by the diversified financial group [[Macquarie Group|Macquarie Group Limited]] in 2017, creating one of Europe’s largest teams of dedicated green infrastructure investors, and now operates under the name Green Investment Group. It is structured as a [[public limited company]] and is owned by the [[Macquarie Group Limited |Macquarie Group]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.macquarie.com/au/about/newsroom/2017/macquarie-led-consortium-to-acquire-the-green-investment-bank|title=Macquarie Group leads consortium to acquire the Green Investment Bank|website=www.macquarie.com|language=en|access-date=23 February 2017}}</ref> It has offices in [[London]] and [[Edinburgh]].<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSL5E8E86QQ20120308 "UK to base Green Investment Bank in Edinburgh, London"] Reuters, 8 March 2012</ref>
==History== ===Origins=== As a result of the [[Climate Change Act 2008]], the United Kingdom became legally committed to significantly reducing its [[carbon emissions]] by 2050. More importantly, the Act committed the UK to generating a significantly higher percentage of its energy from [[renewable energy|renewable sources]] by 2020.<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/government-figures-show-britain-will-fail-to-meet-its-kyoto-obligations-466910.html "Government figures show Britain will fail to meet its Kyoto obligations"] ''The Independent'', 18 February 2006</ref>
A non-partisan, [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] committee on [[climate change]] was established to study and recommend ways of meeting the country's obligations. The committee reported that for a new, low-carbon business and government infrastructure to be established, the necessary investment would range between £200 billion and £1 trillion over the next two decades.<ref name=comm>[https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201011/cmselect/cmenvaud/505/505.pdf Green Investment Bank], Environmental Audit Committee, House of Commons, UK, 2011</ref>
The committee further stated that since traditional sources of capital for investment in green infrastructure could not provide even half that amount by 2025, there would be a funding gap that needed to be covered by the state budget.<ref name=comm />
In 2009, two reports were published advocating the creation of a state-backed infrastructure bank to provide financing to green projects. The first, entitled "Accelerating Green Infrastructure Financing: Outline proposals for UK green bonds and infrastructure bank" was published in March 2009 by [[Climate Change Capital]] and [[E3G]].<ref>[http://www.climatechangecapital.com/media/2153/Accelerating%20Green%20Infrastructure%20Financing%20Final%2021-05-09.pdf "Accelerating Green Infrastructure Financing: Outline proposals for UK green bonds and infrastructure bank"], Climate Change Capital, UK, 2009</ref> The second, entitled "Delivering a 21st Century Infrastructure for Britain" was published by [[Policy Exchange]] in September 2009 and was written by [[Dieter Helm]], James Wardlaw and [[Ben Caldecott]].<ref>[http://www.policyexchange.org.uk/publications/category/item/delivering-a-21st-century-infrastructure-for-britain "Delivering a 21st Century Infrastructure for Britain"], Policy Exchange, UK, 2009</ref> These proposals were then contained in the manifestos of each of the main political parties for the 2010 UK General Election.
The [[Fiscal year]] 2010 [[March 2010 United Kingdom budget|British government budget]] contained the first mention of a "green investment bank" scheme, earmarked with £2 billion. Chancellor [[Alistair Darling]] stated that the [[Labour party (UK)|Labour]] government was committed "to support offshore wind energy" and other forms of alternative energy, which he also billed as "crucial to guiding the country out of [[recession]]".<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/mar/24/budget-green-investment-bank "Budget 2010: Chancellor announces green investment bank"] ''The Guardian'', 24 March 2010</ref>
After the [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|2010 general election]], the newly formed [[Cameron–Clegg coalition|Conservative-Liberal Democrat coalition]] government defined its primary economic objective to be the drastic reduction of Britain's debt and yearly deficits.<ref>[http://www.euronews.net/2010/05/13/british-coalition-stresses-need-for-cuts/ "British coalition stresses need for cuts"] EuroNews, 13 May 2010</ref> Accordingly, the government sought to create a financing scheme for the environmental investment needs of the country that would be funded mainly by the private sector, including the banks.
In June 2010 the Green Investment Bank Commission, established by George Osborne in opposition, after holding hearings recommended that the government created an eponymous banking entity within the year.<ref name=comm /> Chancellor [[George Osborne]] remained sceptical after objections to the creation of such a bank were raised by the Treasury, since a Green Investment Bank would "swell the state deficit" as it would appear as a liability on the government's balance sheet.<ref name=guard>[https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2011/mar/11/greeen-investment-bank?CMP=twt_fd "Green investment bank 'must operate commercially'"] ''The Guardian'', 11 March 2011</ref>
The UK government's [[Spending Review]] of October 2010 that announced a raft of austerity measures to deal with the UK government deficit, also included an announcement about the creation of a Green Investment Bank. The government expected to obtain by early 2013 the European Commission's approval for state aid to the Bank, with investment in green projects estimated to begin by April 2012.<ref>[http://www.bis.gov.uk/news/speeches/vince-cable-resource-security-2011 "Resource security"], Speech by Vince Cable, BIS Secretary, 12 December 2011</ref>
===Criticism=== The plans for the environmental funding scheme were endorsed by [[Greenpeace]], whose executive director urged the prime minister to "get personally involved", as well as by a number of similar organisations,<ref>[http://www.transformuk.org/en/articles/9/letter-to-editor-of-guardian/ Letter to the editor] of ''The Guardian'', 1 March 2009</ref> such as [[Transform UK]], whose director stated that "the only cost the Treasury should consider is the cost of failure to unleash this institution's massive potential to re-power our economy."<ref name=guard /> Environmentalists engaged in public demonstrations demanding a quicker implementation of the plans.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2010/oct/19/greenpeace-treasury-green-investment-bank "Greenpeace activists scale Treasury building in green bank protest"]''The Guardian'', 19 October 2010</ref>
However, non-government organisations and environmentalists criticised the scheme because it lacked ambition. The [[World Development Movement]] disputed that such a small scheme will attract the kind of investment needed to "generate green jobs, green industry and a green economy in the UK".<ref>[http://www.wdm.org.uk/press-release/spending-review-reaction-lessons-should-be-learnt-developing-world Press release] WDM, 20 October 2010</ref> An economic study commissioned by WDM and Platform recommended that, instead of creating a new "banking scheme", the government should "transform the [already] {{Sic|hide=y|publicly|-}}owned [[Royal Bank of Scotland]] into a powerful green investment bank", in the process also "creating 50,000 green jobs".<ref>[http://www.wdm.org.uk/sites/default/files/A%20Bank%20for%20the%20Future.pdf "Bank for the future"] by [[James Leaton]], with additional research by Howard Reed, 2010</ref>
In May 2011, a former adviser to the government, [[Jonathon Porritt]], who had been head of the [[Sustainable Development Commission]], publicly criticised the Coalition's scrapping of a planned rise in aviation tax, its watering down of schemes that promote small-scale renewable electricity and its failure to promote a "green investment bank" with immediate borrowing powers. Mr Porritt claimed he examined 75 policies on which the government had committed itself, finding little or no progress in 55. The government responded that it remains "committed to the environment", but claimed that the economic recession had affected environmental policies.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-13312901 "PM's pledge of greenest government 'vanishingly remote'"] BBC News, 7 May 2011</ref>
The leader of the [[Green Party of England and Wales]] (and [[Member of Parliament|MP]] for [[Brighton Pavilion (UK Parliament constituency)|Brighton Pavilion]]) [[Caroline Lucas]], criticised the nomenclature of the GIB in January 2011, when she wrote that "It's a bit rich to call [the GIB] a green investment bank if it can neither borrow nor lend". Lucas argued that without these powers, "it would be a fund – that is, a pot of money that, once used up, is gone forever.".<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/environment/blog/2011/jan/27/green-investment-bank "The green investment bank: neither particularly green, nor a bank"] The Guardian, 27 January 2011</ref>
Criticism also centred on the location of the institution. Bloomberg claimed that "Most of the 50- 70 jobs will initially be in London..."<ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-03-08/u-k-green-bank-will-have-base-in-edinburgh-jobs-in-london.html "Green Bank Will Have Base in Edinburgh, Jobs in London"] Bloomberg, 8 March 2012</ref> and some questioned that the decision to locate many jobs in London, despite the announcement headline of Edinburgh being chosen as winner of the location contest, pointed to a "bid to defuse Scottish independence... a blatant move to unite the capitals over Alex Salmond's key policy."<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/banksandfinance/9131757/Green-Investment-Bank-bid-to-defuse-Scottish-independence.html "Green Investment Bank bid to defuse Scottish independence"] The Telegraph, 8 March 2012</ref>
===Creation=== On 23 May 2011, Deputy Prime Minister [[Nick Clegg]] at a speech at Climate Change Capital stated that the Green Investment Bank "will begin operating in April 2012", adding that the bank's early targets would be "offshore wind, waste and non-domestic energy efficiency".<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-13502121 "Clegg: UK green bank 'to begin investing in April 2012'"] BBC News, 23 May 2011</ref> Clegg added that legislation would "ensure the independence of the institution."
On 24 May 2011, [[Business Secretary]] [[Vince Cable]], in addressing the parliament, stated that the bank will become "a key component" of the transition to a "low-carbon economy", which will need "significant investment over the coming decades." Cable also stated that the GIB will have an initial capitalisation of £3 billion, which "the Government believes will leverage a further £15 billion of private investment".<ref name=eneff>[http://www.energyefficiencynews.com/i/4124/ "UK Business Secretary sets out future of Green Investment Bank as ‘enduring institution’"] ''Energy Efficiency News'', 25 May 2011</ref>
The same day, BIS, in a press release<ref>[http://www.bis.gov.uk/policies/business-sectors/low-carbon-business-opportunities/gib/detail Press release] BIS, 25 May 2011</ref> containing answers to "frequently asked questions" about the bank, outlined the planned finances of the GIB and its activation in "three phases": *'''Incubation''' (April 2012 until state aid approval): Government makes direct financial investments in the "green economy". *'''Establishment''' (following state aid approval): UK Green Investment Bank established as a "stand-alone institution". *'''Full borrowing powers''' (ca. 2015–16): Bank given powers to borrow, "subject to public sector's net-debt falling as a percentage of GDP".
Dr Cable unveiled on the same day his department's [[Strategic planning|statement of vision]] for the bank.<ref>[http://www.bis.gov.uk/assets/biscore/business-sectors/docs/u/11-917-update-design-green-investment-bank.pdf "Update on the design of the Green Investment Bank"] BIS, May 2011</ref> The document was cautiously<ref>"While different investor groups can be comfortable with different elements of risk profiles, the number of investors willing to take the set of required risks may be limited by lack of information and experience and the application of risk-averse rules of thumb." ''[http://www.bis.gov.uk/assets/biscore/business-sectors/docs/u/11-917-update-design-green-investment-bank.pdf Update]'', p.14</ref> positive about the prospects of private investment in the environment, in the UK.
BIS appeared to indicate on 12 December 2011 that the 'Incubation' phase had progressed, with the announcement of a new team within the department: ''UK Green Investments'' (UKGI). It stated the team's role was to "drive investment in the UK’s green infrastructure until the Green Investment Bank is formally established".<ref>[http://nds.coi.gov.uk/content/detail.aspx?NewsAreaId=2&ReleaseID=422445 GIB moves a step closer] Department for Business, Innovation and Skills, December 2011</ref> Initially the UKGI team consisted of six members: five men and one woman.<ref>[http://www.bis.gov.uk/policies/business-sectors/low-carbon-business-opportunities/uk-green-investments/team The UKGI Team] Department for Business, Innovation and Skills, January 2012</ref>
State aid approval for the bank was granted by the [[EU Commission]] on 17 October 2012, allowing the bank to become fully established.<ref>[http://news.bis.gov.uk/Press-Releases/UK-Green-Investment-Bank-gets-green-light-from-Europe-681c7.aspx "UK Green Investment Bank gets green light from Europe"] Department for Business, Innovation and Skills</ref> The bank was subsequently formally launched in Edinburgh by Vince Cable on 28 November 2012.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-scotland-business-20522615 "Cable launches UK's 'Green Bank'"] BBC News</ref>
==Management== On 25 May 2011, Vince Cable informed the House of Commons that BIS would appoint [[Adrian Montague|Sir Adrian Montague]], [[CBE]], chairman of private equity firm [[3i]], to lead a team of "independent financial experts" in setting up the UK Green Investment Bank before it started work the following year.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/banksandfinance/8534109/Nuclear-boss-Sir-Adrian-Montague-to-head-Green-bank.html "Nuclear boss Sir Adrian Montague to head Green bank"], ''Telegraph'', 25 May 2011</ref> Cable stated that the bank would be initially staffed by up to 100 people tasked with "financing the Coalition's plans for a low-carbon economy".
On 25 May 2012, [[Baron Smith of Kelvin|Lord Smith of Kelvin]] was announced as the first Chair of the bank by Vince Cable.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-scotland-business-18207982|title=Lord Smith to chair Green Investment Bank|author=|date=25 May 2012|work=BBC News|accessdate=14 April 2016}}</ref> Shaun Kingsbury was the bank's chief executive from October 2012 to 2017.
==Part–privatisation== In June 2015 the Business Secretary [[Sajid Javid]] put forward proposals to part-[[Privatization|privatise]] the bank, with the stated aim of giving it full access to the [[capital market]]s.<ref name=POGIB>{{cite news |last= |first= |date=19 December 2015 |title=Privatisation of Green Investment Bank could 'damage its reputation' |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-35138659 |newspaper=BBC News |location=UK |access-date=19 December 2015 }}</ref>
==Final privatisation== On 18 August 2017, the bank was sold to [[Macquarie Group|Macquarie Group Limited]] for £2.3 billion.<ref>{{cite web|title=UK government’s sale of Green Investment Bank completed|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/uk-governments-sale-of-green-investment-bank-completed|publisher=GOV.UK|accessdate=26 November 2017|date=18 August 2017}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Trust fund]] * [[Cap and trade]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/uk-green-investment-bank GOV.UK details] *{{official website|http://www.greeninvestmentbank.com/}} *[http://www.bis.gov.uk/ Department for Business, Innovation and Skills official website] *[http://www.parliament.uk/business/committees/committees-a-z/commons-select/environmental-audit-committee/news/oral-evidence-session---green-investment-bank/ Environmental Audit Committee inquiry into Green Investment Bank] from the British Parliament website, 27 October 2010

revision.text:
{{Infobox ethnic group |group = Holoholo people |population = |region1 = [[Tanganyika Province]], [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]];
[[Lake Tanganyika]], [[Tanzania]] |pop1 = 15,500 |ref1 = |region2 = Tanzania |pop2 = |ref2 = |region3 = |pop3 = |ref3 = |region4 = |pop4 = |ref4 = |region5 = |pop5 = |ref5 = |region6 = |pop6 = |ref6 = |region7 = |pop7 = |ref7 = |region8 = |pop8 = |ref8 = |region9 = |pop9 = |ref9 = |region10 = |pop10 = |ref10 = |languages = [[Holoholo language]] |religions = |related = |footnotes = }} The '''Holoholo people''' (also ''Horohoro'' or ''Kalanga'') are an ethnic group that live around [[Kalemie]] city on [[Lake Tanganyika]] in the present-day [[Tanganyika Province]] of the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]], and on the opposite shore of the lake in [[Tanzania]]. ==Language== As of 2002 there were about 15,500 speakers of the [[Holoholo language]].{{sfn|Holoholo A language...}} The name "Holoholo" was given to them by the Belgians. It comes from the sound of their greeting, which outsiders found comical. The alternative name "Kalanga" simply means people who were there before the current population.{{sfn|Roberts|1991|p=193}} ==History== [[File:Statuette Holoholo-Musée ethnologique de Berlin.jpg|thumb|Holoholo statuette of a woman from the 19th century or early 20th century]] The Holoholo are a matrilineal people.{{sfn|Reefe|1981|p=124}} They are descendants of [[Baguha people]] who fled from the [[Luba Empire]] when it was expanding eastward in the 18th century, settling around [[Kalemie]] where the [[Lukuga River]] leaves the lake.{{sfn|Holoholo Information}} During the period of Luba dominance that followed the eastward expansion under Luba king [[Ilunga Sungu]] around 1800, ''bambudye'' secret societies were introduced among the Holoholo and other peoples, propagating oral traditions of the Luba royal family. The Holoholo adopted and adapted the Luba genesis myth, in which they believed there was a mountain called Ilunga Sungu on the west side of the Lualaba towards the Luba heartland, This refers to the location of the court of Ilunga Sungu at [[Katende]].{{sfn|Reefe|1981|p=127}} The 1935 book ''Les peuplades du Congo belge'' shows the Holoholo living on both sides of the Lukuga.{{sfn|Roberts|1991|p=208}} They became middlemen in the Arab and African slave trade. With suppression of this trade the economy collapsed and disease and local warfare decimated the population. Today the economy is mostly agricultural based on sorghum, maize, peanuts, and beans. Fish are caught with nets, dried and sold locally, the main source of cash in the area. Sorghum is used to make beer.{{sfn|Holoholo Information}} The Holoholo who live in Tanzania around Kungwe Mountain have a tradition that their ancestors came from the Congo side by means of a long island that continued Kungwe Mountain into the lake. The lake level is highly variable, so it is conceivable that they crossed at a time when it was much lower than today, when part of the ridge separating the northern and southern basins of the lake would have been exposed.{{sfn|Clark|1969|pp=35-36}} Thousands of Holo-holo had settled along the Tanganyikan side of the lake by 1915, having sailed over in canoes. A census in 1948 counted 4,410 Holo-holo in Tanganyika.{{sfn|Foden|2006|p=235}} In 1987 the Holoholo people had an estimated population of 12,500 in Tanzania. They traditionally lived in the [[Mahale Mountains]] on the east shore of the lake opposite Kalemie. However they were expelled from this area after 1979 to make way for the [[Mahale Mountains National Park]] created in 1985.{{sfn|Finke|2002|p=537}} ==References== {{reflist |colwidth=25em}} ==Sources== {{refbegin|25em}} *{{cite book |ref=harv |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_r08AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA35 |title=Kalambo Falls prehistoric site, Volume 1 |first=John Desmond |last=Clark |publisher=CUP Archive |year=1969}} *{{cite book |ref=harv |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=16--sm53nX4C&pg=PA537 |title=Rough guide to Tanzania |first=Jens |last=Finke |publisher=Rough Guides |year=2002 |ISBN=1-85828-783-9}} *{{cite book |ref=harv |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1WsycOWeI-YC&pg=PA235 |title=Mimi and Toutou's Big Adventure: The Bizarre Battle of Lake Tanganyika |first=Giles |last=Foden |publisher=Random House Digital, Inc. |year=2006 |ISBN=1-4000-7526-2}} *{{cite web |ref={{harvid|Holoholo Information}} |url=http://www.uiowa.edu/~africart/toc/people/Holoholo.html |title=Holoholo Information |date=3 November 1998 |publisher=University of Iowa |accessdate=2011-12-11}} *{{cite web |ref={{harvid|Holoholo A language...}} |url=http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=hoo |title=Holoholo A language of Democratic Republic of the Congo |work=Ethnologue |accessdate=2011-12-12}} *{{cite book |ref=harv |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=X4VmAWdXPD0C&pg=PA193 |title=The Creation of Tribalism in Southern Africa |publisher=University of California Press |year=1991 |ISBN=0-520-07420-3 |last=Roberts |first=Allen F.|chapter=History, Ethnicity, and Change in the Christian Kingdom of Southeastern Zaire,|editor=Leroy Vail}} *{{cite book |ref=harv |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Yz8cv9-JlN0C&pg=PA127 |title=The rainbow and the kings: a history of the Luba Empire to 1891 |first=Thomas Q. |last=Reefe |publisher=University of California Press |year=1981 |ISBN=0-520-04140-2}} {{refend}} {{Ethnic groups in the Democratic Republic of the Congo}} [[Category:Holoholo| ]] [[Category:Bantu peoples]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Tanzania]] [[Category:Lake Tanganyika]] [[Category:Kalemie]] [[Category:Tanganyika Province]]

revision.text:
{{nofootnotes|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox Motorcycle club | name = Holy Riders MC | image = Holy_Riders_MC_logo.gif | image_size = 100px | motto = | founded = 1981 | founding_location = | founded_by = | leader_name = <!-- name of leader --> | leader_title = <!-- position title for the leader of the club --> | key_people = | type = <!-- Outlaw motorcycle club, AMA chartered, corporate sponsored, charity etc --> | region = Norway, Australia, Germany | marque = | purpose = Christian motorcycle club | membership_est = 500 | activities = <!-- notable events, activities etc --> | website = www.holyriders.no | abbrev = }}
'''Holy Riders''' (HR) is a Norwegian Christian [[motorcycle club]] founded in 1981. It has pr. 2008 approximately 500 members in 17 branches in Norway and is thus one of the largest motorcycle clubs in Norway. The club also has branches in Germany and Sweden. The club's goal is to spread the gospel of salvation through Jesus Christ's death and resurrection to everyone in the motorcycle community. The club is alcohol free and is open to all regardless of age, gender, or religious affiliation. The type Motorcycles members drive everything from American veteran motorcycles through Harley Davidson to Japanese bikes.
==Branches== The club is organized in 17 local branches in Norway, in addition to 2 branches in Sweden and 1 branch in Germany. They serve as individual departments, but is formally under central board. The different departments have their own programs throughout the year, but they all gather for HR's Gatherings, Pilgrimstreffet and Christmas party and annual meeting.
==Power== Power is the Holy Riders magazine and is published with 2 magazines per year. A number is approx. 20 pages.
==Coffee Tent== Holy Riders coffee tent has become a gathering place for many on the MC events in Norway; it distributes both coffee and bibles. . Some of the events they have been permanent on in recent years is, Norgestreffet and TrollRally. on Norgestreffet has Holy Riders also had MC worship meetings on some occasions.{{citation needed |date=November 2011}}
==Holy Riders MC Racing== Holy Riders MC Racing is a racing club that aims to be active participants in the racing environment. They want to be a club that participates and contributes to a positive environment within the different branches. They also wants all within motorsport community to have the opportunity to become acquainted with Jesus.
==See also== *[[List of motorcycle clubs]] *[[Motorcycling]]
==References== {{reflist}} *(February 27, 1994.) [https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=SJpdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=xVwNAAAAIBAJ&pg=6662,8734128&dq=holy-riders&hl=en "Norwegians are Bikers for Jesus."] ''The Telegraph'' *(May 10, 2002.) [https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=W_8wAAAAIBAJ&sjid=EN0FAAAAIBAJ&pg=2233,990017&dq=holy-riders&hl=en "Biker Ministry Reaches Out to Others."] ''Gadsden Times''. *(July 27, 2006.) [http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/ostafjells/buskerud/1.778551 "Today, collected more than 500 motorcycle enthusiasts at Dagali to 25-year anniversary of the Holy Riders."] [http://www.nrk.no Nrk.no] Broadcasting corporation. *(September 7, 2008.) [http://bruntalsky.denik.cz/zpravy_region/motorkari-bavili-krnovskou-mladez-20080907.html "Bikers entertained Krnov youth."] Vltava-Labe-Press, Inc. *{{de icon}} (April 15, 2010.) [http://www.pro-medienmagazin.de/journalismus.html?&news%5Baction%5D=detail&news%5Bid%5D=2888 "Motorisierte Mission"] [http://www.pro-medienmagazin.de/startseite.html Pro-medienmagazin.de].
==External links== *[http://www.holyriders.no/ Official Norwegian site] *[http://www.holyriders.se/ Official Swedish site] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110920092455/http://www.holyriders.de/ Official German site] *[http://www.holyriders.org.ua/ Official Ukrainian site] *[http://holyriders.ru/ Official Russian site] [[Category:Motorcycle clubs]] [[Category:Clubs and societies in Norway]]

The '''Institute for Global Communications''' or '''IGC Internet''' was founded in 1987 and is an institution that provides web hosting service to environmental, peace, and social justice organizations. IGC is a project of the [[Tides Center]]. During the very early days of the Internet, IGC was responsible for training thousands of small progressive groups as to how to use email, mailing lists, discussion groups, gopher sites, and later web sites and other web services to further their mission.
IGC formed an international link when started working with [[GreenNet]] in the [[United Kingdom]].
In 1990, in partnership with six international organizations, IGC co-founded the [[Association for Progressive Communications]] (APC).
At its peak in 1998, IGC had over 35 full-time staff members with offices in San Francisco, California, USA.
Since then ConflictNet went out of existence and LaborNet left the IGC Networks. IGC still offers web hosting services to groups, individuals, and small companies.
==External links== *{{official website|http://www.igc.org/}} *[http://www.apc.org/ Association for Progressive Communications] *[http://www.gn.apc.org/ GreenNet Collective] *[http://archives.dailynews.lk/2009/07/28/fea03.asp IGC Target of DOS attack] [[Category:Activism]] [[Category:American political websites]]

{{Hatnote|For the geographically related exonym see [[Ćići]]}} {{more footnotes|date=February 2012}} {{Infobox ethnic group |group = Istro-Romanians
Vlaşi or Rumâri |image = The Carnival of the Istro-Romanians from Jeian, 2006.jpg |caption = Carnivals [[Zvončari]] from Žejane, 2006 |population = 76{{Croatian Census 2011|E}} |regions = [[Istria]] and [[Italy]]; others live in the United States, Canada, Argentina, Bolivia, Chile, Peru, Venezuela, Australia, Sweden, Germany, and other countries. |languages = [[Istro-Romanian language|Istro-Romanian]];
also [[Croatian language|Croatian]], [[Italian language|Italian]] |religions = [[Roman Catholic]] |related = [[Romanians|Daco-Romanians]], [[Megleno-Romanians]], [[Aromanians]], [[Vlachs of Croatia|Vlachs]], [[Morlachs]] |footnotes = }} '''Istro-Romanians / Istrorumeni''' ([[ethnonym]]: ''Rumeni'' and occasionally also ''Rumâri'' and ''Rumêri''), also called ''Ćiribirci'', ''[[Ćići]]'', and ''[[Vlachs of Croatia|Vlahi]]'' by the local population, and '''''Istro-Romanians''''' by linguists, are a small [[ethnic group]] living in small area of northeastern [[Istria]], in the village [[Žejane]] in eastern plateau of mountain [[Ćićarija]], and several villages in a region of former [[Lake Čepić]] west of Mt. [[Učka]]. The 2001 Croatian census lists only 48 [[Romanian language]] speakers in [[Istria County]].[http://www.dzs.hr/hrv/censuses/Census2001/Popis/H01_03_10/H01_03_10.html Croatian 2001 census, detailed classification by nationality] In the 2011 Croatian census, Istria listed 49 [[Romanians]] and 6 [[Vlachs of Croatia|Vlachs]]. The inhabitants of villages and hamlets speak the [[Čakavian dialect]] which it is believed originated in [[Dalmatia]]. However, there is no known record to show that the Istro-Romanians came from Dalmatia. That there are traces of Istro-Romanian words in the [[Cakavian]] Istrian vocabulary and vice versa indicate only that over the centuries the two neighboring linguistically different groups assimilated through daily social contact and intermarriages, as happens with other peoples and their languages throughout the world. ==History== The first historical record of Romanians in the Istrian region purportedly dates back to 940 A.D. when scholarly Roman Emperor [[Constantine VII]] recorded in ''De Administrando Imperio''" that there were Latin-language speakers in this area who called themselves Romans but who did not come from Rome. A later historical record of Romanians in Istria (not necessarily the "[[Ćići]]", and possibly the "[[Morlachs|Morlacchi]]" i.e. [[Vlachs]]) dates back to 1329, when Serbian chronicles mention that a Vlach population was living in the area, although there was an earlier mention from the 12th century of a leader in Istria called ''Radul'' which may have been a Romanian name. In his monumental book, ''Historia antica, e moderna sacra, e profana, della città di Trieste'', published in his native town of Trieste in 1698, Fra Ireneo della Croce (1625–1713) wrote: {{quotation|"Un'altra memoria antica, degna d'osservatione non minore della già addotte Antichità Romane, osservo in alcuni Popoli addimandati comunemente Chichi habitanti nelle Opčine Trebče, e Gropada situate nel Territorio di Trieste, sopra il Monte cinque miglia distante dalla Città verso Greco: Et in molti altri Villaggi, aspettanti à Castel nuovo, nel Carso Giurisditione de gl'Illustrissimi Signori Conti Petazzi, quali, oltre l'Idioma I Sclavo comune à tutto il Carso, usano un proprio, e particolare consimile al Valacco, intracciato con diverse parole, e vocaboli Latini, come scorgesi dall'ingiunti, & à bel Studio qui da me riferiti. Non deve meravigliarsi chi legge, fe questi Popoli, quali proffessano l'origine loro da Carni, e suoi discendenti, venuti dalla Toscana à fondare la Nostra antica Provincia de' Carni, habbiano sempre conservato l'uso antico della lingua Romana, ò Latina, idioma comune de' loro Antenati, come constumano hoggidì pure al sentire [335] di Gio:Lucio (a) i Popoli nella Valacchia: Valachi autem hedierni quicunque lingua Valacha loquuntur, se ipsos non dicunt Vlahos, aut Valachos, sed Romanos, & à Romanis ortos gloriuntur; Romanaque lingua loqui prositentur, quiod sicut sermo ipsorum comprobat: ita mores quoque crum Italis quam Slavis similiores conveniunt, Che perciò anco i nostri Chichi, addimandansi nel proprio linguaggio Rumeri: Essendo sentimento del mentovato Lucio, (b) che l'uso della lingua latina, fiorì anticamente non solo nell'Italia, ma anco nella Dalmatia, nell'Illirico, & altre parti: Lingua romana, sive Latina Dalmatas usos ad ann. 1200. VVilliemus Tyrius testatur. lib. 2. cap. 17."}} He mentions a people who, "beside the Slavic idiom common for all the Karst area, speak also their own and particular language, which is similar to Wallachian and contains many different Latin words." He was referring to the language of the "Ćići", ''who call themselves in their language as Rumeri'', in his own time, were known to inhabit an extensive part of Istria up to Trieste and surrounding regions. Some linguists believe that the Istro-Romanians migrated to their present location about 600 years ago from [[Transylvania]], after the [[Black Death]] depopulated [[Istria]], as was told to generations of Istro-Romanians who handed down this story from parent to child by word of mouth. Some loan words also suggest that before reaching Istria, the Istro-Romanians lived for a period of time in [[Dalmatia]] near the Cetina river, but this is mere speculation as the loan words could easily have come from other Slavic peoples who likewise emigrated to Istria. Such loan words also exist in Daco-Romanian, the official language of Romania. Moreover, in modern Serbia, there are some Daco-Romanian speakers ''(see [[Romanians of Serbia]])'', but the majority of the large population of Romanians there speak Aromunian (a.k.a. Macedo-Romanian), both being distinctly different languages from Istro-Romanian. [[Image:Istrorumeni linguistic-map1 (2).png|thumb|Two main areas, village Šušnjevica and Žejane (encircled), inhabited by Istro-Romanians.]] More importantly, the Transylvanian connection that is emphasized by linguists is alive in the memory of some of the Istrorumeni themselves who today distinguish themselves into two distinct groups - the ''Ćići'' surrounding the Mune and Žejane area in Ćićarija, and the ''Vlahi'' of the southern Šušnjevica region, this despite the fact that their language is identical except for a few local distinctions. Iosif Popovici entitled his book ''Dialectele române din Istria'' (Halle, 1909) - that is, "''The Dialects...''" not "''The Dialect...''" - indirectly suggesting there were several types of Istro-Romanian dialects in Istria. Romanian linguists are divided in their opinions: Prof. Dr. Iosif Popovici (1876–1928), who had travelled extensively in Istria, endorsed the theory that the Istro-Romanians were natives of [[Ţara Moţilor]] (Western Transylvania) who had migrated into [[Istria]] sometimes during the [[Middle Ages]]. ("Dialectele române din Istria", I, Halle a.d.S., 1914, p. 122 and following). This opinion was shared by [[Ovid Densusianu]] (1873–1938) (a Romanian folklorist, philologist, and poet who introduced trends of European modernism into Romanian literature - thus not a linguistics authority - who stated that Istro-Romanians were not native to Istria (''Histoire de la langue roumaine'', I, p. 337): "''Un premier fait que nous devons mettre en evidence, c'est que l'istro-roumain n'a pu se développer à l'origine là où nous le trouvons aujourd'hui''". The Serbian dialectologist and phonologist [[Pavle Ivić]] (1924–99), respected for his work toward the standardization of the Serbian language, speculated that at the beginning of the Middle Ages a sizable Roman population inhabited all of the [[Balkans]], but his interests focused on the areas contained within the former Yugoslavia, whereas history shows that the Latin language influence reached considerably beyond that region. Besides, the Roman population to which he referred may not relate solely to the Istro-Romanians who migrated to Istria, but also the Istriot (Istro-Romance) speakers of Istria, as well as the Vegliot language (now extinguished) that was spoken in the nearby island of Krk (Veglia). Both of these languages evolved separately from Istro-Romanian. Regarding the Vegliot speakers, in the 15th century, a purportedly similar population of ''Rumeri'' from the near mainland, as noted by Frankopan (Frangipani) princes in their chronicles, settled in northernmost [[Krk]] (Veglia) island, villages Poljica and Dubašnica at actual Malinska. In the mid-19th century they were gradually assimilated, and only some of their toponyms and plant names persist; also their Paternoster, ''Cace nostru'', was noted there. [[Image:Fata din Șușnievița.jpg|thumb|Woman from Šušnjevica, in 1906.]] When Istria was part of the [[Austrian Empire]], the Istro-Rumanians were the majority of a small "comune" (Eng. community, county) near the [[Raša (river)|Arsa]] River and mainly within the Arsa valley, as shown in the 1910 Austrian census.[http://digilander.libero.it/arup/etno1910gr.jpg Ethnic map of Istria in 1910 (Istrorumanian area indicated in a small "pointed" area)] In 1922, after the union of Istria to Italy, the Italian government designated the existing town of Susnieviza (changing its name to [[:it:Valdarsa|Valdarsa]]; today called [[Šušnjevica]]) for the Istro-Romanian community, and appointed [[:it:Andrea Glavina|Andrea Glavina]], an Istro-Romanian professor who had studied in Romania, as their leader. They obtained a school in the [[Istro-Romanian language]] in the town of Valdarsa and reached a population of 3,000 in 1942. The population of modern [[Šušnjevica]] is now reduced to around 200 inhabitants. After World War II, most Istro-Romanians left their ancestral homes, as did the majority of inhabitants throughout the Istrian peninsula due to discrimination, violence and threats by the incoming Communist regime. A small number remained in Istria while others,the Giuliani-Dalmati Italians from the centuries old Venetian Republic rule, along with their Croat neighbors, emigrated to various countries of Europe, most notably Italy, the U.S.A., Canada, Argentina, Bolivia, Chile, Peru, Venezuela, Australia and other countries throughout the world (Istro-Romanians became adjusted to Italy, Argentina, Bolivia, Chile, Peru and Venezuela because of their [[Romance-speaking Europe|Latin identity]]). Those who stayed under Yugoslav rule underwent [[forced assimilation]] as much as, if not more than, they had under the prior brief Italian rule of Fascist Italy.{{Citation needed|date=March 2010}} The Italian writer and historian [[Giuseppe Lazzarini]] believes that there are more than 5,000 Istro-Romanian descendants in [[Istria]], even though the 1991 Census lists only 811 Istro-Romanians. As happened with past and recent changeovers in regimes which have disfavored this minority, most of them identify themselves with other ethnic groups instead of as Istro-Romanian. Lazzarini believes that the Istro-Romanians are the descendants of the Roman legionnaires (brought in by [[Augustus]] to eastern [[Istria]] to colonize the borders of [[Roman Empire]]) and Aromanian shepherds, who escaped the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] invasions and moved to a plague depopulated [[Istria]] in the 15th century. Other historians and linguists, however, disagree with this theory inasmuch as the Aromanian and Istro-Romanian languages are very different and entirely distinguishable from each other. Also significant is that unlike most other Romanian speakers, who are [[Eastern Orthodox]], the Istro-Romanians were in the past and are today [[Roman Catholic]], another characteristic of these people which suggests a different migratory pattern and historical evolution, like their Croat neighbors. In 1998, August Kovačec, a Croatian linguist, (see references below) published a detailed monograph on Istro-Romanians, their population, culture, glossary, grammar which was reflective only of the acknowledged speakers in Istria during the years in which the language was politically discouraged, not of the majority of native speakers who left Istria after World War II. This monomgram and his other texts, while exhaustive, are not the primary or authoritative source. Before and since his writings, Romanian, Italian and even Dalmatian linguists have published their own atlases, dictionaries and vocabularies on this nearly extinguished, but obsolete, language. ==Existent (remaining) settlements== [[Image:O parte din Șușnievița.jpg|thumb|Old view of Suseni (Šušnjevica) in 1906.]] *Area in eastern part of Mount [[Ćićarija]] **[[Žejane]] ([[Istro-Romanian language|Istro-Romanian]]: ''Jeiăn''), 140 inhabitants *Area west of Mount [[Učka]] (historical name: ''Monte Maggiore'') and near former [[Lake Čepić]] / Arsa **[[Šušnjevica]] (''Şuşńieviţe, Susńieviţa'', Istro-Romanian: ''Suseni'') **[[Nova Vas, Kršan|Nova Vas]] (''Noselo'', Istro-Romanian: ''Sat Nou'' meaning "New Village") **[[Jesenovik]] (Istro-Romanian: ''Sucodru'', meaning "under woods") **[[Kostrčani]] (Istro-Romanian: ''Costârceân'') **Letaj (Istro-Romanian: ''Letai'') **Brdo (Berdo / Birdo, Istro-Romanian: ''Bârdo'') == See also == * [[Istro-Romanian language]] * [[Istro-Romanian grammar]] * [[Eastern Romance substratum]] * [[Romance languages]] * [[Romanian language]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ;Bibliography * della Croce, Ireneo: Historia antica, e moderna sacra, e profana, della città di Trieste, (Trieste, 1698) * Feresini, Nerina: ''Il Comune istro-romeno di Valdarsa''. Edizioni Italo Svevo. Trieste: 1996 * Kovačec, August: Istrorumunjsko-hrvatski rječnik s gramatikom i tekstovima ''(Glosar Istroroman-Croat cu gramatica si texte)''. Verba moritura vol. I, 378 p. Mediteran, Pula 1998 * Podbersič, Renato: Čičke prekvanitce z Goca (Folklorni obrazci z Golca v Slovenski Čičariji). LIBRIS. Koper: 2007 * Tekavčić, Pavao: ''Due voci romene in un dialetto serbo-croato dell'Isola di Veglia'' (Krk). Studia Romanica 7: 35-38, Zagreb 1959 == External links == {{Commons category}} * [http://www.istro-romanian.com Istro-Romanian Community Worldwide] * [http://www.istro-romanian.net Istro-Romanians in Croatia] {{Ethnic groups in Croatia}} {{Romanian diaspora}} [[Category:Istro-Romanians]] [[Category:Eastern Romance peoples in Croatia]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Croatia]] [[ca:Istroromanès]] [[es:Istrorrumanos]]

[[File:Catalonia-Campanar catedral de Vic, Osona.jpg|thumb|The cathedral in Vic, where Josep Torras lived the last part of his life.]]
'''Josep Torras i Bages''' ({{IPA-ca|ʒuˈzɛp ˈtorəs}}), born at [[Les Cabanyes]], [[Alt Penedès]], on 12 September 1846, died at [[Vic]], [[Osona]], on 7 February 1916, was a [[Catalonia|Catalan]] thinker, writer, and [[bishop]]. He was one of the main figures in the turn of the 20th century [[Catholicism|Catholic]] [[Catalan nationalism]].
==Biography==
===Torras and the Catalan traditions=== Josep Torras strongly criticized the [[Laïcité|secularism]] displayed by the "militant nationalism" of [[Enric Prat de la Riba]] (1870–1917). In 1892 he wrote ''La tradició catalana'', where he emphasized Conservative Nationalism and warned against the erosion of Christian values. Exalting rural life, the family, religion, and the love of [[Catalan language]], the land and the language took an almost mystical dimension in his point of view.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u6WaAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA24&lpg=PA24&dq=Torras+i+Bages+rural+catalonia&source=bl&ots=4xtWJN8r2Z&sig=VwnfgABn9Hy1VpHy-RxHkxRORUY&hl=en&ei=vtWOScCeHczPkAXEqNSyDA&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=3&ct=result|title=Double Talk: Bilingualism and the Politics of Ethnicity in Catalonia|last=Woolard|first=Kathryn Ann|date=1989|publisher=Stanford University Press|isbn=9780804715027|language=en}}</ref> He was convinced that the Catalan nation had to be Christian in order to establish itself as something enduring and meaningful in the future. His words ''"Catalunya serà cristiana o no serà"'' (Catalonia will be Christian or will not be) are engraved at the gate of [[Santa Maria de Montserrat]] abbey.<ref>[http://coa.sagepub.com/cgi/pdf_extract/10/2-3/51 Josep M. Fradera, ''Rural Traditionalism and Conservative Nationalism in Catalonia 1865-1900''] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120709191840/http://coa.sagepub.com/cgi/pdf_extract/10/2-3/51 |date=2012-07-09 }}</ref>
Torras was very interested in the study of the [[seny]], a virtue often considered a [[Catalan symbols|Catalan cultural symbol]], and encouraged others, like [[Josep Abril i Virgili]] and Jaume Raventós, to do so.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=wgxlZFEckGEC&pg=PA156&lpg=PA156&dq=Jaume+Ravent%C3%B3s+seny&source=bl&ots=oxGmf9t2A0&sig=nXSPNGIH21v0-7z1Eju1cbxjt7s&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=3&ct=result Carta del Bisbe de Vic a Jaume Raventós en aplegar els volums titulats ''Proses de bon Seny'' (Letter to Jaume Raventós)] {{ca icon}}</ref> Based on good sense and wisdom, ''seny'' was perceived by Torras to originate in the traditional Catalan rural farm (''casa pairal'' or ''masia''). The life in the traditional non-urban setting with its frugality, hard work, and religious piety was the right ground for the development of the values and social norms embodied in the Catalan ''seny''.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=DiGiacomo|first=Susan M.|date=1987|title="La Caseta i l'Hortet": Rural Imagery in Catalan Urban Politics|jstor=3317655|journal=Anthropological Quarterly|volume=60|issue=4|pages=160–166|doi=10.2307/3317655}}</ref>
===Ecclesiastical work=== [[File:Ilmo. y Rvmo. Doctor don José Torras y Bages.jpg|thumb|right|Doctor don José Torras y Bages.]]In 1882 Torras became counselor to bishop of Barcelona [[José María de Urquinaona y Vidot|J. M. Urquinaona]]. Specializing in conflict-solving among Catholics, he also was the censor of some newspapers that were compromised in certain inner troubles (''procesos canónicos'') of the Spanish Church at the time.
Years later, in 1888, Josep Torras, after analyzing the growing secularization of Spanish society, wrote the book ''El clero en la vida social moderna'' in [[Spanish language|Spanish]]. In his work he wrote straightforwardly about the often [[integrist]] or reactionary position of the Catholic Church in [[Spain]], and sought to encourage the Spanish Catholic clergy to adapt to the spirit of the times and to focus on moderation and personal spiritual discipline, advice that went largely unheeded at the time.
Torras was promoted to become [[archbishop]] of [[Archdiocese of Burgos|Burgos]] in 1906 and [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Valencia in Spain|Valencia]] in 1913, but he declined because he did not want to put a distance between himself and the mission he was committed to in the heart of Catalonia.<ref>[http://www.canalsocial.net/GER/ficha_GER.asp?id=3166&cat=biografiasuelta GER Torras i Bages - Biografia suelta] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080616091123/http://www.canalsocial.net/GER/ficha_GER.asp?id=3166&cat=biografiasuelta |date=2008-06-16 }}</ref>
==Works== Even though most of his works have been published in compilations under the title ''Obres completes'', his abundant correspondence, crucial for the understanding of certain issues surrounding Catalan nationalism, remains for the most part unpublished. *''Obres completes'', Foment de Pietat, 10 vols., Barcelona 1912-27 *''El clero en la vida social moderna'', 1888 {{es icon}} *''La tradició catalana'', 1892 {{ca icon}}
==See also== *[[Seny]] *[[Catalan nationalism]] *[[Catalan symbols]] *[[Cercle Artístic de Sant Lluc]] *[[Roman Catholic Diocese of Vic]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://books.google.com/books?id=wgxlZFEckGEC&pg=PA156&lpg=PA156&dq=Jaume+Ravent%C3%B3s+seny&source=bl&ots=oxGmf9t2A0&sig=nXSPNGIH21v0-7z1Eju1cbxjt7s&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=3&ct=result#PPA144,M1 Josep Torras i Bages - Obres completes]
{{Authority control}}

Nagendra Babu | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1961|10|29}} | birth_place = [[Mogalthur]], [[Andhra Pradesh]], [[India]] | residence = [[Hyderabad]], [[Telangana]], [[India]] | nationality = [[India]]n | othername = Naga Babu | occupation = [[Actor]], [[Film producer|Producer]] | yearsactive = 1988–present | height = | spouse = [[Padmaja Konidela]] | children = [[Varun Tej |Varun Tej Konidela]]
[[Niharika Konidela]] | parents = Konidela Venkat Rao,Konidela Anjana Devi | brothers = Konidela Chiranjeevi , Konidela Pavan Kalyan | relatives = See [[List of South Indian film families#Chiranjeevi family|Chiranjeevi family]] }} ''' Konidela Nagendra Babu''' is an [[Indian people|Indian]], [[Telugu language|Telugu]] film [[actor]] and [[Film producer|producer]]. He acts mainly in supporting roles and villain roles, though he has also played the lead role in some films. He has acted in ''[[143 (film)|143]]'', ''[[Anji (film)|Anji]]'', ''[[Shock (2006 film)|Shock]]'', ''[[Sri Ramadasu]]'', ''[[Chandamama (2007 film)|Chandamama]]'' and ''[[Orange (2010 Telugu film)|Orange]]''. He has produced several films with his brothers, [[Chiranjeevi]] and [[Pawan Kalyan]] under [[Anjana Productions]]. He has two children, actor [[Varun Tej]] and [[Niharika Konidela|Niharika]].{{cite news| url=http://www.telangananewspaper.com/nagababu-daughter-niharika-debut-movie-titled/ | location=Hyderabad, India | work=TNP LIVE | title=Nagababu Daughter Niharika Debut Movie | date=26 September 2015}} He currently appears in television serials{{cite web|url=http://www.indiaglitz.com/channels/telugu/article/24938.html|title=Nagendra Babu and Pawan Kalyan come together|date=31 August 2006|publisher=IndiaGlitz|accessdate=27 December 2010}} and is also a judge on the comedy show, ''[[Jabardasth (Comedy Show)|Jabardasth]]'', which aired on [[ETV Network]].{{cite web | url=http://cinesiren.com/nagababu-fires-on-naayak-producer-naayak-50-days-celebration-pics/ | title=Producers need to attend functions organized by Fans Associations | publisher=cinesiren | accessdate=February 28, 2013}} He owns a [[production company]], [[Anjana Productions]] in which his family members appear as lead actors.{{cite web|url=https://www.thenewsminute.com/article/tollywoods-first-families-kings-and-queens-who-rule-telugu-film-industry-67805|title=Tollywood's first families|website=www.newsminute.com}} Though he has produced few movies, he has set his style of bench marks in his productions. ==Filmography== ===As actor=== * ''ALL THE FILMS ARE IN [[Telugu language|TELUGU]], UNLESS OTHERWISE NOTICED.'' {| class="wikitable sortable" |- style="background:#ccc" ! revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=January 2008}} {{distinguish|Lamba people (Zambia)}} The '''Lambas''' are an ethnic and linguistic group of people living in the Kéran and Doufelgou Districts (''Préfecture'') of the [[Kara Region]] in Northern [[Togo]] and in the Atakora and Donga Departments of [[Bénin]], West Africa. The capital of the [[Kéran]] District is [[Kandé|Kanté]] and the capital of the [[Doufelgou]] District is [[Niamtougou]].
In Togo, the Lambas live the Center and West of the Kéran District; in the [[Togo Mountains]] on the Défalé Chain; in the Western reaches of Doufelgou District; in Eastern reaches of Doufelgou District North of the Binah River: and, in Niamtougou, in the Villages of Yaka and Agbandé. In Bénin, the Lambas live in and around Boucoumbé (Boukamtié) in the [[Atakora Department]] and near [[Djougou]] and [[Bassila]] in the [[Donga Department]]. They also live in diaspora zones in the Central and Plateaux Regions of Togo, in border areas of Ghana, and in the capital cities of [[Lomé]] and [[Cotonou]].
==People==
The Lambas are primarily engaged in [[subsistence farming]] and small animal husbandry, especially chickens, guinea fowl, goats, pigs, and sheep. They grow [[millet]] and [[sorghum]] that they make into a thick porridge (''la pâte'') that is the staple of their diet and that they brew into [[African Sorghum Beer|thick low-alcohol beer]]. They also grow [[Yam (vegetable)|yams]] and [[cassava]], [[Macrotyloma geocarpum|groundnuts]] (peanuts), beans, and [[fonio]].
The Lambas have migrated in search of fertile available land in Togo to the area along the North-South National Road No. 1 between Sokodé and Notsé, where they have founded numerous communities. In addition, they have migrated to Togo's capital city, Lomé, and the economic capital of Bénin, Cotonou, in search of wage employment. Lamba men served in the colonial armies of Germany, Britain, and France as well as in the Togolese and Beninese armies in the years following the independences of the two countries.
The Lambas refer to themselves and to their Language as Lama. Lamba is the name attributed to them in French and that continues to be used in the administration. In addition, all of the inhabitants of the Doufelgou District of Togo were designated as Lossos by the colonial administration, including people who identify themselves as Lama and Nawdba. Therefore, Lambas from the Doufelgou District are still frequently called Losso. The two populations have exercised considerable mutual influence but their languages are different and do not resemble each other.
==Language==
The Lambas speak a collection of closely related dialects that are grouped together as the [[Lama language]]. There are approximately 200,000 native speakers of Lama in Togo and Bénin. Lama most closely resembles the [[Kabiyé language]] spoken by the Kabiyé people in the Kozah and Binah Districts of Togo as well as in diaspora points. Lama and [http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=kbp Kabiyé] are classified under the [http://www.ethnologue.com/show_family.asp?subid=90744 Grusi, Eastern] cluster of the [http://www.ethnologue.com/show_family.asp?subid=90721 Gur (or ''Voltaique'')] group of the [http://www.ethnologue.com/show_family.asp?subid=90725 Niger-Congo] languages. Also included in this cluster are Tem (Cotokoli), Bagou-Koussountou, Lukpa (Logba or Dompago), Delo (Ntribou), and Chala. Speakers of this cluster of languages constitute 28% of the population of Togo and are the second most widely spoken cluster of languages in Togo after the Gbé cluster that includes Éwé, Mina, and Waci.
{{Ethnic groups in Benin}} {{Ethnic groups in Togo}} [[Category:Ethnic groups in Togo]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Benin]]

{{notability|Biographies|date=August 2011}}
'''Larry Downes''' (born March 1, 1959) is an Internet industry analyst and author on business strategies and information technology. Downes is best known for his first book, ''Unleashing the Killer App: Digital Strategies for Market Dominance'' (Harvard Business School 1998), which focuses on the potential of products and services for dramatically changing business. ''Unleashing the Killer App'' sold over 200,000 copies and was named by the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' one of the five most important books on [[business]] and the [[Internet]] ever published. Downes is also the author of ''The Laws of Disruption: Harnessing the New Forces that Govern Business and Life in the Digital Age.''
His most recent book, co-authored with Paul Nunes, is ''Big Bang Disruption: Strategy in the Age of Devastating Innovation''.
Downes writes regularly for a variety of publications, including ''The Washington Post'', ''Harvard Business Review'', ''[[Forbes]]''<ref name="Forbes Blog">{{cite web | url=https://blogs.forbes.com/larrydownes/ | title=Laws of Disruption |work=Forbes | accessdate=August 4, 2011 | first=Larry | last=Downes}}</ref> and [[CNet]] about such issues as [[net neutrality]], the U.S. [[Federal Communications Commission]] (FCC), and disruptive innovation generally.
He has testified frequently before Congress on technology policy. On February 15, 2011, he testified in front of Congress against the FCC's net neutrality rules, the so-called "Open Internet" rule, which prohibits blocking of lawful content and bans various forms of discrimination in the handling of specific data packets.<ref name="Downes FCC Testimony">{{cite web |url=http://techfreedom.org/files/publications/2011/Downes-Net-Neutrality-Written-Testimony.pdf |title=Ensuring Competition on the Internet: Net Neutrality & Antitrust |date=February 15, 2011 |accessdate=August 4, 2011 |author=Downes, Larry |pages=46}}</ref> He is a critic of over-regulation and an advocate of increased competition. His writings have appeared in various newspapers and magazines around the world, including ''[[Forbes]]'', [[CNet]], ''[[USA Today]]'',<ref name="Mouse Creativity">{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/opinion/editorials/2002-10-07-oplede_x.htm |title='Free the Mouse' for creativity's sake |publisher=USA Today |accessdate=August 4, 2011 |author=Downes, Larry |date=October 7, 2002}}</ref> ''[[Harvard Business Review]]'',<ref name="Commerce Clause">{{cite web |url=http://hbr.org/2005/09/the-commerce-clause-wakes-up/ar/1 |title=The Commerce Clause Wakes Up |date=September 2005 |accessdate=August 4, 2011 |author=Downes, Larry}}</ref> ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'', and the ''[[Harvard Journal of Law and Technology]]''.
Downes held a faculty appointment at the [[Northwestern University School of Law]] from 1998–2001 where he taught courses on The Law of Technology. He also held a faculty appointment at the [[Booth School of Business]] from 1999–2000. He was an Adjunct Professor at the [[University of California, Berkeley]] from 2003–2007, where he was Associate Dean of the School of Information and at the Haas School of Business. From 2006–2010, he was a nonresident Fellow at the [[Stanford Center for Internet and Society]].
From 2014, he was appointed a Project Director at the Georgetown Center for Business and Public Policy's Evolution of Regulation and Innovation project, housed at the [[McDonough School of Business]] at [[Georgetown University]].<ref name="Downes' Work at Georgetown">{{cite web |url=http://cbpp.georgetown.edu/policy-focus/digital-economy/ERI-project |title=The Evolution of Regulation and Innovation Project at the Georgetown Center for Business and Public Policy |date=March 28, 2014 |accessdate=October 14, 2016}}</ref> He also serves as Research Fellow for the Accenture Institute for High Performance.
Downes received his BA from [[Northwestern University]] in 1980 with Honors in [[English language|English]], [[History]], and [[Computer Science]]. He received his J.D. with High Honors from the [[University of Chicago Law School]] in 1993. From 1993–1994, he clerked for Chief Judge [[Richard Posner]] in the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit]]. He was also a consultant with [[Andersen Consulting]] (now [[Accenture]]) and [[McKinsey & Co]] from 1980–1990 and was raised in [[Oak Park, Michigan]].
== References == {{Reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Downes, Larry}} [[Category:Technology in society]] [[Category:Information society]] [[Category:1959 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:University of Chicago faculty]] [[Category:Northwestern University alumni]] [[Category:University of Chicago Law School alumni]] [[Category:Northwestern University faculty]]

{{refimprove|date=August 2012}} {{Infobox ethnic group |group=Lebanese Mexicans
''libano-mexicano''
{{lang|ar|مكسيكي لبناني}} |image= |caption= |population='''991''' Lebanon-born residents (2017){{cite web|title=Table 1: Total migrant stock at mid-year by origin and by major area, region, country or area of destination, 2017|url=http://www.un.org/en/development/desa/population/migration/data/estimates2/data/UN_MigrantStockByOriginAndDestination_2017.xlsx|publisher=United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division |accessdate=17 August 2018}}
est. '''400,000''' Mexicans of Lebanese descent{{cite web|title=The biggest enchilada|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/comment/personal-view/3641163/The-biggest-enchilada.html|publisher=The Telegraph|accessdate=28 February 2015|quote=The Mexican-Lebanese community now numbers around 400,000 but punches way above its weight in commerce...}} |popplace= [[Nuevo León]], [[Yucatán]], [[Veracruz]], [[Coahuila]], [[Jalisco]], [[Sinaloa]], [[Mexico City]], [[Baja California]], [[Guanajuato]], [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], [[Durango]], [[Puebla]] |langs=[[Mexican Spanish]] and [[Lebanese Arabic]] |rels=Predominantly [[Christianity in Lebanon|Christianity]], minority [[Islam in Lebanon|Islam]] | related = [[Lebanese people|Lebanese]] and [[Lebanese diaspora]] }} {{Lebanese people}} '''Lebanese Mexicans''' refers to [[Mexicans|Mexican]] citizens of [[Lebanon|Lebanese]] origin. Although Lebanese Mexicans made up less than 5% of the total immigrant population in [[Mexico]] during the 1930s, they constituted half of the immigrant economic activity.{{cite web|url=http://confines.mty.itesm.mx/articulos2/GarciaRE.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-04-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090327124211/https://confines.mty.itesm.mx/articulos2/GarciaRE.pdf |archivedate=2009-03-27 |df= }} Lebanese influence in [[Culture of Mexico|Mexican culture]] can be seen most particularly in [[Mexican cuisine]], where they have introduced many foods and dishes and created their own recipes such as ''[[al pastor]]''. Interethnic marriage in the Lebanese community, regardless of religious affiliation, is very high; most have only one parent with Lebanese ethnicity. As a result, only a few speak any Arabic, typically limited to a few basic words. The majority, especially among younger generations, speak [[Spanish language|Spanish]] as first language. [[Carlos Slim]], formerly the richest man in the world,{{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/carlos-slim-helu |title= Carlos Slim Helu & family |work=Forbes |accessdate=March 5, 2013}} is an example of Lebanese Mexican success in Mexican society. ==Migration history== Lebanese immigration to Mexico started in the 19th and early 20th centuries.{{cite web|url=http://goliath.ecnext.com/coms2/gi_0199-536840/Marin-Guzman-Roberto-and-Zidane.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080112143920/http://goliath.ecnext.com/coms2/gi_0199-536840/Marin-Guzman-Roberto-and-Zidane.html#abstract |archive-date=12 January 2008 |title=Marin-Guzman, Roberto and Zidane Zeraoui. Arab Immigration in Mexico in the Nineteenth and Twentieth Centuries: Assimilation and Arab Heritage.(Book Review)}} In 1892, the first Lebanese arrived in Mexico from [[Beirut]] in French ships to Mexican ports such as [[Progreso, Yucatán|Puerto Progreso]], [[Veracruz, Veracruz|Veracruz]] and [[Tampico, Tamaulipas|Tampico]].{{citation needed|date=August 2018}} At that time, [[Beirut Vilayet|Lebanon was not an independent nation]]; the territory was held by the [[Ottoman Empire]] and later became a [[French Mandate for Syria and the Lebanon|French protectorate]]. Roughly 100,000 [[Arabic language|Arabic-speakers]] settled in Mexico during this time period. They settled in significant numbers in [[Yucatán]], [[Nayarit|Veracruz]], [[Puebla]], [[Mexico City]] and the northern part of the country (mainly in the states of [[Baja California]], [[Nuevo León]], [[Sinaloa]], [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], [[Coahuila]], and [[Durango]], as well as the city of [[Tampico]] and [[Guadalajara]]). Although Lebanese people made up less than 5% of the total immigrant population in Mexico during the 1930s, they constituted half of the immigrant economic activity.{{cite web|url=http://confines.mty.itesm.mx/articulos2/GarciaRE.pdf |title=Los árabes de México. Asimilación y herencia cultural |language=Spanish |accessdate=2010-04-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090327124211/https://confines.mty.itesm.mx/articulos2/GarciaRE.pdf |archivedate=2009-03-27 |df= }} During the [[1948 Israel-Lebanon war]] and the [[Six-Day War]], thousands of Lebanese left Lebanon and went to Mexico, first arriving in Veracruz. Another concentration of Lebanese-Mexicans is in Baja California facing the US–Mexican border, especially in the cities of [[Mexicali, Baja California|Mexicali]] and [[Tijuana, Baja California|Tijuana]] across from [[San Diego, California|San Diego]] with a large [[Lebanese-American]] community (about 280,000), some of whose families have relatives in Mexico. ==Lebanese culture in Mexico== [[Image:Shrine of Our Lady of Perpetual Help, San Luis Potosi city, San Luis Potosi state, Mexico03.jpg|thumb|right|180px|Image of [[Saint Charbel]] in a Roman Catholic church in [[San Luis Potosí, San Luis Potosí]]]] [[File:Statue of Saint Charbel.JPG|180px|thumb|right|Statue with prayer requests at the [[Mexico City Metropolitan Cathedral]]]] One Lebanese cultural tradition in Mexico itself is to place colored ribbons to the image of St. Charbel to ask some favor or some miracle and to give thanks. The tradition arose in the Candelaria Church in Merced in the historic center of Mexico City. The immigration of Lebanese to Mexico has influenced Mexican culture, in particular food, including introducing [[kibbeh]] and [[tabbouleh]], and even creating recipes such as ''[[tacos árabes]]''. By 1765, [[Phoenix dactylifera|dates]], which originated in North Africa and the Middle East, were introduced into Mexico by the Spaniards. The fusion between Arab and Mexican food has highly influenced the [[Yucatán (state)|Yucatecan]] cuisine. ==Religion== The majority of Lebanese-Mexicans are [[Christianity in Lebanon|Christians]] who belong to the [[Maronite Christianity in Lebanon|Maronite]], [[Roman Catholicism in Lebanon|Roman Catholic]], [[Orthodox Christianity in Lebanon|Eastern Orthodox]] and [[Melkite Christianity in Lebanon|Melkite Catholic]]. The Lebanese initially practiced Catholicism independently from other Mexicans, but learned to speak Spanish; Lebanese-Mexican children quickly joined the country's religious activities. A few [[Islam in Lebanon|Lebanese Muslims]] settled in Mexico. They were responsible for the opening of the first mosque in Mexico, built in the city of [[Torreon]], in Coahuila, and named Suraya. [[Image:Embassy of Lebanon in Mex. city.JPG|thumb|right|Lebanese Embassy in [[Mexico City]]]] ==Notable people== {{Further|List of Lebanese people in Mexico}} ==See also== * [[Immigration to Mexico]] * [[Lebanon–Mexico relations]] * [[Lebanese diaspora]] * [[Lebanese Colombians]] * [[Lebanese Brazilians]] * [[Lebanese Argentines]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://youtube.com/watch?v=JpkgIp9w8IM Los que llegaron - Libaneses] from [[Canal Once]] {{Lebanese diaspora}} {{Arab diaspora}} {{Ethnic groups in Mexico}} [[Category:Arab Mexican]] [[Category:Mexican people of Lebanese descent| ]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Mexico]] [[Category:Arab groups]] [[Category:Lebanese diaspora by country|Mexico]] [[Category:Lebanese emigrants]] [[Category:Immigration to Mexico]]

A list of '''Australian literary awards''' and prizes: {{TOC right}}
== Literature == * [[ABC Fiction Award]] * [[ACT Writing and Publishing Awards]] * [[The Age Book of the Year]] – temporarily suspended in 2013 * [[Ada Cambridge Prize]] * [[Australian Literature Society Gold Medal]] * [[The Australian/Vogel Literary Award]] * [[Banjo Awards]]<ref name="Banjo">{{cite web | url = http://dymocksbuilding.com.au/contentstatic/literarymatter/awards/banjo.asp | title = Banjo Awards | publisher = Dymocks Booksellers | accessdate = 2008-01-16 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * [[Barbara Jefferis Award]] * [[Colin Roderick Award]] * [[Queensland Premier's Literary Awards#Unpublished Indigenous Writer – The David Unaipon Award|David Unaipon Award]] * [[Melbourne Prize for Literature]] * [[Miles Franklin Award]] * [[Ned Kelly Awards]] * [[New South Wales Premier's Literary Awards]] * [[Nita Kibble Literary Award]] * [[Patrick White Award]] * [[Prime Minister's Literary Awards]]<ref>[http://www.arts.gov.au/literature/pmliteraryawards 2008 Prime Minister's Literary Awards] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080720203000/http://www.arts.gov.au/literature/pmliteraryawards |date=2008-07-20 }}</ref> * [[Queensland Premier's Literary Awards]] * [[South Australian Premier's Awards]] * [[Stella Prize]] * [[The Sydney Morning Herald Best Young Australian Novelists]] award * [[T. A. G. Hungerford Award]] * [[Tasmanian Premier's Literary Prizes]] * [[TDK Australian Audio Book Awards]] (1989–1999) * [[Vance Palmer Prize for Fiction]] * [[Victorian Premier's Literary Award]] * [[Western Australian Premier’s Australia-Asia Literary Award]]<ref>[http://www.dca.wa.gov.au/news/stories/front_page_items/australia_and_asia146s_richest_literary_award_launched Australia and Asia's richest literary award launched] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516203423/http://www.dca.wa.gov.au/news/stories/front_page_items/australia_and_asia146s_richest_literary_award_launched |date=2008-05-16 }}</ref> * [[Western Australian Premier's Book Awards]] * [[Voss Literary Prize]]
== Short stories == * [[The Age Short Story Award]] * [[Aurealis Award]]s ** [[Aurealis Award for best fantasy short story|Best Fantasy Short Story]] ** [[Aurealis Award for best horror short story|Best Horror Short Story]] ** [[Aurealis Award for best science fiction short story|Best Science Fiction Short Story]] ** [[Aurealis Award for best young-adult short story|Best Young-Adult Short Story]] * [[Australian Book Review#ABR Elizabeth Jolley Short Story Prize|Elizabeth Jolley Short Story Prize]]
== Poetry == * [[ACT Writing and Publishing Awards]] * [[Anne Elder Award]] * [[Bruce Dawe National Poetry Prize]]<ref name="dawe">{{cite web|title=The Bruce Dawe National Poetry Prize |publisher=UQS Australia Faculty of the Arts |url=http://www.usq.edu.au/arts/community/poetryprize/default.htm |accessdate=2007-09-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070904182059/http://www.usq.edu.au/arts/community/poetryprize/default.htm |archivedate=2007-09-04 |df= }}</ref> * [[The Blake Poetry Prize]] * [[Christopher Brennan Award]] * [[C. J. Dennis Prize for Poetry]] * [[Grace Leven Prize for Poetry]] * [[Griffith University Josephine Ulrick Poetry Prize]]<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.griffith.edu.au/humanities-languages/school-humanities/news-and-events/josephine-ulrick-prizes |title=Archived copy |access-date=2014-07-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140820154043/http://www.griffith.edu.au/humanities-languages/school-humanities/news-and-events/josephine-ulrick-prizes |archive-date=2014-08-20 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> * [[Gwen Harwood Poetry Prize]] * [[Ipswich Poetry Feast]] * [[Judith Wright Calanthe Award]] * [[Judith Wright Prize]] * [[Kenneth Slessor Prize for Poetry]] * [[Mary Gilmore Prize]] * [[Newcastle Poetry Prize]] * [[Australian Book Review|Peter Porter Poetry Prize]] * [[Philip Hodgins|Philip Hodgins Memorial Medal]] * [[Queen's Gold Medal for Poetry]] * [[The Roland Robinson Literary Award]] * [[Thomas Shapcott Poetry Prize]] * [[Val Vallis Award]] * [[The Vincent Buckley Poetry Prize]]
==Plays== * [[Patrick White Playwrights' Award]] * [[Philip Parsons Young Playwrights Award]]
==Youth literature== * [[Inky Awards]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://insideadog.com.au/page/inky-awards|title=The Inky Awards - Inside A Dog|publisher=}}</ref>
==Children's books== * [[List of CBCA Awards|Children's Book Council of Australia awards]] **Australian Children's Choice Awards *** [[BILBY Award|Books I Love Best Yearly]] (BILBY Awards) — CBCA Queensland Branch *** [[COOL Award|Canberra's Own Outstanding List]] (COOL Awards) — CBCA ACT Branch **Children's Book of the Year Awards *** [[Children's Book of the Year Award: Early Childhood|Early Childhood]] *** [[Children's Book of the Year Award: Younger Readers|Younger Readers]] *** [[Children's Book of the Year Award: Older Readers|Older Readers]] *** [[Children's Book of the Year Award: Picture Book|Picture Book of the Year]] *** [[Children's Book of the Year Award: Eve Pownall Award for Information Books|Eve Pownall Award for Information Books]] ** [[Crichton Award for Children's Book Illustration]] ** [[Dame Annabelle Rankin Award]] ** [[Leila St John Award]] ** [[Nan Chauncy Award]] * [[Dromkeen Medal]]
== History == * [[Australian History Awards]] * [[New South Wales Premier's History Awards]] * [[Victorian Community History Awards]]

==Nonfiction== * [[Association for the Study of Australian Literature#Awards|A.D. Hope Prize]] * [[ACT Writing and Publishing Awards]] * [[Australian Book Review|Calibre Prize for an Outstanding Essay]] * [[The Bragg UNSW Press Prize for Science Writing]] * [[Magarey Medal for biography]], [[Association for the Study of Australian Literature]] * [[National Biography Award]] * [[Peter Blazey Fellowship]] * [[Association for the Study of Australian Literature#Awards|Walter McRae Russell Award]] * [[Walkley Awards]] * [[Whitley Awards (Australia)]]
== See also ==
* [[Australian literature]] * [[Commonwealth Writers Prize|The Commonwealth Writers Prize]] * [[List of literary awards]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Australian literature-related lists|Awards]] [[Category:Australian literary awards| ]] [[Category:Lists of awards|Australian literary]]

This list is a subsection of [[List of prizes, medals, and awards]]; this list focuses on early career awards, which are determined within a profession by age or length of time in the profession.
==List of awards== ===Arts=== ;Literary * [[Geoffrey Faber Memorial Prize]] (recognises a single volume of poetry or fiction by a Commonwealth author under 40) * [[International Young Publisher of the Year]] (young publishers) * [[Bronwen Wallace Memorial Award]] (a writer under 35 who has not yet published his or her first book)
;Music *[[BBC Young Musician of the Year]] *[[Eurovision Young Musicians]] * [[International Young Music Entrepreneur of the Year]] (music industry) * [[Peter Whittingham Award]] (musicians)
;Other
* [[Tiger Conference|Top 30 Under 30]] ( leaders from different spheres under 30)
* [[Turner Prize]] (visual artist under age of 50)
===Sciences=== * [[Fields Medal]] (mathematicians not over age of 40) * [[Francqui Prize]] (Belgian scholar or scientist under 50) * [[Otto Hahn Medal]] (young/junior scientists) * [[Otto-Klung-Weberbank Prize]] (outstanding younger German scientists under the age of 40) * [[Passano Foundation Young Scientist Award]] * [[Searle Scholars Program]] ( career development award made annually to the 15 young US professionals in biomedical research and chemistry) * [[Prime Minister's Prizes for Science|Frank Fenner's (prev. Science Minister's) Prize for Life Scientist of the Year]] (early to mid-career scientists, not more than ten years past the award of their highest degree (e.g. Master’s or PhD), working in the life sciences) * [[Prime Minister's Prizes for Science|Malcolm McIntosh Prize for Physical Scientist of the Year]] (early to mid-career scientists, not more than ten years past the award of their highest degree (e.g. Master’s or PhD), working in the physical sciences) * [[Presidential Early Career Award]] for scientists and engineers * [[Margaret Oakley Dayhoff Award]] from the [[Biophysical Society]], Rockfille, Maryland - given to a woman who "has achieved prominence for 'substantial contributions to science'" and showing high promise in the early part of her career * Maria Goeppert-Mayer Award, American Physical Society (best young physicist in the world)<ref>University of Massachusetts, [http://www.umass.edu/newsoffice/article/obituary-judy-young-astronomer-who-built Judy Young Obituary], May 28, 2014.</ref> * [[Charles F. Lucks Award]] (for significant contribution to the subject of thermal conductivity by a young scientist)
; Social sciences * [[T. S. Ashton Prize]] (economic history - author is 35 or younger, OR within 5 years of Ph.D., OR has no previous publication in economic/social history or closely related field) * [[John Bates Clark Medal]] (American economist under age of 40)
==See also== * [[List of prizes, medals, and awards]] * [[List of awards for youth]] * [[Lemelson-MIT Prize]], for mid-career inventors<ref>Lemelson-MIT Program, [http://web.mit.edu/invent/a-prize.html Lemelson-MIT Prize] (last visited 2010/06/06)</ref>
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Lists of awards]] [[Category:Early career awards| ]] [[Category:Awards by age of recipient|Early career]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Early career awards}}
