[[File:Mutinus Titinus.png|thumb|A denarius issued by Quintus Titius, thought to depict a bearded Mutunus Tutunus]] In [[Religion in ancient Rome|ancient Roman religion]], '''Mutunus Tutunus''' or '''Mutinus Titinus''' was a [[phallus|phallic]] marriage deity, in some respects equated with [[Priapus]]. His shrine was located on the [[Velian Hill]], supposedly since the [[founding of Rome]], until the 1st century BC.
During preliminary [[Marriage in ancient Rome|marriage rites]], Roman brides are supposed to have straddled the phallus of Mutunus to prepare themselves for intercourse, according to [[Church Fathers]] who interpreted this act as an obscene loss of [[virginity]].<ref>[[H.J. Rose]], ''The'' Roman Questions'' of Plutarch: A New Translation'' (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1924, reprinted 1974), p. 84 [https://books.google.com/books?id=rKOuoVnZsFAC&pg=PA84&dq=%22Mutunus+Tutunus%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=100&as_brr=3&cd=17#v=onepage&q=%22Mutunus%20Tutunus%22&f=false online.]</ref> The Christian apologist [[Arnobius]] says that Roman matrons were taken for a ride (''inequitare'') on Tutunus's "awful phallus" with its "immense shameful parts",<ref>[[Arnobius]], ''Adversus nationes'' 4.7 (see also 4.11): ''Tutunus, cuius immanibus pudendis horrentique fascino vestras inequitare matronas et auspicabile ducitis et optatis''. Compare [[Tertullian]], ''Ad nationes'' 2.11 and ''Apologeticus'' 25.3. On the translation of ''pudendis'', see J.N. Adams, ''The Latin Sexual Vocabulary'' (Johns Hopkins University Press, 1982, 1990), pp. 55–56.</ref> but other sources specify that it is brides who learned through the ritual not to be embarrassed by sex: "Tutinus, upon whose shameful lap sit brides, so that the god seems to sample their shame before the fact."<ref>[[Lactantius]], ''Divinarum Institutionum'' 1.20.36: ''Tutinus in cuius sinu pudendo nubentes praesident ut illarum pudicitiam prior deus delibasse videatur''. See also [[Augustine of Hippo]] (particularly ''[[De civitate Dei]]'' 4.11 and 6.9) who "several times refers with distaste to the practices associated with" the priapic gods; R.W. Dyson, ''The City of God Against the Pagans'' (Cambridge University Press, 1998, 2002), p. 1221 [https://books.google.com/books?id=ReU2M8cLtGcC&pg=PA1221&dq=%22Mutunus+Tutunus%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=100&as_brr=3&cd=7#v=onepage&q=%22Mutunus%20Tutunus%22&f=false online.]</ref> The 2nd-century grammarian [[Sextus Pompeius Festus|Festus]] is the only classical Latin source to take note of the god,<ref>[[Jean-Noël Robert]], ''Eros romano: sexo y moral en la Roma antigua'' (Editorial Complutense, 1999), p. 58 [https://books.google.com/books?id=1wS-vtfUdbUC&pg=PA58&dq=%22este+fascinus+tiene+nombre+y+se+le+honra+como+a+un+dios+Mutunus+Tutunus%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&cd=1#v=onepage&q=%22este%20fascinus%20tiene%20nombre%20y%20se%20le%20honra%20como%20a%20un%20dios%20Mutunus%20Tutunus%22&f=false online.]</ref> and the characterization of the rite by Christian sources is likely to be hostile or biased.<ref>[[Ronald Syme]], ''The Augustan Aristocracy'' (Oxford University Press, 1989), p. 6, note 37, marks "the mockery of the Christian writers"; see also Augustine's "distaste" for the phallic gods noted above. W.H. Parker, ''Priapea: Poems for a Phallic God'' (Routledge, 1988), p. 135 [https://books.google.com/books?id=iZUOAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA135&dq=%22Church+fathers%22+mutunus+OR+tutunus+OR+mutinus+OR+titinus&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=100&as_brr=3&cd=2#v=onepage&q=%22Church%20fathers%22%20mutunus%20OR%20tutunus%20OR%20mutinus%20OR%20titinus&f=false online], observes that the ritual of Mutunus was "condemned by early Church fathers"; Joseph Rykwert, ''The Idea of a Town: The Anthropology of Urban Form in Rome, Italy, and the Ancient World'' (MIT Press, 1988), p. 159 [https://books.google.com/books?id=Jq78Ff2TYHAC&pg=PA159&dq=%22Church+fathers%22+mutunus+OR+tutunus+OR+mutinus+OR+titinus&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=100&as_brr=3&cd=1#v=onepage&q=%22Church%20fathers%22%20mutunus%20OR%20tutunus%20OR%20mutinus%20OR%20titinus&f=false online], notes that they spoke "scathingly" of phallic rituals. Tertullian's bias in his assemblage of deities to deride (including Mutunus) pointed out by [[Mary Beard (classicist)|Mary Beard]], John North ''et al.'', ''Religions of Rome: A Sourcebook'' (Cambridge University Press, 1998), p. 359, note 1 [https://books.google.com/books?id=xQd82l39KX4C&pg=PA359&dq=Christian+mutunus+OR+tutunus+OR+mutinus+OR+titinus&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=100&as_brr=3&cd=17#v=onepage&q=Christian%20mutunus%20OR%20tutunus%20OR%20mutinus%20OR%20titinus&f=false online.] The ''fascinum'' — identified by Arnobius with the phallus of Mutunus — "was used by Christian writers in their tirades against pagan customs," points out Enrique Montero Cartelle, ''El latín erótico: aspectos léxicos y literarios'' (University of Seville, 1991), p. 70 [https://books.google.com/books?id=vUfXS1qQg9MC&pg=PA70&dq=%22Fascinum+fue+empleado+por+los+escritores+cristianos%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&cd=1#v=onepage&q=%22Fascinum%20fue%20empleado%20por%20los%20escritores%20cristianos%22&f=false online.] For a fuller discussion, see Carlos A. Contreras, "Christian Views of Paganism," ''Aufstieg und Niedergang der römischen Welt'' II.23.1 (1980) 974–1022, p. 1013 [https://books.google.com/books?id=0soI8HZXT3gC&pg=PA1013&dq=Christian+mutunus+OR+tutunus+OR+mutinus+OR+titinus&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=100&as_brr=3&cd=40#v=onepage&q=Christian%20mutunus%20OR%20tutunus%20OR%20mutinus%20OR%20titinus&f=false online] specifically in relation to Mutunus and in general asserting that "Arnobius commits the same mistake as other Fathers of applying Christian conceptions to pagan ideas in order to condemn them" (p. 1010). "Our knowledge of such things," that is, of rites such as those of Mutunus, "comes from Christian writers who are openly concerned to discredit all aspects of pagan idolatry," states Peter Stewart, ''Statues in Roman Society: Representation and Response'' (Oxford University Press, 2003), p. 266, note 24 [https://books.google.com/books?id=xauWDEbWMs8C&pg=PA266&dq=%22Our+knowledge+of+such+things+comes+from+Christian+writers+who+are+openly%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&cd=1#v=onepage&q=%22Our%20knowledge%20of%20such%20things%20comes%20from%20Christian%20writers%20who%20are%20openly%22&f=false online.]</ref>
==Etymology== Unlike Priapus, who is depicted in human form with an outsized [[erection]], Mutunus seems to have been embodied purely by the phallus, like the ''[[fascinus]]'' or the mysterious begetter of [[Servius Tullius]]. The god's name is related to two infrequently recorded slang words for penis in Latin, ''mūtō'' (or ''muttō'') and ''mūtōnium''.<ref>J.N. Adams, ''The Latin Sexual Vocabulary'' (Johns Hopkins University Press, 1982, 1990), p. 62 [https://books.google.com/books?id=GDP9VHGbF1AC&pg=PA62&dq=%22Mutunus+Tutunus%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=100&as_brr=3&cd=1#v=onepage&q=%22Mutunus%20Tutunus%22&f=false online.]</ref> "Mutto" was also used as a ''[[cognomen]]'', the third of the [[Roman naming convention|three elements of a Roman man's name]].<ref>''[[Corpus Inscriptionum Latinarum|CIL]]'' V.1412, 8473, as cited by Adams. The moneyer Quintus Titius, one of whose coins has been interpreted as depicting Mutunus, may have used the ''cognomen'' Mutto; [[T.R.S. Broughton]], ''The Magistrates of the Roman Republic'' (American Philological Association, 1952), vol. 2, p. 454.</ref> [[Gaius Lucilius|Lucilius]] offers the earliest recorded instance of both forms: ''at laeva lacrimas muttoni<ref>''Muttōni'' is the [[dative case|dative]] form of ''muttō''.</ref> absterget amica'' ("A girlfriend wipes away Mutto's tears — his left hand, that is"),<ref>Lucilius 307 and 959. Kirk Freundenburg has dubbed the ''muttō'' of Lucilius "clearly the least finicky of all personified penises in Roman satire": ''Satires of Rome: Threatening Poses from Lucilius to Juvenal'' (Cambridge University Press, 2001), p. 205 [https://books.google.com/books?id=QzOjItakZRoC&pg=PA205&dq=muttonis&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=100&as_brr=3&cd=3#v=onepage&q=muttonis&f=false online.] The left hand was preferred for masturbation by the Romans; see Antonio Varone, ''Erotica pompeiana: Love Inscriptions on the Walls of Pompeii'' («L'Erma» di Bretschneider, 2002), p. 95 [https://books.google.com/books?id=Vg9h-tW4KikC&dq=insula+felicula&q=%22To+grasp+the+meaning+of+the+text%22#v=snippet&q=%22To%20grasp%20the%20meaning%20of%20the%20text%22&f=false online.]</ref> and the derivative ''mūtōnium''. ''Mūtōnium'' may have replaced the earlier form, as it appears later among the [[Graffito (archaeology)|graffiti of Pompeii]].<ref>''CIL'' IV.1939, 1940.</ref> [[Horace]] has a dialogue with his ''muttō'': "What do you want? Surely you're not demanding a grand [[Roman consul|consul]]'s granddaughter as a cunt?"<ref>[[Horace]], ''[[Satires (Horace)|Sermones]]'' 1.2.68.</ref> Both Lucilius and Horace thus personify the ''muttō''.<ref>Adams, ''Latin Sexual Vocabulary'', p. 63.</ref> ''Mūtūniātus'', used by [[Martial]] and in the ''[[Priapeia|Corpus Priapeorum]]'',<ref>[[Martial]], ''Epigrams'' 3.73.1 and 11.63.2; [[Corpus Priapeorum]] 52.10.</ref> describes a "well-endowed" male.<ref>Craig Arthur Williams, ''Roman Homosexuality: Ideologies of Masculinity in Classical Antiquity'' (Oxford University Press, 1990), p. 92 [https://books.google.com/books?id=Kf4cs5Y0fiIC&pg=PA92&dq=%22Mutinus+Titinus%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=50&as_brr=3&cd=1#v=onepage&q=%22Mutinus%20Titinus%22&f=false online.]</ref>
Both parts of the name ''Mūtūnus Tūtūnus'' are [[reduplicative]], ''Tītīnus'' perhaps from ''tītus'', another slang word for "penis."<ref>Adams, ''Latin Sexual Vocabulary'', p. 32.</ref>
==Cult== The shrine of Mutunus Tutunus on the Velia has not been located. According to Festus, it was destroyed to make a private [[Roman bath|bath]] for the ''[[College of Pontiffs|pontifex]]'' and [[Augustus|Augustan]] supporter [[Gnaeus Domitius Calvinus|Domitius Calvinus]], even though it was revered as among the most ancient landmarks.<ref>[[Sextus Pompeius Festus|Festus]] 142L, as cited and discussed by Lawrence Richardson, ''A New Topographical Dictionary of Ancient Rome'' (Johns Hopkins University Press, 1992), p. 262 [https://books.google.com/books?lr=&num=50&as_brr=3&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&id=K_qjo30tjHAC&dq=%22Mutinus+Titinus%22&q=mutunus#v=snippet&q=mutunus&f=false online.] See also [[Ronald Syme]], ''The Augustan Aristocracy'' (Oxford University Press, 1989), p. 6 [https://books.google.com/books?id=fj8oQ4lzteIC&pg=PA6&dq=%22Mutunus+Tutunus%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=100&as_brr=3&cd=19#v=onepage&q=%22Mutunus%20Tutunus%22&f=false online.]</ref>
This uprooting raises the question of why Calvinus was permitted to displace such a venerable shrine. The Church Fathers associate Mutunus with groupings of other deities that are assumed to be based on the lost theological works of [[Varro]]. Through examining these connections, [[R. E. A. Palmer|Robert Palmer]] concluded that the old cult of Mutunus was merged with that of [[Liber|Father Liber]], who was variously identified with or shared attributes with [[Jupiter (mythology)|Jupiter]], [[Bacchus (mythology)|Bacchus]], and [[Priapus#Worship and attributes|Lampsacene Priapus]]. Palmer further conjectured that it was Mutunus, in the form of Liber, to whom [[Julius Caesar]] made sacrifice on the [[Assassination of Julius Caesar|day of his assassination]], receiving the ill [[omen]]s that the conspirator [[Decimus Junius Brutus Albinus|Decimus Brutus]] urged him to ignore. Caesar had previously celebrated his victory at the [[Battle of Munda]] on the [[Liberalia]], or festival of Liber held March 17, and he visited the house of the ''pontifex'' Calvinus on the [[Ides of March]], near the archaic shrine of Mutunus-Liber. In Palmer's view, the evident ill favor of the god gave [[Augustus]] license to reform the cult during his program of religious revivalism that often disguised radical innovations. The god was then [[Hellenized]] as [[Dionysus#Appellations|Bacchus Lyaeus]].<ref>[[R. E. A. Palmer|Robert E.A. Palmer]], "Mutinus Titinus: A Study in Etrusco-Roman Religion and Topography," in ''Roman Religion and Roman Empire: Five Essays'' (University of Pennsylvania Press, 1974), pp. 187–206.</ref>
Palmer concurred with [[Numismatics|numismatists]] who regard a [[denarius]] minted by [[Titia (gens)|Quintus Titius]], [[moneyer]] ''ca.'' 90–88 BC, as picturing an aged and bearded Mutunus on its [[obverse and reverse|obverse]].<ref>The identification dates back at least to Ch. Lenormant, "Types des médailles romaines," ''Revue numismatique'' (1838), pp. 11–12 [https://books.google.com/books?id=dnjRAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA11&dq=%22Mutinus+Titinus%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=50&as_brr=3&cd=17#v=onepage&q=%22Mutinus%20Titinus%22&f=false online.]</ref> The winged diadem is a reference to the Priapus of Lampsacus and to the winged phallus as a common motif in Roman decorative arts, which can also serve as an [[apotropaic]] charm against the [[evil eye]]. Another issue by Titius pictures an ivy-crowned Bacchus, with both denarii having a virtually identical [[Pegasus]] on the reverse. [[Michael Crawford (historian)|Michael Crawford]] finds "no good grounds" for identifying this figure as Mutunus,<ref>[[Michael Crawford (historian)|Michael Crawford]], ''Roman Republican Coinage'' (Cambridge University Press, 1974, 2001), vol. 1, pp. 344 and 346 [https://books.google.com/books?id=NuBION2KtM4C&pg=PA346&dq=%22Mutunus+Tutunus%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=100&as_brr=3&cd=18#v=onepage&q=%22Mutunus%20Tutunus%22&f=false online.]</ref> but Palmer points to the shared [[iconography]] of the Bacchus–Liber–Priapus figure and the associative [[etymology]] of the ''[[gens]]'' name Titius. A ''titus'' ("penis") with wings was a visual pun, since the word also referred to a type of bird.<ref name=satire>[[Scholiast]] on [[Persius]], ''Satire'' 1.20; Adams, ''Latin Sexual Vocabulary'', p. 32.</ref> Varro seems to have associated ''Titinus'' with the [[Titii]], in an etymological collocation that included [[Titus Tatius]], the royal [[Sabine]] contemporary of [[Romulus]]; the [[Curia]] Titia; or the ''[[Tribal Assembly|tribus]]'' of the [[Tribe#Etymology|Titienses]], one of the three original tribes of Rome.<ref>Palmer, "Mutinus Titinus," p. 190.</ref>

{{infobox officeholder |name = Nicholas Sarwark |image = Nicholas Sarwark in Phoenix October 2016.jpg |office = Chair of the [[Libertarian National Committee]] |term_start = June 29, 2014 |predecessor = [[Geoff Neale]] |office2 = Chair of the [[Libertarian Party of Maryland]] |term_start2 = 2001 |term_end2 = 2003 |predecessor2 = Steve Boone |successor2 = Chip Spangler |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1979|8|27}} |birth_name = Nicholas J. Sarwark |birth_place = [[Phoenix, Arizona]], U.S. |party = [[Libertarian Party (United States)|Libertarian]] |spouse = {{marriage|Valerie Sarwark|2009}} |children = 3 |residence = Phoenix, Arizona, U.S. |alma_mater = [[Washington Adventist University]]
[[American University]]{{cite web|url=http://spectrummagazine.org/article/2015/04/17/libertarian-party-chair-and-wau-grad-talks-about-freedom|title=Libertarian Party Chair and WAU Grad Talks About Freedom|website=spectrummagazine.org}} |religion = |website = [http://chair.sarwark.org/ Official website] }} '''Nicholas J. Sarwark''' (born August 27, 1979){{cite web|url=http://www.lp.org/nicholas-sarwark|title=Nicholas Sarwark - Libertarian Party|publisher=}} is the 19th and current chairman of the [[Libertarian National Committee]] (LNC), the executive body of the [[Libertarian Party (United States)|Libertarian Party (LP) of the United States]]. Prior to his election to that position in 2014,{{cite web | url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2014/jun/30/inside-the-beltway-984141094/ | title=Inside the Beltway: Libertarians shift into aggressive mode | work=[[The Washington Times]] | date=June 30, 2014 | accessdate=July 3, 2014 | author=Harper, Jennifer}} he served on several of the LP's national committees, as well as chair of the [[Libertarian Party of Maryland]], and as vice chair of the [[Libertarian Party of Colorado]].{{cite web | url=http://westmorelandtimes.com/news/12316/03/libertarians-elect-new-leadership/ | title=Libertarians elect new leadership | work=Westmoreland Times | date=July 3, 2014 | accessdate=July 3, 2014 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140706222144/http://westmorelandtimes.com/news/12316/03/libertarians-elect-new-leadership/ | archivedate=July 6, 2014 | df= }} Sarwark was a candidate for [[Mayor of Phoenix]] in that city's 2018 [[Phoenix mayoral election, 2018|mayoral election]]. He finished fourth with 10.5 per cent of the votes. ==Early life and education== {{Unsourced|section|date=November 2018}} Sarwark was born on August 27, 1979 in [[Phoenix, Arizona]]. He attended classes at community college while still attending high school. He graduated from [[Washington Adventist University]] in 1998 and joined the Libertarian Party in 1999. Sarwark received his [[Juris Doctor]] from [[American University]]’s Washington College of Law in 2008 [[cum laude]]. ==Career== Sarwark was elected as Libertarian National Committee chair by the delegates of the 2014 [[Libertarian National Convention]] in [[Columbus, Ohio]] on June 29, 2014, defeating incumbent chairman [[Geoff Neale]] who had served two non-consecutive terms as chair of the LNC. He was re-elected as chairman of the Libertarian National Committee at the [[Libertarian National Convention]] in [[2016 Libertarian National Convention|2016]] and again in [[2018 Libertarian National Convention|2018]]. He was a deputy [[public defender]] in the state of [[Colorado]]. He is also a businessman with experience in computer consulting and sales. ==Personal life== Sarwark formerly resided in [[Denver]], with his wife and three children, where he served as vice chair of the [[Colorado Libertarian Party]]."[http://lpmaryland.org/news-2014-libertarian-national-convention/ News from 2014 Libertarian Party National Convention]," lpmaryland.org (1 July 2014, updated 27 August 2014).  Before that, he lived in [[Maryland]], where he served as chair of the [[Libertarian Party of Maryland]]. He and his family moved to [[Phoenix, Arizona]], his hometown, in 2014.{{cite web|url=http://azcapitoltimes.com/news/2016/11/21/nicholas-sarwark-a-libertarian-born-and-bred-in-arizona/|title=Nicholas Sarwark: A Libertarian born and bred in Arizona – Arizona Capitol Times|first=Jeremy|last=Duda|website=azcapitoltimes.com}} Sarwark is vice president of his family's used-car dealership.{{cite web|last1=Sarward|first1=Nicholas|title=Nicholas Sarwark|url=https://www.linkedin.com/in/nicholas-sarwark-2b156/|website=LinkedIn|accessdate=10 February 2018}}{{cite web|title=Sarwark's Consolidated Auto Sales|url=http://www.consolidatedauto.com/en/about-us/our-story.cfm|website=Sarwark's Consolidated Auto Sales|publisher=Sarwark's Consolidated Auto Sales|accessdate=10 February 2018}} ==Controversies== ===Feud with Mises Institute=== Sarwark faced criticism in August 2017 when he attacked the [[Mises Institute|Ludwig von Mises Institute]] and [[Thomas E. Woods|Tom Woods]] on [[Twitter]] for reviving [[Murray Rothbard]]'s strategy to rally the [[right-wing populism|populist]] and anti-establishment [[right-wing politics|Right]] behind [[paleolibertarianism]], an [[anarcho-capitalism|anarcho-capitalist]] movement aimed at [[cultural conservatism|preserving]] traditionally [[Western culture|Western]], [[European Americans|European-American]] culture.{{cite web|url=http://www.thejacknews.com/politics/political-highlights/flame-war-tom-woods-nick-sarwark-libertarian-purge-racists/|title=Flame War Rages Between Tom Woods And Nick Sarwark Over Libertarian Party Purge of Racists|date=September 7, 2017|accessdate=October 28, 2017|work=TheJackNews}} Sarwark also criticized Woods and the Mises Institute for failing to dissociate from and denounce the support of [[far-right politics|far-right]] individuals, especially [[neo-Nazism|neo-Nazis]], after a fatal [[Unite the Right rally|white nationalist rally]] in [[Charlottesville, Virginia]].{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dqhnkzp5lN4|title=646: Nick Sarwark Talks About the LP, White Nationalism, and Tom Woods|date=August 31, 2017|accessdate=October 28, 2017}} ===Stratfor conspiracy=== In March 2018, the ''Free Thought Project'' published an article{{Cite news|url=http://thefreethoughtproject.com/libertarian-party-head-wikileaks-intelligence-assets/|title=EXCLUSIVE: Head Of Libertarian Party Named In Wikileaks List Of Secret US Intelligence Assets|date=2018-03-17|work=The Free Thought Project|access-date=2018-03-25|language=en-US}} stating that they received a tip that Nicholas Sarwark's name appeared in a list of [[Stratfor]]'s clients published by Wikileaks in 2011. It was confirmed that the address listed was one of Sarwark's family owned businesses and insinuated this proved that Sarwark had a relationship with Stratfor either as a client or informant. Sarwark stated{{Cite news|url=https://libertarianpartyofbradfordcountyfl.org/2018/03/18/nick-sarwark-caught-in-lie/|title=Commissar Nick Sarwark Digs His Hole Deeper|date=2018-03-18|work=Libertarian Party of Bradford County|access-date=2018-03-25|language=en-US}} that "The Excel spreadsheet is a list of gift memberships to Stratfor’s email newsletter. My brother-in-law bought me a one-year gift subscription for Christmas in 2008. I did not renew after it expired," which some Libertarians felt was not truthful.{{Citation needed|date=November 2018}} Reporting{{Cite news|url=https://libertarianvindicator.com/2018/03/20/nicholas-sarwark-conspiracy-theory-falls-flat/|title=Nicholas Sarwark Conspiracy Theory Falls Flat|date=2018-03-20|work=THE LIBERTARIAN VINDICATOR|access-date=2018-03-25|language=en-US}} by the Libertarian Vindicator showed that Sarwark's statement lined up with Stratfor's statement{{Cite news|url=https://www.pcworld.com/article/247028/confidential_client_list_safe_from_anonymous_says_hacker_target.html|title=Confidential Client List Safe from Anonymous, Says Hacker Target|work=PCWorld|access-date=2018-03-25|language=en}} in 2011 that what was acquired in the hack was a list of subscribers and not clients and an article{{Cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2012/02/stratfor-is-a-joke-and-so-is-wikileaks-for-taking-it-seriously/253681/|title=Stratfor Is a Joke and So Is Wikileaks for Taking It Seriously|last=Fisher|first=Max|work=The Atlantic|access-date=2018-03-25|language=en-US}} by ''[[The Atlantic]]'' stated that Stratfor's appearance as a "shadow CIA" was good marketing and is not an accurate label. ==See also== *[[Arvin Vohra]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{C-SPAN|nicholassarwark}} * [https://sarwarkforphoenix.com/ Nicholas Sarwark] for [[Mayor of Phoenix|Mayor]] of [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]] {{s-start}} {{s-ppo}} {{s-bef|before = [[Geoff Neale]]}} {{s-ttl|title = Chairman of the [[United States Libertarian Party|Libertarian National Committee]] |years = 2014-Present}} {{s-inc}} {{s-end}} {{U.S. Libertarian Party}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sarwark, Nicholas}} [[Category:1979 births]] [[Category:American automobile salespeople]] [[Category:Arizona Libertarians]] [[Category:Colorado Libertarians]] [[Category:Libertarian National Committee chairs]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Maryland Libertarians]] [[Category:People from Denver]] [[Category:Public defenders]] [[Category:Members of the Libertarian Party (United States)]] [[Category:Washington College of Law alumni]]

{{distinguish|Oroch language}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2011}} {{Infobox language |name=Orok |altname=Uilta |states=[[Russia]], [[Japan]] <!--in order of population size--> |region=[[Sakhalin Oblast]] ([[Russian Far East]]), [[Hokkaido]] |ethnicity=300 [[Orok people|Orok]] (2010 census)<ref name=e18/> |speakers=50 to 100 |date=2010 census |ref=e18 |familycolor=Altaic |fam1=[[Tungusic languages|Tungusic]] |fam2=Southern |fam3=Nanai group |script=[[Cyrillic]] |iso3=oaa |glotto=orok1265 |glottorefname=Orok }}
'''Orok''' is the Russian name for the language known by its speakers as '''Uilta''', '''Ulta''', or '''Ujlta'''. Similarly, the people are called [[Orok people|Oroks or Ulta]]. It is a [[Tungusic languages|Tungusic language]]. The language is spoken in the Poronaysky and Nogliksky [[Administrative divisions of Sakhalin Oblast|Administrative Divisions]] of [[Sakhalin Oblast]], in the [[Russian Federation]].
According to the [[Russian Census (2002)|2002 Russian census]] there were 346 Oroks living in Russia, of whom 64 were competent in Orok. By the 2010 census, that number had dropped to 47. Oroks also live on the island of [[Hokkaido]] in Japan, but the number of speakers is uncertain, and certainly small.<ref>Novikova, 1997</ref>
There are two dialects of Orok: northern (east Sakhalin) and southern (poronaysky). The variety of the language spoken on the island of Hokkaido belongs to the southern dialect.
Orok is used conversationally in everyday situations by the members of the older generation. It is also the language of oral folk literature. Oroks also speak Russian.
An alphabetic script, based on Cyrillic, was introduced in 2007. A primer has been published, and the language is taught in one school on the island of [[Sakhalin]].
==General information==
Orok is a [[Tungusic languages|Tungusic language]] that is spoken in areas of [[Sakhalin]], [[Russia]] and [[Hokkaido]], [[Japan]]. Its language code is 'oaa'. Orok is also known as Ulta, Ujlta, Uilta, and Sprache der Oroken. Currently it can be classified as a moribund or critically endangered language. The 2010 census reported 47 Orok people who are able to speak Orok competently. Furthermore, in a paper by Yoshiko Yamada in 2010, it is stated that there are 10 active speakers, 16 conditionally bilingual speakers, and 24 passive speakers who can understand with the help of Russian. The article states that "It is highly probable that the number has since decreased further."<ref name= yamada>Yamada, Yoshiko, 2010: "A Preliminary Study of Language Contacts around Uilta in Sakhalin". Hokkaido University.</ref>
==Classification==
The language of '''Orok''' is classified as a [[Tungusic languages|Tungusic language]]. More specifically, it is classified as a Southern Tungusic language and Amur Tungusic language.
==Alphabet== The [[Cyrillic script]] introduced in 2007 is:<ref>Уилтадаирису (in Russian; retrieved 2011-08-17) ({{cite web |url=http://uztranslations.net.ru/?category=tungusbooks-tungusic&altname=uiltadairisu_hovorim_po-uiltinski |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-12-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826124733/http://uztranslations.net.ru/?category=tungusbooks-tungusic&altname=uiltadairisu_hovorim_po-uiltinski |archivedate=26 August 2014 |df=dmy-all }})</ref> <!-- Аа А̄а̄ Бб Вв Гг Дд Ее Е̄е̄ Зз Ии Ӣӣ Јј Кк Лл Мм Нн Н?н? Ӈӈ Оо О̄о̄ Өө Ө̄ө̄ Пп Сс Тт Уу Ӯӯ Хх Чч Ээ Э̄э̄-->
[[File:Orok alphabet 2008.svg|500px]]
The letter "en with left hook" is contained in [[Unicode]] since version 7.0.
== Phonology ==
=== Vowels === {| class="wikitable" style=text-align:center |- ! !! [[Front vowel|Front]] !! [[Central vowel|Central]] !! [[Back vowel|Back]] |- ! [[Close vowel|Close]] |i iː||||u uː |- ! [[Mid vowel|Mid]] |ɛ ɛː, eː||ə əː |ʌ ʌː, ɔ ɔː |- ![[Open vowel|Open]] | |ɐ ɐː | |}
=== Consonants === {| class="wikitable" ! colspan="2" | ![[Bilabial consonant|Bilabial]] ![[Dental consonant|Dental]] ![[Lateral consonant|Lateral]] ![[Palatal consonant|Palatal]] ![[Velar consonant|Velar]] ![[Uvular consonant|Uvular]] |- align="center" ! rowspan="2" |[[Stop consonant|Plosive]] !<small>voiceless</small> |p |t | |tʃ |k |(q) |- align="center" !<small>voiced</small> |b |d | |dʒ |ɡ |(ɢ) |- align="center" ! rowspan="2" |[[Fricative consonant|Fricative]] !<small>voiceless</small> | |s | | |x |(χ) |- align="center" !<small>voiced</small> |β |(z) | | |(ɣ) |(ʁ) |- align="center" ! colspan="2" |[[Nasal consonant|Nasal]] |m |n | |ɲ |ŋ | |- align="center" ! colspan="2" |[[Liquid consonant|Liquid]] | |r |l |ʎ | | |- align="center" ! colspan="2" |[[Approximant consonant|Approximant]] | | | |j | | |} Consonants in parentheses indicate allophones.
== Etymology ==
The Orok language is also known as the Uilta language. While they are called the Oroks by their neighbors in the Sakhalin such as the [[Ainu people|Ainu]], [[Nivkh people|Nivkh]], Japanese, and the Russians, these people prefer ''uil'ta~ul'ta''. The word ''Uilta'' may come from the word ''ulaa'' which means 'domestic reindeer'. This makes sense as the main occupation of the Orok people is reindeer herding.<ref name=toshiro>Tsumagari, Toshiro, 2009: "Grammatical Outline of Uilta (Revised)". Hokkaido University</ref>
== Education ==
In efforts to preserve the Orok language and educate, many researchers have come up with dictionaries and lexical documentations. In 2008, the first Uilta primer was published to set a writing system and to educated local speakers of Uilta.<ref name=toshiro/>
==Geographic distribution==
The Orok/Uilta people mainly are located in the north-eastern part of Sakhalin. Orok has two dialects: Northern (east Sakhalin) and Southern (poronaysky). The geographic distribution determines which dialect is spoken. Also, the few Orok speakers in Hokkaido speak the southern dialect. "The distribution of Uilta is closely connected with their half-nomadic lifestyle, which involves reindeer herding as a subsistence economy."<ref name=yamada />
===Dialects/Varieties===
The Southern Orok people stay in the coastal Okhotsk area in the Spring and Summer, and move to the North Sakhalin plains and East Sakhalin mountains during the Fall and Winter. The Northern Orok people live near the Terpenija Bay and the Poronai River during Spring and Summer, and migrate to the East Sakhalin mountains in the Fall and Winter.
== See also == *[[Sakhalin]] *[[Orok people]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== Further reading == * Majewicz, A. F. (1989). The Oroks: past and present (pp. 124–146). Palgrave Macmillan UK. * Pilsudski, B. (1987). Materials for the study of the Orok [Uilta] language and folklore. In, Working papers / Institute of Linguistics Uniwersytet im. Adama Mickiewicza w Poznaniu. * Matsumura, K. (2002). Indigenous Minority Languages of Russia: A Bibliographical Guide. * Kazama, Shinjiro. (2003). Basic vocabulary (A) of Tungusic languages. Endangered Languages of the Pacific Rim Publications Series, A2-037. * Yamada, Yoshiko. (2010). A Preliminary Study of Language Contacts around Uilta in Sakhalin. Journal of the Center for Northern Humanities 3. 59-75. * Tsumagari, T. (2009). Grammatical Outline of Uilta (Revised). Journal of the Graduate School of Letters, 41-21. * Ikegami, J. (1994). Differences between the southern and northern dialects of Uilta. Bulletin of the Hokkaido Museum of Northern Peoples, 39-38. * Knüppel, M. (2004). Uilta Oral Literature. A Collection of Texts Translated and Annotated. Revised and Enlarged Edition . (English). Zeitschrift für Ethnologie, 129(2), 317. * Smolyak, A. B., & Anderson, G. S. (1996). Orok. Macmillan Reference USA. * Missonova, L. (2010). The emergence of Uil'ta writing in the 21st century (problems of the ethno-social life of the languages of small peoples). Etnograficheskoe Obozrenie, 1100-115. *Larisa, Ozolinya. (2013). A Grammar of Orok (Uilta). Novosibirsk Pablishing House Geo. * Janhunen, J. (2014). On the ethnonyms Orok and Uryangkhai. Studia Etymologica Cracoviensia, (19), 71. * Pevnov, A. M. (2009, March). On Some Features of Nivkh and Uilta (in Connection with Prospects of Russian-Japanese Collaboration). In サハリンの言語世界: 北大文学研究科公開シンポジウム報告書= Linguistic World of Sakhalin: Proceedings of the Symposium, September 6, 2008 (pp. 113–125). 北海道大学大学院文学研究科= Graduate School of Letters, Hokkaido University. * Ikegami, J. (1997). Uirutago jiten [A dictionary of the Uilta language spoken on Sakhalin]. * K.A. Novikova, L.I. Sem. Oroksky yazyk // Yazyki mira: Tunguso-man'chzhurskie yazyki. Moscow, 1997. (Russian)

revision.comment: Adding local [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "Point of maximum global copper production" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|Point of maximum global copper production}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} [[File:Copper - world production trend.svg|thumb|right|300px|World copper production, 1900–2012]]
'''Peak copper''' is the point in time at which the maximum global [[copper]] production rate is reached. Since copper is a finite resource, at some point in the future new production from mining will diminish, and at some earlier time production will reach a maximum. When this will occur is a matter of dispute. Unlike [[fossil fuel]]s, copper is [[scrap]]ped and reused and it has been estimated that at least 80% of all copper ever mined is still available (having been repeatedly recycled).<ref>[http://www.copperinfo.com/environment/recycling.html Copper Alliance | Our mission is to defend and grow markets for copper based on its superior technical performance and its contribution to a higher quality of life worldwide]. Copperinfo.com. Retrieved on 14 March 2014.</ref> Copper is among the most important industrial metals, valued for its heat and electrical conductivities and malleability. Copper is used in electrical power cables, data cables, electrical equipment, cooling and refrigeration tubing, [[heat exchangers]], [[brass]] casing small arms [[ammunition]], water pipes, and [[jewellery]].{{cn|date=December 2016}}
Copper has been used at least 10,000 years. More than 97% of all copper ever mined and smelted has been extracted since 1900. The increased demand for copper due to the growing Indian and Chinese economies since 2006 has led to increased prices and an increase in [[Metal theft|copper theft]].<ref name=Leonard2006>{{cite web |url=http://www.salon.com/2006/03/02/peak_copper/ |title=Peak copper? |work=Salon|author=Leonard, Andrew |date=2 March 2006 |accessdate=23 March 2008}}</ref>
==History== Concern about the copper supply is not new. In 1924 geologist and copper-mining expert [[Ira Joralemon]] warned: :"... the age of electricity and of copper will be short. At the intense rate of production that must come, the copper supply of the world will last hardly a score of years. ... Our civilization based on electrical power will dwindle and die."<ref>{{cite journal|title=Copper and electricity to vanish in twenty years?|journal=Engineering and Mining Journal|date=26 July 1924|volume=118|issue=4|pages=122}}</ref>
==Copper demand== Total world production is about 18 million [[metric ton]]s per year.<ref>[http://minerals.usgs.gov/minerals/pubs/commodity/copper/ Copper Statistics and Information, Mineral Commodity Summaries, 2014], USGS{{nonspecific|date=October 2017}}</ref> Copper demand is increasing by more than 575,000 tons annually and accelerating.<ref name=Leonard2006/> Based on 2006 figures for per capita consumption, Tom Graedel and colleagues at Yale University calculate that by 2100 global demand for copper will outstrip the amount extractable from the ground.<!-- (Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, vol 103, p 1209) --><ref name=Cohen2007>{{cite journal |url=http://www.science.org.au/nova/newscientist/027ns_005.htm?id=mg19426051.200&print=true |title=Earth's natural wealth: an audit |issue=2605 |pages=34–41 |journal=[[New Scientist]] |author=David Cohen |date=23 May 2007 |accessdate=9 April 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080720095945/http://www.science.org.au/nova/newscientist/027ns_005.htm?id=mg19426051.200&print=true |archivedate=20 July 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> China accounted for more than 22% of world copper demand in 2008,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/mar/20/internationalcrime |title=Deaths and disruption as price rise sees copper thefts soar |work=[[The Guardian]] |author1=Glaister, Dan |author2=Branigan, Tania |author3=Bowcott, Owen |lastauthoramp=yes |date=20 March 2008 |accessdate=9 April 2008}}</ref> and is nearly 40% in 2014.
For some purposes, other metals can substitute, [[aluminium wire]] was substituted in many applications, but improper design resulted in fire hazards.<ref>http://www.cpsc.gov//PageFiles/118856/516.pdf</ref> The safety issues have since been solved by use of larger sizes of aluminium wire (#8AWG and up), and properly designed aluminium wiring is still being installed in place of copper. For example, the [[Airbus A380]] uses aluminum wire in place of copper wire for electrical power transmission.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://spectrum.ieee.org/aerospace/aviation/manufacturing-mayday |title=Manufacturing Mayday: Production glitches send Airbus into a tailspin |work=[[IEEE Spectrum]] |author=Hellemans, Alexander |date=1 January 2007 |accessdate=19 June 2014}}</ref> <!-- ===Population increase=== --> <!-- ===Electrification=== -->
==Copper supply== [[File:2012copper (mined).svg|thumb|300px|right]] Globally, economic copper resources are being depleted with the equivalent production of three world-class copper mines being consumed annually.<ref name=Leonard2006/> Environmental analyst [[Lester Brown]] suggested in 2008 that copper might run out within 25 years based on what he considered a reasonable extrapolation of 2% growth per year.<ref name="Brown">{{cite book |author=Brown, Lester |title=Plan B 2.0: Rescuing a Planet Under Stress and a Civilization in Trouble |publisher=W.W. Norton |year=2006|location=New York|page=109 |isbn=0-393-32831-7}}</ref>
===New copper discoveries=== Fifty-six new copper discoveries have been made during the three decades 1975–2005.<ref name=Leonard2006/> World discoveries of new copper deposits are said to have peaked in 1996.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.silverseek.com/CharlestonVoice/1135873932.php |title=Peak Copper Means Peak Silver |work=Charleston Voice |date=29 December 2005 |accessdate=9 April 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131104020042/http://news.silverseek.com/CharlestonVoice/1135873932.php |archivedate=4 November 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> However, according to the US Geological Survey (USGS), remaining world copper reserves have more than doubled since then, from 310 million metric tons in 1996<ref>US Geological Survey, [http://minerals.usgs.gov/minerals/pubs/commodity/copper/240397.pdf Mineral commodity summaries], 1997, p.53.</ref> to 690 million metric tons in 2013.<ref>US Geological Survey, [http://minerals.usgs.gov/minerals/pubs/commodity/copper/mcs-2014-coppe.pdf Mineral commodity summaries], 1997, p.49.</ref>
===Production=== {{see also|List of countries by copper production}} [[File:Top 5 Copper Producers.png|thumb|Production trends in the top five copper-producing nations]]
As shown in the table below, the three chief national producers of copper, respectively, in 2002, were Chile, Indonesia, and the [[Copper mining in the United States|United States]]. In 2013, they were Chile, China, and Peru. Twenty-one of the 28 largest copper mines in the world are not amenable to expansion.<ref name=Leonard2006/> Many large copper mines will be exhausted between 2010 and 2015.<ref name=Leonard2006/>
{| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:right" |- |+ Copper production (thousands tonnes)<ref name=USGS2004>{{cite web |url=http://minerals.usgs.gov/minerals/pubs/commodity/copper/coppemcs04.pdf |title=pg. 54 – Copper |publisher=[[USGS]] |year=2004 |format=PDF |accessdate=9 April 2008}}</ref><ref name=USGS2006>{{cite web |url=http://minerals.usgs.gov/minerals/pubs/commodity/copper/coppemcs06.pdf |title=pg. 56 – Copper |publisher=[[USGS]] |year=2006 |format=PDF |accessdate=9 April 2008}}</ref><ref name=USGS2008>{{cite web |url=http://minerals.usgs.gov/minerals/pubs/commodity/copper/mcs-2008-coppe.pdf |title=pg. 54 – Copper |publisher=[[USGS]] |year=2008 |format=PDF |accessdate=9 April 2008}}</ref><ref name=USGS2010>{{cite web |url=http://minerals.usgs.gov/minerals/pubs/commodity/copper/mcs-2010-coppe.pdf |title=pg. 49 – Copper |publisher=[[USGS]] |year=2010 |format=PDF |accessdate=15 July 2012}}</ref><ref name=USGS2011>{{cite web |url=http://minerals.usgs.gov/minerals/pubs/commodity/copper/mcs-2011-coppe.pdf |title=pg. 49 – Copper |publisher=[[USGS]] |year=2011 |format=PDF |accessdate=29 March 2015}}</ref><ref name=USGS2012>{{cite web |url=http://minerals.usgs.gov/minerals/pubs/commodity/copper/mcs-2012-coppe.pdf |title=pg. 49 – Copper |publisher=[[USGS]] |year=2012 |format=PDF |accessdate=15 July 2012}}</ref><ref name=USGS2013>{{cite web |url=http://minerals.usgs.gov/minerals/pubs/commodity/copper/mcs-2013-coppe.pdf |title=pg. 49 – Copper |publisher=[[USGS]] |year=2013 |format=PDF |accessdate=29 March 2015}}</ref><ref name=USGS2014>{{cite web |url=http://minerals.usgs.gov/minerals/pubs/commodity/copper/mcs-2014-coppe.pdf |title=pg. 48 16,100 ! 16,100 ! 16,100 ! 16,900 ! 18,200 ! 18,400 ! 19,100 |}
===Reserves=== Copper is a [[Abundance of elements in Earth's crust|fairly common]] element, with an estimated concentration of 50–70 ppm (0.005–0.007 percent) in earth's crust (1 kg of copper per 15–20 tons of crustal rock).<ref name=emsley>{{cite book|author=Emsley, John|title=Nature's building blocks: an A–Z guide to the elements|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=j-Xu07p3cKwC&pg=PA123|year=2003|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-850340-8|pages=121–125}}</ref> A concentration of 60 ppm would multiply out to 1.66 quadrillion [[tonne]]s over the 2.77e22 kg mass of the crust,<ref>American Geophysical Union, Fall Meeting 2007, abstract #V33A-1161. [http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2007AGUFM.V33A1161P Mass and Composition of the Continental Crust]</ref> or over 90 million years' worth at the 2013 production rate of 18.3 MT per year. However, most of it cannot be extracted profitably at the current level of technology and the current market value. At the present time, copper deposits are considered potentially profitable if they are located sufficiently close to the surface and they contain at least 0.3–0.5 percent copper.{{Citation needed|date=November 2009}}
The USGS reported a current total reserve base of copper in potentially recoverable ores of 1.6 billion tonnes as of 2005, of which 950 million tonnes were considered economically recoverable.<ref name=Biello2006>{{cite news |url=http://www.sciam.com/article.cfm?id=measure-of-metal-supply-f |title=Measure of Metal Supply Finds Future Shortage |work=[[Scientific American]] |author=Biello, David|date=17 January 2006 |accessdate=23 March 2008}}</ref> A 2013 global assessment identified "455 known deposits (with well-defined identified resources) that contain about 1.8 billion metric tons of copper", and predicted "a mean of 812 undiscovered deposits within the uppermost kilometer of the earth's surface" containing another 3.1 billion metric tons of copper "which represents about 180 times 2012 global copper production from all types of copper deposits."<ref name=Hammarstrom2013>{{cite news |url=https://gsa.confex.com/gsa/2013AM/webprogram/Paper226200.html |title=Undiscovered Porphyry Copper Resources—A Global Assessment |work=[[The Geological Society of America: Annual Meeting & Expo]] |author=Hammarstrom, Jane M. |date=29 October 2013 |accessdate=12 April 2014}}</ref>

Country ! 1996 Reserves ! Percent ! 2015 Reserves ! Percent |- | style="text-align:left;"| {{flag|Chile}} | 88,000 | 28.4% | 209,000 | 29.9% |- | style="text-align:left;"| {{flag|Australia}} | 7,000 | 2.26% | 93,000 | 13.2% |- | style="text-align:left;"| {{flag|Peru}} | 7,000 | 2.26% | 68,000 | 9.71% |- | style="text-align:left;"| {{flag|Mexico}} | N/A | N/A | 38,000 | 5.43% |- | style="text-align:left;"| {{flag|United States}} | 45,000 | 14.5% | 35,000 | 5.00% |- | style="text-align:left;"| {{flag|China}} | 3,000 | 0.968% | 30,000 | 4.29% |- | style="text-align:left;"| {{flag|Russia}} | 20,000 | 6.45% | 30,000 | 4.29% |- | style="text-align:left;"| {{flag|Poland}} | 20,000 | 6.45% | 28,000 | 4.00% |- | style="text-align:left;"| {{flag|Indonesia}} | 11,000 | 3.55% | 25,000 | 3.57% |- | style="text-align:left;"| {{flag|Congo-Kinshasa}} | N/A | N/A | 20,000 | 2.86% |- | style="text-align:left;"| {{flag|Zambia}} | 12,000 | 3.87% | 20,000 | 2.86% |- | style="text-align:left;"| {{flag|Canada}} | 11,000 | 3.55% | 11,000 | 1.57% |- | style="text-align:left;"| {{flag|Kazakhstan}} | 14,000 | 4.52% | 6,000 | 0.86% |- | style="text-align:left;"| {{flag|Zaire}} | 11,000 | 3.55% | N/A | N/A |- | style="text-align:left;"| {{flag|Philippines}} | 7,000 | 2.26% | N/A | N/A |- | style="text-align:left;"| ''Other countries'' | 55,000 | 17.7% | 90,000 | 12.9% |- ! style="text-align:left;"| {{noflag}}''[[World]]'' ! 310,000 ! 100% ! 700,000 ! 100% |}
====Known conventional resources==== ====Recycling==== In the US, more copper is recovered and put back into service from recycled material than is derived from newly-mined ore. Copper's recycle value is so great that premium-grade scrap normally has at least 95% of the value of primary metal from newly mined ore.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.copper.org/education/history/g_fact_future.html |title=Copper in the USA: Bright Future – Glorious Past |publisher=[[Copper Development Association]] |accessdate=9 April 2008}}</ref>
{{Asof|2011}}, recycled copper provided 35% of total worldwide copper usage.<ref>International Copper Study Group, [http://www.icsg.org/index.php/component/jdownloads/finish/170/1188 World Copper Factbook 2013], p.50.</ref>
====Undiscovered conventional resources==== Based on discovery rates and existing geologic surveys, researchers estimated in 2006 that 1.6 billion metric tons of copper could be brought into use. This figure relied on the broadest possible definition of available copper as well as a lack of energy constraints and environmental concerns.<ref name=Biello2006/>
The US Geological Survey estimated that, as of 2013, there remained 3.5 billion metric tons of undiscovered copper resources worldwide in porphyry and sediment-hosted type deposits, two types which currently provide 80% of mined copper production. This was in addition to 2.1 billion metric tons of identified resources. Combined identified and estimated undiscovered copper resources were 5.6 billion metric tons,<ref>Kathleen M. Johnson and others, [http://pubs.usgs.gov/fs/2014/3004/pdf/fs2014-3004.pdf Estimate of undiscovered copper resources of the world, 2013], US Geological Survey, Fact Sheet 2014–3004, Jan. 2014.</ref> 306 times the 2013 global production of newly mined copper of 18.3 million metric tons.
===Unconventional resources=== Deep-sea nodules are estimated to contain 700 million tonnes of copper.<ref name=USGS2008/>
==Politics==
===Chile=== Chile is the world's largest copper producer, and in 2007 accounted for 37% of the world's primary copper production. One researcher wrongfully claimed that Chilean copper production would begin to decline irreversibly in 2008.<ref name=Leonard2006/> This was contradicted by the Chilean Copper Commission, which projected that, based on planned expansion projects, Chilean copper production will continue to increase through at least 2012.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20080516051205/http://www.icsg.org/conferences/Sep_06_meeting_Cochilco_Presentation.pdf Chilean Copper Commission (Sept. 2006): ''Current and future situation of the copper industry in Chile'']. icsg.org</ref>
===Zaire=== In [[Zaire]], copper production fell 90% from 1976 (502,000 tons) to wartime 1993 (50,000 tons). Resumption depends on political factors.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.africa.upenn.edu/Hornet/irin_2277.html |title=Zaire: IRIN Briefing Part II |publisher=[[University Of Pennsylvania]] |date=27 February 1997 |accessdate=9 April 2008}}</ref><!--
==World peak copper== ---> <!-- ===Pessimistic predictions of future copper production=== ---> <!-- ===Optimistic predictions of future copper production=== ---> <!-- ==Possible effects and consequences of Peak copper==
--->
==Copper prices== [[File:Copper Price History USD.png|250px|thumb|Copper [[metric ton]] prices 1986 – early-2011 in US$, showing 2008's price collapse]]
The international price of copper struck a first peak level on 6 March 2008, on the [[London Metal Exchange]] (LME), surging 5.8% over the previous trading day to {{USD}}4.02 per pound. The previous record was set on 12 May 2006, at US$3.98/lb. The price increased rapidly in early-2008, rising 23% in February 2008,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-03/08/content_7744648.htm |title=International copper price hits record high |publisher=China View |date=8 March 2008 |accessdate=9 April 2008}}</ref> then declined 40% before December 2008,<ref>Jha, Dilip Kumar (30 November 2008) [http://www.business-standard.com/india/news/falling-demand-may-dent-base-metal-prices/00/48/341701/ Falling demand may dent base metal prices]. ''Business Standard''</ref> and reached US$1.30 by year's end.<ref>[http://charts3.barchart.com/chart.asp?sym=HGZ8&data=A&jav=adv&vol=Y&divd=Y&evnt=adv&grid=Y&code=BSTK&org=stk&fix= $1.30 price]. Charts3.barchart.com. Retrieved on 14 March 2014.</ref> In February 2011 the price peaked at US$4.58/lb<ref>[http://www.lme.com/copper.asp London Metal Exchange: Copper]. LME.com. Retrieved on 14 March 2014.</ref> but then fell to US$3.18/lb during 2013.
<!-- ===Substitutes=== ---> <!-- ==Historical understanding of world copper supply limits== ---> ==Criticism== [[Julian Lincoln Simon|Julian Simon]] was a senior fellow at the [[Cato Institute]] and a professor of business and economics. In his book ''[[The Ultimate Resource|The Ultimate Resource 2]]'' (first printed in 1981 and reprinted in 1998), he extensively criticizes the notion of "peak resources", and uses copper as one example. He argues that, even though "peak copper" has been a persistent scare since the early 20th century, "known reserves" grew at a rate that outpaced demand, and the price of copper was not rising but falling over the long run. For example, even though world production of copper in 1950 was only one-eighth of what it was in early-2000s, known reserves were also much lower at the time – around 100 million metric tons – making it appear that the world would run out of copper in 40 to 50 years at most.
Simon's own explanation for this development is that the very notion of known reserves is deeply flawed,<ref>Simon, Julian (16 February 1998) [http://www.juliansimon.com/writings/Ultimate_Resource/TCHAR12.txt Chapt 12, "People, Materials, and Environment"] in ''The Ultimate Resource II''.</ref> as it does not take into account changes in mining profitability. As richer mines are exhausted, developers turn their attention to poorer sources of the element and eventually develop cheap methods of extracting it, raising known reserves. Thus, for example, copper was so abundant 5000 years ago, occurring in pure form as well as in highly concentrated copper ores, that prehistoric peoples were able to collect and process it with very basic technology. As of the early 21st century, copper is commonly mined from ores that contain 0.3% to 0.6% copper by weight. Yet, despite the material being far less widespread, the cost of, for example, a copper pot was vastly lower in the late 20th century than 5000 years ago.<ref>Simon, Julian (16 February 1998) [http://www.juliansimon.com/writings/Ultimate_Resource/ ''The Ultimate Resource II'']</ref>
Simon essentially states that not all viable copper has been discovered and that not all technological advancements in mining and refining have occurred, so statements that the point of peak copper has been or will be reached must be false. Simon supports his argument by showing that copper supplies have increased and prices have fallen. Simon's thesis of peak resources is not based on current scientific analysis or geological measurements, but the analysis of historical trends and the assumption that they can and will continue.
==See also== * [[2000s commodities boom]] * [[Hubbert peak theory]] * [[List of copper alloys]] * [[Mineral resource classification]] * [[Peak minerals]]

B. Gordon*, M. Bertram and T. E. Graedel |journal=[[Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences]] |publisher= [[United States National Academy of Sciences|U.S. National Academy of Sciences]] |date=31 January 2006 |pages= 1209–1214 |volume=103 |doi=10.1073/pnas.0509498103 |issue=5 |pmid=16432205 |pmc=1360560|bibcode = 2006PNAS..103.1209G }}

{{Infobox FBI Ten Most Wanted | name = Robert Francis Van Wisse | image0 = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | charge = [[Unlawful Flight to Avoid Prosecution]] - [[Murder]] | reward = Up to $100,000 | alias = Francisco Salas, Roberto Francisco Salas, Robert F. Vanwisse, Robert Wisse, Robert F. Van Wisse, Robert Francis Vanwise, Robert Vanwisse | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1965|2|03}} | birth_place = [[Guadalajara]], [[Mexico]] | death_date = | death_place = | cause = | nationality = Mexican | ethnicity = White (Hispanic) | gender = Male | height = {{height|ft=5|in=6}} | weight = {{convert|180|lb|kg|abbr=on}} | occupation = [[Teaching English as a foreign language|English teacher]] in Mexico, possibly a medical or agricultural worker | parents = | siblings = | spouse = | children = | conviction = Murder | conviction_penalty = 30 years in prison | conviction_status = | added_date = December 13, 2016 | caught_date = | remove_date = | surrendered_date = January 26, 2017 | number = 511 | status = Surrendered }} '''Robert Francis Van Wisse''' (born February 3, 1965)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fbi.gov/news/stories/new-top-ten-fugitive-terry-ad-strickland|title=Wanted by the FBI: New Top Ten Fugitive Robert Francis Van Wisse|publisher=FBI|accessdate=December 19, 2016}}</ref> is an American criminal who was added to the [[FBI Ten Most Wanted Fugitives]] list in December 2016, in relation to a sexual assault and murder in [[Austin, Texas]] in September 1983. In January 2017, he surrendered to U.S. officials. On March 28, 2017, Van Wisse pled guilty to murder and was sentenced to 30 years in prison.
==Crime== On September 19, 1983, Laurie Stout, who owned a janitorial service in Austin with her husband, went into a building which she was hired to clean. Her body was found at 8:30 am the following morning in the second floor men's bathroom where she was working. She had been sexually assaulted and murdered.<ref name="upi">{{cite news|last1=Stephen|first1=Feller|title=Fugitive on FBI 'most wanted' list for '83 Texas murder surrenders|url=https://www.upi.com/Top_News/US/2017/01/26/Fugitive-on-FBI-most-wanted-list-for-83-Texas-murder-surrenders/1341485478428/|accessdate=18 September 2017|work=UPI|publisher=United Press International, Inc.|date=26 January 2017|language=en}}</ref> The [[Austin Police Department]] later ruled Stout’s death was a homicide due to strangulation and [[asphyxia]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Staff|title=FBI: Man wanted in strangling of Austin mother more than 30 years ago|url=https://cw39.com/2016/12/13/fbi-man-wanted-in-strangling-death-of-austin-mother-more-than-30-years-ago/|accessdate=18 September 2017|work=CW39 NewsFix|publisher=KIAH • A TRIBUNE BROADCASTING STATION|date=13 December 2016|language=en}}</ref>
Everyone who was in the building that evening was questioned, including 18-year-old Van Wisse, who was late registering for a class at the [[University of Texas]] at the time. He was given [[fingerprinting]] and [[DNA testing]], and ruled out as a suspect at the time due to the under developed DNA technology in 1983.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Catherine|first1=Townsend|title=Texas Man Charged With Strangling Young Mother To Death In 1983 Makes FBI's Ten Most Wanted List - CrimeFeed|url=http://crimefeed.com/2016/12/27437/|website=CrimeFeed|publisher=Discovery Communications, LLC.|accessdate=18 September 2017|language=en|date=20 December 2016}}</ref>
===Cold case investigation=== In 1992, an investigator was hired to reopen the cold case. She found that the 1983 testing of Van Wisse's DNA was misleading due to outdated technology, and after reevaluation he was determined to be the prime suspect.<ref name="kxan" />
On October 3, 1996, a state arrest warrant was issued for Van Wisse in [[Travis County, Texas]], after he was charged in Stout's murder. On March 6, 1997, Van Wisse was also charged with unlawful flight to avoid prosecution and a Federal arrest warrant was issued for Van Wisse by the [[United States District Court]] in Austin.<ref>{{cite news|title=Former UT student linked to 1983 killing added to FBI Most Wanted list|url=http://www.kvue.com/news/local/former-ut-student-linked-to-1983-killing-added-to-fbi-list/369490807|accessdate=18 September 2017|work=KVUE-ABC|publisher=KVUE-TV, A TEGNA Company|date=14 December 2016}}</ref> On December 13, 2016, Van Wisse became the 511th person added to the FBI Ten Most Wanted Fugitives list, with a $100,000 reward.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fbi.gov/wanted/topten/robert-francis-van-wisse|title=Van Wisse's FBI Top 10 Most Wanted Fugitive Alert|publisher=FBI|accessdate=December 18, 2016}}</ref><ref name="kxan">{{cite news|last1=Bien|first1=Calily|last2=Glas|first2=Brittany|title=1983 Austin murder suspect added to FBI's Top 10 Most Wanted list|url=http://kxan.com/2016/12/13/fbi-in-austin-looking-for-texans-on-top-10-most-wanted-list/|accessdate=December 18, 2016|work=KXAN}}</ref> On January 26, 2017, he surrendered to U.S. officials in [[Laredo, Texas]] at the Mexican border.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Villalpando|first1=Roberto|last2=Hall|first2=Katie|title=Fugitive in 1983 Austin cold case surrenders to authorities|url=http://www.statesman.com/news/local/fugitive-1983-austin-cold-case-surrenders-authorities/LscSphQPN5cpUDNHzexFlK/|accessdate=January 27, 2017|work=Austin American-Statesman|publisher=Nexstar Broadcasting|date=January 26, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=CRIMESIDER STAFF|title=FBI "10 Most Wanted" fugitive, wanted in 1983 slaying, turns self in|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/robert-van-wisse-fbi-10-most-wanted-fugitive-wanted-in-1983-slaying-turns-self-in/|accessdate=18 September 2017|work=CBS/AP|publisher=CBS Interactive Inc.|date=27 January 2017|location=AUSTIN, Texas|language=en}}</ref>
On March 28, 2017, Van Wisse pled guilty to murder and was sentenced to 30 years in prison. His attorney said that plea deal negotiations were started before Van Wisse turned himself in.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bien|first1=Calily|title=Austin man who was on FBI’s Most Wanted gets 30 years for murder|url=http://kxan.com/2017/03/28/austin-man-who-was-on-fbis-most-wanted-gets-30-years-for-murder/|accessdate=April 14, 2017|work=KXAN|publisher=Nexstar Broadcasting|date=March 28, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Claiborne|first1=Casey|title=Van Wisse pleads guilty in 1983 murder of Laurie Stout|url=http://www.fox7austin.com/news/local-news/van-wisse-pleads-guilty-in-1983-murder-of-laurie-stout|accessdate=18 September 2017|work=KTBC|agency=Fox News|publisher=Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc.|date=28 March 2017|language=en}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2015}} {{Use Indian English|date=March 2015}} The '''SEC Classification''' is the classification of Indian consumers on the basis of parameters. Traditionally the two parameters used to categorize consumers were: Occupation and Education of the chief wage earner (Head) of the households.The SEC classification,created in 1988, was ratified by Market Research Society of India (MRSI), is used by most media researchers and brand managers to understand the Indian consuming class.Originally developed by [[IMRB International]] as a way of understanding [[market segment]]s, and [[consumer behavior]] it was standardized and adopted by the Market Research Society of India in the mid-1980s as a measure of socio-economic class and is now commonly used as a [[market segmentation]] tool in India.
In the older version,the SEC Classification consists of two grids-
* The [[urban area|Urban]] SEC Grid, which uses [[Literacy|Education]] levels and [[Job (role)|Occupational]] criteria of the Chief Wage Earner (CWE) of a household as measures to determine socio-economic classification, and segments urban India into 7 groups (A1 to E2) and * The [[Rural]] SEC Grid, which uses [[Literacy|Education]] and Type of House (pucca, semi-pucca, and katcha) as measures of socio-economic class, and segments rural India into 4 groups (R1,R2,R3,R4)
This is based on the assumption that higher education leads to higher income thus higher consuming potential. But we know that this may not be true always. A trader or a retailer with no qualification can earn more income than a Post graduate executive, but SEC will categorize the traders/retailers not as SEC A1or A2.
So, in order to combat this problem, the Government came up with the new SEC system on 3 May 2011.
'''The new SEC system is based on two variables:'''
'''1. Education of the Chief Earner.''' The options are Illiterate, Literate but no formal schooling or Schooling unto 4 years, Schooling between 5–9 years, High School pass, Some college (including a diploma but not a graduate), Graduate / Post Graduate (General), Graduate / Post Graduate (Professional)
'''2. The number of Consumer durables(pre-decided from a list of 11 items) owned by the family'''. The list of 11 items are: Electricity Connection, Ceiling Fan, LPG Stove, Two Wheeler, Color TV, Refrigerator, Washing Machine, Personal Computer/Laptop, Car/Jeep/Van, Air Conditioner, Agricultural Land
There are 12 grades in the new system starting from A1 to E3.
These grids are used to determine the consumption preferences, and purchasing power of households, and are common tools used by social and business researchers working in India. The SEC grid does not use family income levels as a measure as this data is hard to collect and it has been demonstrated that education levels and occupation criteria in India are better determinants of consumer preference. The methodology used in these tools differs from the [[Household Potential Index]], which measures consumption intensity.
==Urban SEC Grid (old version)==
{| class="wikitable" |-gkk but not graduate!! Graduate/Postgraduate general!! Graduate/Post Graduate professional |- |Skilled Workers|| E2|| E1|| D|| C|| C|| B2|| B2 |- | Petty traders|| E2|| D|| D|| C|| C|| B1|| B2 |- | Shop Owners|| D|| D|| C|| B2|| B1|| A2||A2 |- | Businessmen with No employees|| D|| C|| B2|| B1|| A2|| A2|| A1 |- | Businessmen with 1-9 employees|| C|| B2|| B2|| B1|| A2|| A1|| A1 |- | Businessmen with 10+ employees|| B1|| B1|| A2|| A|| A1|| A1|| A1 |- | Self Employed professional|| D|| D|| D|| B|| B|| A|| A |- | Clerical/Salesman|| D|| D|| D|| C|| B2|| B|| B |- | Supervisory Level|| D|| D|| C|| C|| B2|| B1|| A2 |- | Officers/Executives-Junior|| C|| C|| C|| B2|| B1|| A2|| A2 |- | Officers/Executives-Mid/Senior|| B1|| B1|| B1|| B1|| A2|| A1|| A1 |}
It divides the population into 3 classes:
* Upper most segment of the consuming class-A1,A2 and B1 * Middle segment- B2 and C * The lower most segment—D, E1, and E2..
==References== *http://readbetweentheps.blogspot.com/2005/09/socio-economic-classification-are-we.html *http://www.mrsi.in/whatismrsi.html

page.title: Socioeconomic development and the Bahá'í Faith

revision.text:
[[File:Tarbiyat School, Tehran, ca 1911.jpg|thumb|upright=1.25|right|Students of ''School for Girls'', Tehran, 13 August 1933. The school was closed by government decree in 1934. <ref>[http://denial.bahai.org/003.php ''History of Bahá'í Educational Efforts in Iran''].</ref>]] Since its inception the [[Bahá'í Faith]] has had involvement in [[socioeconomic development]] beginning by giving greater freedom to women,<ref name="iranhistory">{{cite web | last = Momen | first = Moojan|authorlink= Moojan Momen | title = History of the Baha'i Faith in Iran | work = draft "A Short Encyclopedia of the Baha'i Faith" | publisher = Bahai-library.com | url =http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_iran#9.%20Social%20and%20economic%20development | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2009-10-16}}</ref> promulgating the promotion of female education as a priority concern,<ref>{{cite journal | last = Kingdon | first = Geeta Gandhi | title = Education of women and socioeconomic development | journal = Baha'i Studies Review | volume = 7 | issue = 1 | year = 1997 | url =http://bahai-library.com/kingdon_education_women_development }}</ref> and that involvement was given practical expression by creating schools, agricultural coops, and clinics.<ref name="iranhistory"/> Current development activities are related to areas such as education, health, agriculture, arts and media, the local economy and the advancement of women. By 2017 there were an estimated 40,000 small scale projects, 1,400 sustained projects, and 135 Bahá'í inspired organizations.<ref name="betterment">Bahá’í Office of Social and Economic Development (2018). ''[http://www.bahai.org/documents/osed/betterment-world.pdf?a28125bc For the Betterment of the World: The Worldwide Bahá'í Community's Approach to Social and Economic Development]''.</ref>
==Historical development== The accelerated growth of the worldwide community in the 1960s-1980s expanded it with a large number of poor, illiterate villagers and tribal peoples in India, Africa and South America, which meant an enormous challenge for the social and economic development of communities. According to the [[Bahá'í teachings]], development should increase people’s self-reliance, communal solidarity, giving access to knowledge, and, where possible, removing sources of injustice. Spiritual, moral and material development should be linked together.<ref name="momen-2007">{{cite encyclopedia |last= Momen |first= Moojan|authorlink= Moojan Momen |encyclopedia= New Lion Handbook: The World's Religions |title= The Bahá’í Faith |year= 2007 |publisher= Lion Hudson Plc |location= Oxford |isbn= 978-0-7459-5266-6 |page=464}}</ref> These priorities are envisioned as crucial to the development of world peace.
The religion entered a new phase of activity when a message of the [[Universal House of Justice]] dated 20 October 1983 was released.<ref name="survey">{{cite journal |title= The Baha'i Faith 1957–1988: A Survey of Contemporary Developments | first = Moojan | last = Momen |authorlink= Moojan Momen|author2=Smith, Peter | year = 1989 | url = http://bahai-library.com/momen_smith_developments_1957-1988 |volume = 19 | journal = Religion | pages=63–91 |doi= 10.1016/0048-721X(89)90077-8}}</ref><ref>[[Universal House of Justice]] (20 October 1983). ''[http://www.bahai.org/library/authoritative-texts/the-universal-house-of-justice/messages/#d=19831020_001&f=f1-2 To the Bahá’ís of the World]''.</ref> The Office of Social and Economic Development was established<ref>{{Cite book | last = Smith | first = Peter| authorlink= Peter Smith (historian) | title = An Introduction to the Baha'i Faith | publisher = Cambridge University Press | year = 2008 | url = http://www.cambridge.org/catalogue/catalogue.asp?isbn=9780521862516&ss=fro | isbn = 978-0-521-86251-6}}</ref> and Bahá'ís were urged to seek out ways, compatible with the Bahá'í teachings, in which they could become involved in the social and economic development of the communities in which they lived. Worldwide in 1979 there were 129 officially recognized Bahá'í socioeconomic development projects. By 1987, the number of officially recognized development projects had increased to 1482.<ref name="survey" />
In time with the release of the Universal House of Justice's release of its statement ''[[The Promise of World Peace]]'', it also sent a letter of all national assemblies to specify goals for the community for the [[International Year of Peace]].<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Make plans now for 'Peace Year 1986'|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1985 | number = 648|ISSN=0195-9212 | page =1 |url = }}</ref> These goals included sponsoring activities about the theme of peace which is a priority of the religion: to engage the attention of people to relevant topics related to peace (often related matters of justice and development) and the [[Bahá'í Faith and the unity of humanity|unity of humanity]].
==Current situation== The Bahá'ís around the world are currently being encouraged to focus on capacity building through activities such as spiritual education of children, a youth empowerment program, [[Bahá'í study circle|study circles]], and devotional gatherings.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |last=Gervais |first=Marie |date=2008 |title=Baha’i Faith and Peace Education |encyclopedia=Encyclopedia of Peace Education |publisher=Teachers College, Columbia University |location=New York |url=http://www.tc.columbia.edu/epe/epe-entries/GervaisBahaiFaith_22feb08.pdf |format=PDF |access-date=3 May 2018 |ref=harv |df=dmy}}</ref> For most of these activities, material developed by the [[Ruhi Institute]] is used.<ref name=Blosson&Kaye>{{cite journal |author1= Rosemary Blosson |author2=Sylvia B Kaye | title =Learning by Doing: Preparation of Baha'i Nonformal Tutors | journal =New Directions for Adult and Continuing Education | volume =2012 | issue =133 | pages =45–57 | date =March 14, 2012 | url =http://eric.ed.gov/?id=EJ978367 | doi =10.1002/ace.20006}}</ref> Initiatives of social action include activities in areas like health, sanitation, education, gender equality, arts and media, agriculture, and the environment.<ref name="betterment" /> Educational projects include schools, which range from village tutorial schools to large secondary schools, and some universities.<ref name="momen-2007" />
==Statistics== In November 1986, the Baha'i department of statistics released the following summary of projects accomplished:<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Baha'i Social and Economic Development Programs|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=November 1986 | number = 668|ISSN=0195-9212 | page =13 |url =https://bahai.works/index.php?title=File:Baha%27i_News_668.pdf&page=15 }}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" border="1" ! Programs !! World!! Africa !!Americas!!Asia!!Australasia!!Europe |- | Education (tutorial/academic/other) || 732||169 || 115||427 || 13||8 |- | Health and social services || 78||28 || 14||25 || 2||9 |- | Radio stations || 5||0 || 5||0 || 0||0 |- | Agriculture and forestry || 74||35 || 13||20 || 5||1 |- | Community development || 358||60 || 266||12 || 7||13 |- | Total || 1247||292 || 413||484 || 27||31 |}
In April 2018, the Bahá'í Office of Social and Economic Development released the following conservative estimates, based on provided by national Bahá’í institutions.<ref name="betterment" /> {| class="wikitable" border="1" ! Bahá'í Development Activities Worldwide!! 1996!! 2001 !! 2006 !! 2011 !! 2017 |- | Activities of fixed duration || >1,300 || >2,400 || >7,000 || >18,000 || >40,000 |- | Sustained projects || >250 || >500 || >650 || >1,100 || >1,400 |- | Bahá'í inspired organizations || 39 || 62 || 83 || 118 || 135 |}
==Some particular examples== * The [[Bahá'í International Community]], an international non-governmental organization, maintains a presence devoted to supporting and coordinating socioeconomic development activities at the United Nations as well as presenting papers and reports of activities of the religion to UN agencies on themes of development and peace.<ref> * [http://www.bic.org/statements/preparation-life-peace-contribution-women Preparation for Life in Peace: The Contribution of Women], by the Bahá'í International Community, as the written version of an oral statement to the European Regional Seminar for the International Year of Peace, 6 May 1985, Vienna, Austria * [http://www.bic.org/statements/peace-and-development Peace and Development], by the Bahá'í International Community, as a Statement to the United Nations International Year of Peace Seminar for the Asia and Pacific and Western Asia Regions, 20 May 1985, Bangkok, Thailand * [http://www.bic.org/statements/preparation-life-peace-role-youth Preparation for Life in Peace: The Role of Youth], by the Bahá'í International Community as a Statement to the International Year of Peace Seminar for the Asia, Pacific and Western Asia Regions, 20 May 1985 *[http://statements.bahai.org/pdf/86-0526.pdf Statement on the Year of Peace], by the Bahá'í International Community, as a Statement to the Fifth session of the South Pacific Commission (SPC) Committee of Representatives of Governments and Administrations (CARGA), Noumea, New Caledonia, 26–30 May 1986 </ref>
* Related to the [[International Year of Peace]] in 1986, public conferences and seminars were organized in several countries.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Germany proclaims message of peace|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1986 | number = 662|ISSN=0195-9212 | page =12 |url = }}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine | title = India hosts 'World Peace Conference'|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1986 | number = 662|ISSN=0195-9212 | page =12 |url = }}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Pakistan |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1986 | number = 662|ISSN=0195-9212 | page =14 |url = }}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine | title = Association's 11th annual Conference |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1986 | number = 662|ISSN=0195-9212 | page =8 |url = }}</ref>
* Bahá'ís and interested parties have participated in an annual conference since 1999 sponsored by the Rabbani Charitable Trust in Orlando Florida.<ref>{{Cite web | title = Social and Economic Development Conference History | work = | publisher = Rabbani Charitable Trust | url = http://rabbanitrust.org/pages/695-sed-history | accessdate = 2012-11-04}}</ref> [[Mildred Mottahedeh]] gave nearly all her wealth away by establishing charities such as the Mottahedeh Development Services. The Bahá'í Chair for World Peace is located at the Center for International Development and Conflict Management under the auspices of the College of Behaviorial and Social Sciences at the [[University of Maryland]].<ref>{{Cite web | title = The Baha'i Chair for World Peace | work = | publisher = The Baha'i Chair for World Peace | year = 2015| url = http://bahaichair.umd.edu | accessdate = 2015-06-01}}</ref>
==List of Bahá'í-inspired organizations== Some larger scale examples are: *[[FUNDAEC]], Colombia *[[New Era High School]], India *[[Barli Development Institute for Rural Women]], India *[[Banani International Secondary School]], Zambia *[[Nur University]], Bolivia *[[School of the Nations (Bahá'í – Brazil)|School of the Nations]], Brazil *[[School of the Nations (Macau)|School of the Nations]], Macau *[[Townshend International School]], Czech Republic *[[Tahirih Justice Center]], United States
==See also== *[[Bahá'í Faith and gender equality]] *[[Ruhi Institute]] *[[Bahá'í radio]] *[[Bahá'í school]] *[[Bahá'í Faith by country]] *[[Huqúqu'lláh]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== *{{Cite book|last = Arbab|first = Farzam|authorlink=Farzam Arbab|editor-last = Harper|editor-first = Sharon|title = The Lab, the Temple, and the Market|contribution = Promoting a Discourse on Science, Religion, and Development|year = 2000|publisher = International Development Research Centre|place = Ottawa, ON, Canada|isbn = 0889369208 | url = http://web.idrc.ca/openebooks/920-8/#page_149 | ref = harv }} * Bahá’í Office of Social and Economic Development (2018). ''[http://www.bahai.org/documents/osed/betterment-world.pdf?a28125bc For the Betterment of the World: The Worldwide Bahá'í Community's Approach to Social and Economic Development]''.
==External links== *[http://www.bahai.org/dir/social_action/sed Bahai.org: Social and Economic Development] *[http://www.bahai.org/widening-embrace A Widening Embrace] (chapter 3; 2018 documentary film on bahai.org) *[http://www.globalprosperity.org Institute for Studies in Global Prosperity (ISGP)] *[http://media.bahai.org Photographs of Bahá’ís alongside others, contributing to the betterment of society] *[http://bahai-charity.weebly.com/bahai-charitable-agencies.html Baha'i-Inspired Charitable Agencies and Social and Economic Development Organizations]
{{Bahá'í-2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Socioeconomic Development (Baha'i)}} [[Category:Bahá'í practices]] [[Category:Economic development]]
