revision.text:
{{Use New Zealand English|date=January 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox Ethnic group |group = Turkish New Zealanders |image = |caption = |pop = 957 (2013 census){{cite web|title=2013 Census ethnic group profiles: Turkish|url=http://archive.stats.govt.nz/Census/2013-census/profile-and-summary-reports/ethnic-profiles.aspx?request_value=24775&tabname=Populationandgeography|publisher=Statistics New Zealand|accessdate=13 September 2018}}
est.2,000-3,000{{cite web|url=http://pif.org.nz/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=73:question-how-many-turks-living-in-new-zealand-&catid=46:turkish-community&Itemid=79|title=How many Turks living in New Zealand?|publisher=Pearl of the Islands Foundation|accessdate=29 October 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100513092537/http://pif.org.nz/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=73:question-how-many-turks-living-in-new-zealand-&catid=46:turkish-community&Itemid=79|archivedate=13 May 2010|df=dmy-all}}
plus {{circa|1,600}} [[Turkish Cypriots]]{{cite web|first=Esra|last=Türkel|url=http://www.starkibris.net/index.asp?haberID=125704|title=Sözünüzü tutun|trans-title=Keep your promise|language=tr|publisher=starkibris.net|date=26 July 2012|accessdate=7 January 2018}} |popplace = [[Wellington]]{{·}}[[Dunedin]]{{·}}[[Christchurch]]{{·}}[[Auckland]] |langs = [[New Zealand English]], [[Turkish language|Turkish]] |rels = [[Sunni Islam]], [[Alevi Islam]]}} '''Turkish New Zealanders''' or '''New Zealand Turks''' are [[Turkish people]] who are [[New Zealanders|New Zealand citizens]], residents of [[New Zealand]], or people who are of Turkish descent. Most have come to [[New Zealand]] from [[Turkey]] and the island of [[Cyprus]]. In addition, there are also recent Turkish arrivals (mostly refugees) from [[Iraq]] and [[Syria]]. The Turkish people are one of the most visible immigrant groups from the Middle East. They operate their own businesses specialising in traditional [[Turkish food]], such as [[kebab]], [[baklava]], and [[Turkish delight]].{{cite encyclopedia|first1=James|last1=Veitch|first2=Dalia|last2=Tinawi|url=https://teara.govt.nz/en/middle-eastern-peoples/page-4|encyclopedia=Te Ara - the Encyclopedia of New Zealand|title=Other Middle Eastern peoples: The Turks and others|date=8 February 2005|accessdate=7 January 2018}} ==Demographics== ===Population=== According to the 2013 census, the Turkish ethnic group accounted for 957 residents, which was a 49.5% increase from the 2006 census. This was a greater percentage increase than the 47.6% increase between the 2001 and 2006 censuses. ===Areas of settlement=== The majority of Turkish New Zelanders live in urban areas, mostly in the [[North Island]] (80.6%) and the remainder live in the [[South Island]] (19.4%). The Turkish community mostly live in the [[Auckland Region]] (mostly in the [[Waitematā Local Board]], the [[Devonport-Takapuna Local Board]], and the [[Orakei Local Board]]), followed by the [[Wellington Region]], and the [[Otago Region]]. == Notable people == *[[Ayse Tezel]] *[[Murat Yanbakan]] == See also == *[[Turkish Australians]] *[[New Zealand–Turkey relations]] *[[Turkish Diaspora]] *[[Arab New Zealanders]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://pif.org.nz Pearl of the Islands Foundation], a Turkish cultural foundation in New Zealand *[http://www.turkish.org.nz/ New Zealand Turkish Society] *[http://www.turkish.co.nz/ Murat YANBAKAN Turkish Translator in New Zealand] {{Turkish people by country}} {{Immigration to New Zealand}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Turks In New Zealand}} [[Category:Turkish diaspora by country|New Zealand]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in New Zealand]] [[Category:New Zealand people of Turkish descent| ]]

The '''wealth effect''' is the change in spending that accompanies a change in perceived [[wealth]].• Darby, Michael R. (1987). "wealth effect," ''[[The New Palgrave: A Dictionary of Economics]]'', v. 4, pp. 883–4.
   • {{cite web |url=http://www.portfolio.com/views/blogs/odd-numbers/2008/06/17/in-praise-of-the-wealth-effect |title=In Praise of the Wealth Effect – Economics Blog – Zubin Jelveh – Odd Numbers – Portfolio.com |publisher=portfolio.com |accessdate=2009-04-20 |last=Jelveh |first=Zubin }} Usually the wealth effect is positive: spending changes in the same direction as perceived wealth. ==Effect on individuals== Changes in a [[consumer]]'s wealth cause changes in the amounts and distribution of his or her [[Consumption (economics)|consumption]]. People typically spend more overall when one of two things is true: when people ''actually are'' richer, objectively, or when people ''perceive themselves'' to be richer—for example, the assessed value of their [[Real estate pricing|home increases]], or a [[stock]] they own goes up in price. Demand for some goods (called [[inferior good]]s) decreases with increasing wealth. For example, consider consumption of cheap fast food versus steak. As someone becomes wealthier, their demand for cheap fast food is likely to decrease, and their demand for more expensive steak may increase. Consumption may be tied to relative wealth. Particularly when supply is highly inelastic—or in the case of monopoly—one's ability to purchase a good may be highly related to one's relative wealth in the economy. Consider for example the cost of real estate in a city with high average wealth (for example New York or London), in comparison to a city with a low average wealth. Supply is fairly inelastic, so if a [[helicopter drop]] (or [[gold rush]]) were to suddenly create large amounts of wealth in the low wealth city, those who did not receive this new wealth would rapidly find themselves crowded out of such markets, and materially worse off in terms of their ability to consume/purchase real estate (despite having participated in a weak [[Pareto improvement]]). In such situations, one cannot dismiss the relative effect of wealth on demand and supply, and cannot assume that these are static (see also [[General equilibrium]]). However, according to [[David Backus]] the wealth effect is not observable in economic data, at least in regard to increases or decreases in home or stock equity. For example, while the [[stock market boom]] in the late 1990s (q.v. [[dot-com bubble]]) increased the wealth of Americans, it did not produce a significant change in consumption, and after the crash, consumption did not decrease.{{cite web |url=http://www.slate.com/id/2193287/ |title=Debunking the "Wealth Effect": Declining house prices don't necessarily slow down consumer spending. |first=Christopher |last=Flavelle |publisher=Slate |date=2008-06-10}} Economist [[Dean Baker]] disagrees and says that “housing wealth effect” is well-known and is a standard part of economic theory and modeling, and that economists expect households to consume based on their wealth. He cites approvingly research done by Carroll and Zhou that estimates that households increase their annual consumption by 6 cents for every additional dollar of home equity.{{Citation |first=Baker |last=Dean |title=The End of Loser Liberalism |url = http://www.deanbaker.net/images/stories/documents/End-of-Loser-Liberalism.pdf |year=2011 |pages=18 |isbn=978-0-615-53349-0|publisher =Center for Economic and Policy Research}} ==See also== * [[Income effect]] * [[Income elasticity of demand]] * [[Money illusion]] * [[Ricardian equivalence]] * [[Wealth (economics)]] * [[Wealth elasticity of demand]] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Wealth]] [[Category:Economics effects]]

revision.text:
{{Use Pakistani English|date=February 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Zarina Baloch | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1934|12|29}} | birth_place = Allahabad Chand Village, [[Sindh]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2005|10|25|1934|12|29}} | death_place = | nationality = [[Pakistani]] | other_names = | known_for = | occupation = [[Folk singer]] | spouse = [[Rasul Bux Palejo]] (married in the 1960s) | children = [[Ayaz Latif Palijo]] (son){{cite news|last1=Palija|first1=Khair|title=Jiji Zarina laid to rest|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/163070/jiji-zarina-laid-to-rest|accessdate=20 February 2018|newspaper=Dawn|date=27 October 2005}}
Akhter Baloch (daughter) {{small|(from her first husband)}} | relatives = [[Sassui Palijo]] (granddaughter){{cite web|last1=Palijo|first1=Sassui|url=http://wn.com/Sassui_Palijo|website=wn.com website|title=PPP Senator Sassui Palijo raises the issue of QAU students in the Senate|accessdate=20 February 2018}} }} '''Zarina Baloch''' ({{lang-sd|'''زرينه بلوچ'''}}) (29 December 1934 – 25 October 2005) was a Pakistani [[folk music]] [[Singer|singer]], vocalist and composer. She was also an actress, Radio and TV artist, writer, teacher for over 30 years, [[Political Activist|political activist]] and [[social worker]]. ==Early life and family== She was born in 29 December 1934 in Allahdad Chand Village, [[Hyderabad, Sindh|Hyderabad]], [[Sindh]], [[Pakistan]] her mother, Gulroz, died in 1940 when Zarina was six years old. She studied with Mohammad Juman, who was also a [[Sindhi language|Sindhi]] singer. At early age 15 years, her family [[arranged marriage|arranged her marriage]] with a remote relative. She had two children: Akhter Baloch also known as Zina (born in 1952), and Aslam Parvez (born in 1957). However, Baloch and her husband disagreed on the subject of her [[further education]] and the pair were separated in 1958. Baloch joined [[Pakistan Broadcasting Corporation|Radio Hyderabad]] in 1960 and received her first Music Award in 1961. Then Zarina married Sindhi politician [[Rasool Bux Palijo]], their marriage took place in [[Hyderabad, Sindh|Hyderabad]] on 22 September 1964 and they had a son, [[Ayaz Latif Palijo]]. In 1967, she became a teacher at the Model School [[University of Sindh|Sindh University]]. She retired in 1997 and died in 2005 of [[Brain tumor|Brain Cancer]] in [[Liaquat National Hospital]].{{cite news|title=LEGENDARY HEROINE OF SINDH JEEJEE ZAREENA BALOCH|url=https://iaoj.wordpress.com/2010/10/22/legendary-heroine-of-sindh-jeejee-zareena-baloch/|date=22 October 2010|publisher=Indus Asia Online Journal |accessdate=20 February 2018}} ==Imprisonment and political activism== In 1979, Zarina was arrested and imprisoned in [[Sukkur]] and [[Karachi]] jails for leading the protests against [[President of Pakistan|President]] [[Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq|General Zia ul Haq]]'s [[Operation Fair Play|Martial Law]]. The songs and anthems sung by Zarina Baloch "Maan Chuke Balochani", "Man Yagehaan" and "Jeaey Sindh" became the musical symbols of [[Baloch people|Baloch]] and [[Sindhi people|Sindhi]] nationalism. Because of her struggle against the [[ruling class]]es and against [[gender discrimination]], [[feudalism]] and [[Military coups in Pakistan|martial laws]] of [[Ayub Khan (general)|Ayub Khan]] and [[Yahya Khan]], she earned the title of ''JeeJee'' (mother) of the [[Sindhi people]].{{cite web|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/272824|newspaper=Dawn|date=26 October 2007|title=HYDERABAD: Jiji Zarina Baloch remembered|accessdate=20 February 2018}}[https://tribune.com.pk/story/979023/in-loving-memory-jiji-zarina-baloch-remembered/ In loving memory: Jiji Zarina Baloch remembered] The Express Tribune (newspaper), Published 26 October 2015, Retrieved 20 February 2018 She was one of the leading founders of [[Sindhiani Tahreek]], [[Women’s Action Forum]], Sindhi Adabi Sangat and Sindhi Haree Committee. She was fluent in [[Sindhi language|Sindhi]], [[Urdu language|Urdu]], [[Saraiki language|Seraiki]], [[Balochi language|Balochi]], [[Persian language|Persian]], [[Arabic language|Arabic]] and [[Gujarati language|Gujrati]]. ==Awards and recognition== *[[Pride of Performance]] Award by the [[President of Pakistan]] in 1994 *[[Faiz Ahmed Faiz]] Award *[[Pakistan Television Corporation]] (PTV) Award *[[Lal Shahbaz Qalandar]] Award *[[Shah Abdul Latif Bhittai]] Award ==Art and literary contributions== She wrote many songs and poetry which became popular among the nationalists in [[Sindh]] and [[Balochistan, Pakistan|Balochistan]]. She was the author of several stories and poems, and her Book "Tunhinjee Gola Tunhinjoon Galhion" was published in 1992. ==Famous songs== * Jeay Sindh aen Jeay Sindh, Jam e Muhabat Piaye Sindh * Mor Tho Tilley Rana * Sabhka Moomal Sabbko Raarno * Tunhnjii Yaarii * Sindhri tey sir ker na dendo * Kaang Lanvain * Guzrii Vaii Barsaat * Bbii Khabar Na Aahai Par * Kiin Karyaan Maan * Jjariyan Bhar Jaaiyoon * Saavak Rat main Saanvara * Paee Yaad Aaya * Gehraa Gehraa Nairn ==See also== * [[List of Sindhi singers]] * [[Rasul Bux Palejo]] * [[Ayaz Latif Palijo]] * [[Sassui Palijo]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070318230709/http://www.atsindh.com:80/jjzb/index.html Profile of Zarina Baloch (archived)] {{Pride of Performance for Arts}} {{Sindhi nationalism}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Baloch, Zarina}} [[Category:1934 births]] [[Category:2005 deaths]] [[Category:Baloch people]] [[Category:Pakistani female singers]] [[Category:Pakistani folk singers]] [[Category:Pakistani human rights activists]] [[Category:Sindhi people]] [[Category:Pakistani feminists]] [[Category:Pakistani socialists]] [[Category:Recipients of the Pride of Performance]] [[Category:20th-century singers]] [[Category:Sindhi-language singers]] [[Category:Singers from Sindh]]
